1100.summary: The event logging service has shut down
1100.description: This is a normal event logged at time of shutdown
1100.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
1100.llm_technical_description: The logging service has shut down normally. This event typically occurs when system resources are exhausted and the service restarts automatically upon next use.

1101.summary: Audit events have been dropped by the transport.
1101.description: We have observed this event being logged upon restarting Windows after a dirty shutdown.
1101.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
1101.llm_technical_description: The observed event indicates that the system's audit logging process has been disabled during a restart following a dirty shutdown. This suggests potential issues such as misconfiguration, unauthorized activity, or an attempt to bypass normal security measures like file cleanup.

1102.description:
Event 1102 is logged whenever the Security log is cleared, REGARDLESS of the status of the Audit System Events audit policy. The Account Name and Domain Name fields identify the user who cleared the log.

Logon ID allows you to correlate backwards to the logon event (4624) as well as with other events logged during the same logon session.
1102.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
1102.llm_technical_description: An audit log was cleared without following the Audit System Events policy. The user who cleared the log is identified by Account Name and Domain Name fields. This event can potentially indicate an attempt to circumvent security controls, as it occurs during a logon session via Logon ID.

1104.summary: The security Log is now full
1104.description:
No more events will be logged until the log is expanded, cleared or configured to overwrite events.

This event indicates a "hole" in your audit trail and should be avoided with the implementation of an effective log management solution that collects events before they can be overwritten or before the log fills up.

"Do not overwrite events (clear log manually)" should only be used in conjunction with the security option "Audit: Shutdown system immediately if unable to log security audits". Of course these 2 settings together will cause the system outages if the log is allowed to fill up and would only be appropriate for systems with the highest integrity requirements on audit trails.
1104.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
1104.llm_technical_description: The 'Security Log is now full' event indicates that system logs may have reached capacity, potentially due to misconfigured logging settings or normal operation under high activity. This can prevent analysis tools from accessing recent data and might signal misconfiguration if not part of a controlled environment.

1105.description: This event is only logged when "When maximum log size is reached:" is set to "Archive the log when full, do not overwrite events". When the log reaches maximum size Windows saves it to %systemroot%\System32\Winevt\Logs\ with the file name Archive-Security-YYYY-MM-DD-HH-MM-SS-NNN.evtx.
1105.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
1105.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that the system log has reached its maximum size limit, triggering an automatic backup to the designated location. This is a normal system behavior to prevent data loss in case of critical issues or when system performance degrades.

1108.summary: The event logging service encountered an error
1108.description: I have observed this event on actual systems but have not been able to determine the cause. Start a discussion below if you get this event and have questions or comments.
1108.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
1108.llm_technical_description: The Event Processing Service encountered an error during its operation. This event is common in systems and may indicate a hardware failure, software issue, or potential malicious activity if unexpected behavior occurs.

4608.description: 4608 is an important security event: Any operating system is essentially defenseless when the operating system is down.
4608.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4608.llm_technical_description: The event 'Windows is starting up' under category 'Security State Change' indicates that Windows has initiated its boot process. The description suggests potential compromise of system state as any operating system being down could be vulnerable to attack.

4609.description: Despite the documentation, as of Release candidate1 this event is not found. Perhaps this is because the event logging service stops first (event 1100). This is funny since the same problem used to happen in NT. MS fixed it in 2000 and looks like they broke it again at least as of RC1.
4609.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4609.llm_technical_description: This event, ID 4609, indicates that the Windows system is shutting down as expected. However, there's a note suggesting this issue might have been caused by changes in logging services after an attempted compromise. The event was previously consistent with issues seen before and after fixes, implying it could be related to compromised systems attempting to disrupt normal operations.

4610.summary: An authentication package has been loaded by the Local Security Authority
4610.description:
Event4610 is logged once at startup for each authentication package on the system. 

An authentication package is a DLL that encapsulates a given form of authentication, such as NTLM or Kerberos. The Local Security Authority calls into the appropriate authentication package during the logon process to find out if the user is authentic. 

Although a third party can develop an authentication package, few do so, except for smart card and token manufacturers. The only authentication package logged by Windows Server 2008 is C:\Windows\system32\msv1_0.dll : MICROSOFT_AUTHENTICATION_PACKAGE_V1_0 which is just one of the authentication options supported by Windows (See 514 for a list of standard authentication packages on Windows Server 2003). The other authentication options supported by Windows Server 2008 appear to now be part of a larger package called a security package. See 4622. From MSDN: "A security package that functions as an authentication package and implements the functionality required by SSPI is called a security support provider/authentication package (SSP/AP)."

The security implication of event 4610, realistically, is low. Although a rogue package could cause great harm by stealing credentials at the time of logon, the effort required in developing and installing a rogue authentication package is significant.
4610.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4610.llm_technical_description: Event 4610 indicates that an authentication package has been loaded during the system startup for each user logon, which is part of Windows' normal security mechanisms. This event confirms the successful verification process using established authentication methods like NTLM or Kerberos.

4611.summary: A trusted logon process has been registered with the Local Security Authority
4611.description:
An occurrence of event 4611 is logged at startup and occasionally afterwards for each logon process on the system. 

A logon process is a trusted part of the operating system and handles the overall logon function for different logon methods including incoming RAS connections, RunAs, interactive logons initiated by CtrlAltDel, and network logons (as in drive mappings). 

Because logon processes are such trusted functions, a rogue logon process would be a devastating security breach--but an improbable one, given the effort and skill required. 

Standard logon processes for Windows Server 2008:
4611.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4611.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4611</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>12289</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-10-14T03:43:29.604031000Z" /> <EventRecordID>1048175</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="516" ThreadID="548" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-18</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">DC01$</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x3e7</Data> <Data Name="LogonProcessName">Winlogon</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4611.llm_technical_description: A trusted logon process has been registered with the Local Security Authority (LSA). This event occurs at startup and occasionally after logons. The presence of this event could indicate normal system operations or potential unauthorized activity if linked to an unknown actor using Rubeus for malicious purposes.

4612.summary: Internal resources allocated for the queuing of audit messages have been exhausted, leading to the loss of some audits.
4612.description: This event has not been observed but would indicate that an extremely high period of activity prevented Windows from logginga number of security events.
4612.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4612.llm_technical_description: The internal system resources for auditing messages are exhausted, leading to the loss of some security audits. This suggests high activity or potential denial-of-service attempts during normal operations.

4614.summary: A notification package has been loaded by the Security Account Manager.
4614.description:
An occurrence of Event4614 is logged for each notification package on the system. 

Notification packages are DLLs that Windows calls into whenenever a user changes his/her password. The purpose of a notification package is to let you evaluate passwords against your own rules for acceptability. The notification package answers back whether or not the password is acceptable. Notification packages are also used to implement password synchronization systems. 

A rogue notification package would be a devastating security breach because notification packages are supplied with the clear text of the password and are simpler to write and install than authentication packages and logon processes (see 4610, 4611, and 4622).
4614.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4614.llm_technical_description: A notification package loaded by the Security Account Manager indicates that a user has changed their password, which is part of normal system operations. However, if this occurs frequently or inappropriately, it may suggest unauthorized access attempts or vulnerabilities related to password management.

4615.description: LPC is used for communication between threads or processes or for communication between kernel mode and user mode components. The communication can be on the samecomputer between the client and server functions. In 2000 there were several LPC port spoofing vulnerabilities patched for Windows NT.
4615.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4615.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that an application is using the LPC (Large Patch) port inappropriately. LPC ports are typically used for specific types of communication within Windows, such as between kernel-mode components or certain high-security operations. The use of these ports without proper authorization can be a sign of malicious activity, especially if it involves attempts to exploit known vulnerabilities related to improper handling of these ports. This event aligns with potential attacker behaviors that aim to bypass security controls or gain unauthorized access.

4616.description: This event indicates the old and new system time as well as who did it as specified in the Subject: section. Process information shows the program that was used to change the time. Changing the time manually from the taskbar uses rundll.exe as shown in the example.
4616.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022

4616.llm_technical_description: The system time was changed, potentially by an unauthorized user or application via the taskbar interface using rundll.exe.

4618.summary: A monitored security event pattern has occurred
4618.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4618.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4618</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>12290</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-11-11T21:42:33.264246700Z" /> <EventRecordID>1198759</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="500" ThreadID="528" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="EventId">4624</Data> <Data Name="ComputerName">DC01.contoso.local</Data> <Data Name="TargetUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="TargetUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="TargetUserDomain">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="TargetLogonId">0x1</Data> <Data Name="EventCount">10</Data> <Data Name="Duration">“Hour"</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4618.llm_technical_description: Insufficient information provided to generate a technical description.

4621.description: In testing I configured the log to crash on audit failure and then filled up the security log which indeed brought the system down. I rebooted, reset the CrashOnAuditFail registry setting, cleared the log and restarted. The event was never logged.
4621.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4621.llm_technical_description: This event logs a system recovery attempt after an audit failure was configured. The attempt resulted in a system crash but failed to generate a log entry despite being rebooted and settings reset.

4622.summary: A security package has been loaded by the Local Security Authority.
4622.description: Security packages are yet another type of plug-in that extends security functionality in Windows. MSDN defines a security package as "The software implementation of a security protocol. Security packages are contained in security support provider DLLs or security support provider/authentication package DLLs." From http://msdn2.microsoft.com/en-us/library/aa380130.aspx: Windows operating system supports authentication using security packages that function as both security support providers and as authentication packages. Security packages provide the logon process support services of a Windows authentication package and also provide authentication services to applications by implementing a set of functions that are mapped to the Security Support Provider Interface (SSPI). The security implication of event 4622realistically, is low. Although a rogue package could cause great harm by stealing credentials at the time of logon, the effort required in developing and installing a rogue security package is significant.
4622.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4622.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a security package has been loaded by the Local Security Authority (LSA). Security packages are extensions of Windows' security functionality, often used for authentication and support services. While normal operation can involve legitimate security updates or extensions, an unusual or unrecognized security package could indicate malicious activity if it is unauthorized or contains malicious code.

4624.summary: An account was successfully logged on
4624.description: This is a highly valuable event since it documents each and everysuccessful attemptto logon to the local computer regardless of logon type, location of the user or type of account. You can tie this event to logoff events 4634 and 4647 using Logon ID.
4624.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4624.llm_technical_description: This is a highly suspicious successful logon attempt with logon type 9 (NewCredentials), indicating potential token impersonation or theft. The event may be related to an attempt to leverage a Kerberos relay attack, which could elevate privileges locally from domain-joined limited users to local system administrative privileges. Multiple similar logons could indicate a targeted attack pattern.

4625.summary: An account failed to log on
4625.description: This is a useful event because it documents each and every failed attempt to logon to the local computer regardless of logon type, location of the user or type of account.
4625.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
