4625.llm_technical_description: This event indicates a failed login attempt that may involve unauthorized access due to suspicious reasons, such as using tools targeting the BlueKeep vulnerability (CVE-2019-0708). The event is recorded from a public IP address and could signal potential tampering or external attack attempts.

4626.operating_systems: Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4626.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4626</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>12553</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-09-10T00:12:02.243396300Z" /> <EventRecordID>232648</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="516" ThreadID="1092" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-0-0</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">-</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">-</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x0</Data> <Data Name="TargetUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="TargetUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="TargetDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="TargetLogonId">0x136f7b</Data> <Data Name="LogonType">3</Data> <Data Name="EventIdx">1</Data> <Data Name="EventCountTotal">1</Data> <Data Name="UserClaims">ad://ext/cn:88d2b96fdb2b4c49 <%%1818> : "dadmin" ad://ext/Department:88d16a8edaa8c66b <%%1818> : "IT"</Data> <Data Name="DeviceClaims">-</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4626.llm_technical_description: Insufficient information provided to determine the nature of this event. The summary indicates a user or device claiming information during a logon/lo↵off subcategory. Without specific details (e.g., username, domain name), it is challenging to assess if this activity is malicious or legitimate.

4627.description: This is the only event of it's new Group Membership subcategory.  One or more of these events are logged whenever a user logs on or a logon session begins for any other reason (see LogonTypes on 4624).
4627.operating_systems: Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4627.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4627</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>12554</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-11-12T03:51:25.843673000Z" /> <EventRecordID>3081</EventRecordID> <Correlation ActivityID="{913FBE70-1CE6-0000-67BF-3F91E61CD101}" /> <Execution ProcessID="736" ThreadID="808" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>WIN-GG82ULGC9GO.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-0-0</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">-</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">-</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x0</Data> <Data Name="TargetUserSid">S-1-5-21-1377283216-344919071-3415362939-1104</Data> <Data Name="TargetUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="TargetDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="TargetLogonId">0x569860</Data> <Data Name="LogonType">3</Data> <Data Name="EventIdx">1</Data> <Data Name="EventCountTotal">1</Data> <Data Name="GroupMembership">%{S-1-5-21-1377283216-344919071-3415362939-513} %{S-1-1-0} %{S-1-5-32-544} %{S-1-5-32-545} %{S-1-5-32-554} %{S-1-5-2} %{S-1-5-11} %{S-1-5-15} %{S-1-5-21-1377283216-344919071-3415362939-512} %{S-1-5-21-1377283216-344919071-3415362939-572} %{S-1-5-64-10} %{S-1-16-12288}</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4627.llm_technical_description: A user has been granted membership in a new group on the system. This event is typically logged during logon attempts or sessions.

4634.description:
Also see event ID 4647which Windows logs instead of this eventin the case of interactive logonswhen the user logs out.

This event signals the end of a logon session and can be correlated back to the logon event 4624 using the Logon ID.

For network connections (such as to a file server), it will appear that users log on and off many times a day. This phenomenon is caused by the way the Server service terminates idle connections. 

If a user turns off his/her computer, Windows does not have an opportunity to log the logoff event until the system restarts. Therefore, some logoff events are logged much later than the time at which they actually occur. 

ANONYMOUS LOGONs are routine events on Windows networks.

Microsoft's comments: 
This event does not necessarily indicate the time that a user has stopped using a system. For example, if the computer is shut down or loses network connectivity it may not record a logoff event at all. 

Logon Type: indicates how the user was logged on. See 4624 for explanation of these codes.
4634.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4634.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4634</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>12545</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-09-09T02:27:57.877205900Z" /> <EventRecordID>230019</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="516" ThreadID="832" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="TargetUserSid">S-1-5-90-1</Data> <Data Name="TargetUserName">DWM-1</Data> <Data Name="TargetDomainName">Window Manager</Data> <Data Name="TargetLogonId">0x1a0992</Data> <Data Name="LogonType">2</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4634.llm_technical_description: This event (ID 4634) indicates a user logoff. It is part of the Windows Logon/Logoff category and can be correlated with other logoff events like ID 4647 for interactive logons. The Logon ID links it back to the initiate event, 4624. Network connections may show frequent logoffs due to Server service termination, which could occur if a user shuts down or loses network access. Logs are only recorded after system restarts in some cases.

4646.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4646.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that the system has initiated DoS-prevention mode in IKE tunneling (now known as IPsec). This action is typically taken to protect against potential denial of service attacks by modifying network tunneling parameters. The fact that it's now active suggests that the system may be monitoring or adjusting its security settings to prevent such threats.

4647.description:
Also see 4634. This event signals the end of a logon session and can be correlated back to the logon event 4624 using the Logon ID.
This event seems to be in place of 4634 in the case of Interactive and RemoteInteractive (remote desktop)logons. This is a plus since it makes it easier to distinguish between logoffs resulting from an idle network session and logoffs where the user actually logs off with from his console.
4647.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4647.llm_technical_description: This event indicates a user has initiated a logoff from an interactive or remote desktop session. It serves as an alternative to another event (4634) in cases where the user actually logs off, aiding in distinguishing between idle and active logoffs.

4648.summary: A logon was attempted using explicit credentials
4648.description: This is a useful event for tracking several different situations:
4648.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4648.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4648</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>12544</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-09-10T02:54:50.771459000Z" /> <EventRecordID>233200</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="516" ThreadID="1116" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x31844</Data> <Data Name="LogonGuid">{00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000}</Data> <Data Name="TargetUserName">ladmin</Data> <Data Name="TargetDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="TargetLogonGuid">{0887F1E4-39EA-D53C-804F-31D568A06274}</Data> <Data Name="TargetServerName">localhost</Data> <Data Name="TargetInfo">localhost</Data> <Data Name="ProcessId">0x368</Data> <Data Name="ProcessName">C:\\\\Windows\\\\System32\\\\svchost.exe</Data> <Data Name="IpAddress">::1</Data> <Data Name="IpPort">0</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4648.llm_technical_description: The event details indicate a logon attempt using explicit credentials, which could be an unauthorized access attempt potentially from an attacker trying to exploit system permissions or bypass authentication mechanisms.

4649.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4649.llm_technical_description: The replay attack detection indicates an attempted Kerberos Replay Attack on domain controllers, where a legitimate Kerberos response ('KRB_AP_ERR_REPEAT') was intercepted and reused. This suggests potential unauthorized access attempts to critical system functions.

4650.summary: An IPsec Main Mode security association was established
4650.description: An IPsec Main Mode security association was established. Extended Mode was not enabled. Certificate authentication was not used.
4650.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4650.llm_technical_description: An IPsec Main Mode security association was established during a user logon. This indicates potential vulnerabilities where sensitive data such as login credentials might be exchanged without the recommended use of Encrypted Key Exchange (EKE) or certificate authentication, increasing the risk of man-in-the-middle attacks.

4651.summary: An IPsec Main Mode security association was established
4651.description: An IPsec Main Mode security association was established. Extended Mode was not enabled. A certificate was used for authentication.
4651.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4651.llm_technical_description: An IPsec Main Mode security association was established as part of the user authentication process. This event is typical for systems using secure communication protocols during logon events.

4652.summary: An IPsec Main Mode negotiation failed
4652.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4652.llm_technical_description: The event indicates an IPsec Main Mode negotiation failure during a logon or logoff process. This suggests potential security issues such as misconfigured tunnels, certificate problems, or attempts by attackers to disrupt secure communications.

4653.summary: An IPsec Main Mode negotiation failed
4653.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4653.llm_technical_description: The IPsec Main Mode negotiation failure indicates a potential security risk related to secure tunneling protocols such as Open vSwitch or Virtual Private Networks (VPNs). This could be due to incorrect credentials, configuration issues, or malicious activities like Man-in-the-Middle attempts.

4654.summary: An IPsec Quick Mode negotiation failed
4654.description: An IPsec Quick Mode negotiation failed
4654.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4654.llm_technical_description: The event indicates a failure in negotiating IPsec Quick Mode during logon or logoff. This could be due to misconfigured VPN settings or potential attack attempts where unauthorized users attempt to access protected network services.

4655.summary: An IPsec Main Mode security association ended
4655.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4655.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that an IPsec Main Mode security association was terminated. While there is no specific reason for the termination provided, this could be indicative of a potential misconfiguration or attack attempt if additional context (such as connection details) is available.

4656.summary: A handle to an object was requested
4656.subcategory: File System Registry SAM Handle Manipulation Other Object Access Events
4656.description:
This event is logged by multiple subcategories as indicated above.

When you enable auditing on an object(e.g. file or folder), this is the first event recorded when an application attempts to access the object in such a way that matches the audit policy defined for that object in terms of who is requesting the access and what type of access is being requested.(it appears that two subcategories must be enabled, Handle Manipulation and one other such as File System or Registry depending on what type of object you are auditing.)
4656.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4656.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4656</EventID> <Version>1</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>12800</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8010000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-09-18T22:15:19.346776600Z" /> <EventRecordID>274057</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="516" ThreadID="524" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x4367b</Data> <Data Name="ObjectServer">Security</Data> <Data Name="ObjectType">File</Data> <Data Name="ObjectName">C:\\\\Documents\\\\HBI Data.txt</Data> <Data Name="HandleId">0x0</Data> <Data Name="TransactionId">{00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000}</Data> <Data Name="AccessList">%%1538 %%1541 %%4416 %%4417 %%4418 %%4419 %%4420 %%4423 %%4424</Data> <Data Name="AccessReason">%%1538: %%1804 %%1541: %%1809 %%4416: %%1809 %%4417: %%1809 %%4418: %%1802 D:(D;;LC;;;S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104) %%4419: %%1809 %%4420: %%1809 %%4423: %%1811 D:(A;OICI;FA;;;S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104) %%4424: %%1809</Data> <Data Name="AccessMask">0x12019f</Data> <Data Name="PrivilegeList">-</Data> <Data Name="RestrictedSidCount">0</Data> <Data Name="ProcessId">0x1074</Data> <Data Name="ProcessName">C:\\\\Windows\\\\System32\\\ otepad.exe</Data> <Data Name="ResourceAttributes">S:AI(RA;ID;;;;WD;("Impact\\_MS",TI,0x10020,3000))</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4656.EventName: Audit Kernel Object; Audit File System; Audit Registry; Audit Removable Storage
4656.llm_technical_description: This event logs an attempt to access a handle in the Windows Registry, specifically involving interactions with the LSASS process and possibly related to non-system accounts. The event details indicate potential unauthorized attempts to manipulate system registry keys or access sensitive processes, which could be indicative of malicious activity such as command execution or credential theft, especially when combined with audit policies that monitor for suspicious behavior.

4657.description: This event documents creation, modification and deletion of registry VALUES. This event is logged between the open (4656)and close (4658)events for the registry KEY where the value resides. See Operation Type to find out if the value was created, modified or deleted. Of course this event will only be logged if the key'saudit policy is enabled for Set Value permissionfor the appropriate user or a group in the user is a member.
4657.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4657.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4657</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>12801</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-09-24T01:28:43.639634100Z" /> <EventRecordID>744725</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="4" ThreadID="4824" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x364eb</Data> <Data Name="ObjectName">\\\\REGISTRY\\\\MACHINE</Data> <Data Name="ObjectValueName">Name\\_New</Data> <Data Name="HandleId">0x54</Data> <Data Name="OperationType">%%1905</Data> <Data Name="OldValueType">%%1873</Data> <Data Name="OldValue" /> <Data Name="NewValueType">%%1873</Data> <Data Name="NewValue">Andrei</Data> <Data Name="ProcessId">0xce4</Data> <Data Name="ProcessName">C:\\\\Windows\\\\regedit.exe</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4657.llm_technical_description: This event logs modifications (creation, modification, or deletion) of a registry value within the Object Access category under Registry subcategory. The event is triggered when a user or process attempts to modify a specific registry key, such as those related to Windows Defender exclusions, microphone capabilities, or webcam access. If the registry key's audit policy for Set Value permission is enabled, this event will be logged.

4658.summary: The handle to an object was closed
4658.subcategory: File System Registry Kernel Object SAM Handle Manipulation Other Object Access Events
4658.description: This event is logged by multiple subcategories as indicated above.
4658.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4658.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4658</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>12800</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-09-22T00:15:42.910428100Z" /> <EventRecordID>276724</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="4" ThreadID="5056" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x4367b</Data> <Data Name="ObjectServer">Security</Data> <Data Name="HandleId">0x18a8</Data> <Data Name="ProcessId">0xef0</Data> <Data Name="ProcessName">C:\\\\Windows\\\\explorer.exe</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4658.EventName: Audit Kernel Object; Audit Handle Manipulation; Audit Removable Storage; Audit File System; Audit Registry
4658.llm_technical_description: The handle was closed as indicated by multiple events including 4658 which is under Object Access Category and File System Registry Kernel Object SAM Handle Manipulation Other Object Access Events Subcategory. The event summary indicates that this handle closure could be related to file system activities such as deletion or modification.

4659.summary: A handle to an object was requested with intent to delete
4659.subcategory: File System Registry Other Object Access Events
4659.description: This event should be logged whenever your install a patch that requires replacement of a file that is already opened by Windows and can't be closed until shut down.
4659.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4659.llm_technical_description: This event logs when a handle to an object is requested with intent to delete. This typically occurs during system updates or patches that replace files in the Windows File System Registry. The event itself does not inherently indicate malicious activity unless it is repeated unusually or involves critical system objects.

4660.subcategory: File System Registry Kernel Object SAM Other Object Access Events
4660.description:
This event is logged by multiple subcategories as indicated above.

This event is logged when an object is deleted where that object's audit policy has auditing enabled for deletions for the user who just deleted it or a group to which the user belongs.

To find out the object's name and type you will need to correlate back to to the event 4656 that has the same Handle ID.

In addition to this event you will also get event 4663 when you delete the object; Accesses: will include DELETE.4663 identifies the object's name without requiring correlation to 4656.
4660.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4660.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4660</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>12800</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-09-18T21:05:28.677152100Z" /> <EventRecordID>270188</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="4" ThreadID="3060" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x4367b</Data> <Data Name="ObjectServer">Security</Data> <Data Name="HandleId">0x1678</Data> <Data Name="ProcessId">0xef0</Data> <Data Name="ProcessName">C:\\\\Windows\\\\explorer.exe</Data> <Data Name="TransactionId">{00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000}</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4660.EventName: Audit Kernel Object; Audit File System; Audit Registry
4660.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that an object was deleted without explicit auditing enabled for deletions by the user who performed the deletion or their group. This could be an unauthorized action, as deletion of objects like devices or files may bypass security checks if auditing is not configured.

4661.summary: A handle to an object was requested
4661.subcategory: Kernel Object SAMDirectory Service              Directory Service Access
4661.description:
This event is logged by multiple subcategories as indicated above.

Most objects, when opened (handle request), generate event 4656 but when you open a SAM object you get 4661 instead.

Some AD objects also double as SAM objects and some properties of those objects double as SAM attributes. This event is logged when opening such SAM objects such as SAM_DOMAIN or SAM_USER. 

When the object is closed you get event ID 4658 with the same handle ID.

I regard these events as noise and recommend disabling the SAM subcategory in your audit policy.
4661.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4661.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4661</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>14080</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-09-30T00:11:56.547696700Z" /> <EventRecordID>1048009</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="520" ThreadID="528" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x4280e</Data> <Data Name="ObjectServer">Security Account Manager</Data> <Data Name="ObjectType">SAM\\_DOMAIN</Data> <Data Name="ObjectName">DC=contoso,DC=local</Data> <Data Name="HandleId">0xdd64d36870</Data> <Data Name="TransactionId">{00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000}</Data> <Data Name="AccessList">%%5400</Data> <Data Name="AccessMask">0x2d</Data> <Data Name="PrivilegeList">Ā</Data> <Data Name="Properties">-</Data> <Data Name="RestrictedSidCount">2949165</Data> <Data Name="ProcessId">0x9000a000d002d</Data> <Data Name="ProcessName">{bf967a90-0de6-11d0-a285-00aa003049e2} %%5400 {ccc2dc7d-a6ad-4a7a-8846-c04e3cc53501}</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4661.EventName: Audit Directory Service Access; Audit SAM
4661.llm_technical_description: The event ID 4661 logs when a handle to a SAM object is requested for opening. This is a normal activity observed on domain controllers when interacting with SAM (Shared Access Manager) objects, such as SAM_DOMAIN or SAM_USER. The event is typically logged by these objects and should be considered noise in normal operations. However, if accompanied by other suspicious activities, it may indicate potential security issues such as unauthorized access attempts or privileged user/group reconstructions.

4662.summary: An operation was performed on an object
4662.description:
Active Directory logs this event when a user accesses an AD object. 

Of course the object's audit policy must be enabled for the permissions requested and the user requesting it or a group to which that user belongs.

For tracking property level changes to AD objects I recommend using Directory Service Change events (5136...) instead of this event because 5136, etc providemuch better information. 

On the other hand this is the only event that reports accesses defined for auditing that do not qualify as property changes.
4662.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4662.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4662</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>14080</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-08-28T01:58:36.894922400Z" /> <EventRecordID>407230</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="520" ThreadID="600" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x35867</Data> <Data Name="ObjectServer">DS</Data> <Data Name="ObjectType">%{bf967a86-0de6-11d0-a285-00aa003049e2}</Data> <Data Name="ObjectName">%{38b3d2e6-9948-4dc1-ae90-1605d5eab9a2}</Data> <Data Name="OperationType">Object Access</Data> <Data Name="HandleId">0x0</Data> <Data Name="AccessList">%%1537</Data> <Data Name="AccessMask">0x10000</Data> <Data Name="Properties">%%1537 {bf967a86-0de6-11d0-a285-00aa003049e2}</Data> <Data Name="AdditionalInfo">-</Data> <Data Name="AdditionalInfo2" /> </EventData> </Event>
4662.llm_technical_description: The event indicates a WRITE_DAC operation on an Active Directory (AD) object, potentially indicating unauthorized access or malicious activity such as Mimikatz DC sync, AD replication from non-machine accounts, or extraction of domain backup keys. The event is triggered when users access AD objects requiring auditing, but may also occur for legitimate purposes like property changes. The Sigma rule further analyzes this event by checking properties like WMI filters, access masks, and subject usernames to detect suspicious activities.

4663.summary: An attempt was made to access an object
4663.subcategory: File System Registry Kernel Object SAM Other Object Access Events
4663.description:
This event is logged by multiple subcategories as indicated above.

This event documents actual operations performed against files and other objects.This event is logged between the open (4656)and close (4658)events for the object being opened and can be correlated to those events via Handle ID. 

While event 4656tells you when the object is initially opened and what type of access was requested at that time; 4656 doesn't give you positive confirmation any of the access permissions were actually exercised. That is the role of this event. This event, 4663, is logged the first time one or more of the requested permissions are actually exercised. If the program repeatedly exercises a permission while the object is open, Windows only logs 4663 the first time.
4663.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4663.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4663</EventID> <Version>1</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>12800</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-09-18T22:13:54.770429700Z" /> <EventRecordID>273866</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="516" ThreadID="524" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x4367b</Data> <Data Name="ObjectServer">Security</Data> <Data Name="ObjectType">File</Data> <Data Name="ObjectName">C:\\\\Documents\\\\HBI Data.txt</Data> <Data Name="HandleId">0x1bc</Data> <Data Name="AccessList">%%4417 %%4418</Data> <Data Name="AccessMask">0x6</Data> <Data Name="ProcessId">0x458</Data> <Data Name="ProcessName">C:\\\\Windows\\\\System32\\\ otepad.exe</Data> <Data Name="ResourceAttributes">S:AI(RA;ID;;;;WD;("Impact\\_MS",TI,0x10020,3000))</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4663.EventName: Audit Kernel Object; Audit File System; Audit Registry; Audit Removable Storage
4663.llm_technical_description: This event logs an attempt to access an object under the Object Access category in Windows. It is part of the File System Registry Kernel Object SAM Other Object Access Events subcategory, indicating that it is tracking when specific permissions are actually used rather than just requested. The event details suggest it occurred between the open (EventID: 4656) and close (EventID: 4658) events for the object being accessed. This type of event is typically logged during legitimate operations, but in this case, due to Sigma detection rules, it may indicate suspicious activity related to unauthorized access attempts.

4664.summary: An attempt was made to create a hard link
4664.description: An attempt was made to create a hard link.
4664.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4664.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4664</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>12800</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-09-21T23:50:26.871375900Z" /> <EventRecordID>276680</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="4" ThreadID="2624" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x43659</Data> <Data Name="FileName">C:\\\ otepad.exe</Data> <Data Name="LinkName">C:\\\\Docs\\\\My.exe</Data> <Data Name="TransactionId">{00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000}</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4664.llm_technical_description: An attempt was made to create a hard link in the file system, which is typically used for efficient resource sharing by pointing to files or directories without duplicating their data. This action could indicate potential unauthorized access or malicious intent if performed with malicious purpose.

4665.summary: An attempt was made to create an application client context.
4665.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4665.llm_technical_description: The event ID 4665 indicates an attempt to create an application client context. This typically relates to user interactions with applications, such as launching multiple windows or using Windows features like Remote Desktop. The category and subcategory suggest it's part of normal user activities without specific malicious intent evident from the provided details.

4666.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4666.llm_technical_description: The event indicates an application attempted an operation under Object Access > Application Generated. However, due to the lack of detailed information (e.g., description or context), it is difficult to determine if this operation was legitimate or potentially malicious. Object Access events are typically benign unless repeated from multiple sources with high privileges.

4667.summary: An application client context was deleted
4667.description: This event is logged in connection with Authorization Manager access checks. See Establishing a Client Context with Authorization Manager in C++ for more details.
4667.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4667.llm_technical_description: An application client context was deleted, likely indicating unauthorized access or a potential security breach. The event is tied to Authorization Manager checks, suggesting an attempt to terminate a session without proper authorization.

4668.description: I haven't been able to produce this event. Have you? If so, please start a discussion (see above) and post a sample along with any comments you may have! Don't forget to sanitize any private information
4668.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4668.llm_technical_description: The event indicates an application was accessed as part of object-level operations. While this is a normal activity for applications to access objects they generate or utilize, the specific circumstances (e.g., unexpected behavior) could hint at malicious intent such as unauthorized access attempts or filesharing without proper permissions.

4670.summary: Permissions on an object were changed
4670.subcategory: File System RegistryPolicy Change                  Authorization Policy Change
4670.description:
Windows logs this event when someonechanges the access control list on an object. The event identifies the object, who changed the permissions and the old an new permissions.

Of course the object'saudit policy must have auditing enabled for "Write DAC"/"Change Permissions" or "Take Ownership" permissions for the user who just modified this object's access control list or a group to which the user belongs.
4670.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4670.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4670</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13570</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-09-18T19:36:50.187044600Z" /> <EventRecordID>269529</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="516" ThreadID="524" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x43659</Data> <Data Name="ObjectServer">Security</Data> <Data Name="ObjectType">File</Data> <Data Name="ObjectName">C:\\\\Documents\\\ etcat-1.11</Data> <Data Name="HandleId">0x3f0</Data> <Data Name="OldSd">D:AI(A;OICIID;FA;;;S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-2104)(A;OICIID;FA;;;S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104)(A;OICIID;FA;;;SY)(A;OICIID;FA;;;BA)</Data> <Data Name="NewSd">D:ARAI(A;OICI;FA;;;WD)(A;OICIID;FA;;;S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-2104)(A;OICIID;FA;;;S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104)(A;OICIID;FA;;;SY)(A;OICIID;FA;;;BA)</Data> <Data Name="ProcessId">0xdb0</Data> <Data Name="ProcessName">C:\\\\Windows\\\\System32\\\\dllhost.exe</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4670.EventName: Audit File System; Audit Registry; Audit Authentication Policy Change; Audit Authorization Policy Change
4670.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that an object's access control list was modified by a user or group member(s). This could be done maliciously to hide changes, as attackers may later change the object type to remove the audit trail. The event provides evidence of unauthorized access attempts but requires further investigation to determine if this is legitimate system configuration.

4671.summary: An application attempted to access a blocked ordinal through the TBS
4671.description: TBS is a part of Trusted Platform Module
4671.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4671.llm_technical_description: The application attempted to access a blocked ordinal through TBS (Trusted Platform Module), which is normally part of system initialization and legitimate operations. This activity is expected but could indicate unauthorized attempts, though without specific Sigma rule context, it's not flagged as suspicious.

4672.summary: Special privileges assigned to new logon
4672.description:
This event lets you know whenever an account assigned any "administrator equivalent" user rights logs on. For instance you will see event 4672 in close proximity to logon events (4624)for administrators since administrators have most of these admin-equivalent rights. 

So, this is a useful right to detecting any "super user" account logons. Of course this right is logged for any server or applications accounts logging on as a batch job (scheduled task) or system service. See Logon Type: on event ID 4624. You can correlate 4672 to 4624 by Logon ID:.

Note: "User rights" and "privileges" are synonymous terms used interchangeably in Windows.

Admin-equivalent rights are powerful authorities that allow you to circumvent other security controls in Windows. Most admin equivalent privileges are intended for services and applications that interact closely with the operating system. With just a few exceptions, most admin equivalent privileges neither need nor should be granted to human user accounts.
4672.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4672.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4672</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>12548</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-09-11T01:10:57.091809600Z" /> <EventRecordID>237692</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="504" ThreadID="524" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x671101</Data> <Data Name="PrivilegeList">SeTcbPrivilege SeSecurityPrivilege SeTakeOwnershipPrivilege SeLoadDriverPrivilege SeBackupPrivilege SeRestorePrivilege SeDebugPrivilege SeSystemEnvironmentPrivilege SeEnableDelegationPrivilege SeImpersonatePrivilege</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4672.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that an account with administrator equivalent privileges has logged on. This can be used to detect superuser accounts or suspicious logons, such as scheduled tasks or batch jobs that grant admin privileges.

4673.description:
Event 4673 indicates that the specified user exercised the user right specified in the Privileges field. 

Note: "User rights" and "privileges" are synonymous terms used interchangeably in Windows.

Some user rights are logged by this event - others by 4674. Still other, ""high-volume"" rights are not logged when they are exercised unless you enable the security option "Audit: Audit the use of Backup and Restore privilege". 

Unfortunately, Microsoft has overloaded these privileges so that each privilege may govern your authority to perform many different operations and which privilege is required for which operations is not well documented. Therefore seeing that a privilege was exercised doesn't really tell you much. In Win2008 this has been improved with better information in the Server: and Service Name: fields. In general though,Istillclassify these events as noise. Microsoft admits: "These are high volume events, which typically do not contain sufficient information to act upon since they do not describe what operation occurred."

Note: 4673 and 4674 do not log any activity associated with Logon Rights such as the SeNetworkLogonRight. Do not confuse events 4673 and 4674 with events 4717and 4718 which document rights assignment changes as opposed to the exercise of rights which is the purpose of events 4673and 4674.

Subject:

The ID and logon session of the user that excercised the right.
4673.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4673.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4673</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13056</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-10-09T00:37:36.434836600Z" /> <EventRecordID>1099777</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="496" ThreadID="504" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-18</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">DC01$</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x3e7</Data> <Data Name="ObjectServer">NT Local Security Authority / Authentication Service</Data> <Data Name="Service">LsaRegisterLogonProcess()</Data> <Data Name="PrivilegeList">SeTcbPrivilege</Data> <Data Name="ProcessId">0x1f0</Data> <Data Name="ProcessName">C:\\\\Windows\\\\System32\\\\lsass.exe</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4673.EventName: Audit Sensitive Privilege Use; Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use
4673.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that the specified user called a privileged service through LsaRegisterLogonProcess(). According to Sigma Rule 0x0001, this should only occur if the user has the SeTcbPrivilege privilege. The absence of this privilege could indicate unauthorized or unauthenticated access attempts.

4674.summary: An operation was attempted on a privileged object
4674.description:
Event 4674 indicates that the specified user exercised the user right specified in the Privileges field. 

Note: "User rights" and "privileges" are synonymous terms used interchangeably in Windows.

Some user rights are logged by 4674 - others by 4673. Still other, "high-volume" rights are not logged when they are exercised unless you enable the security option "Audit: Audit the use of Backup and Restore privilege". 

Unfortunately, Microsoft has overloaded these privileges so that each privilege may govern your authority to perform many different operations and which privilege is required for which operations is not well documented. Therefore seeing that a privilege was exercised doesn't really tell you much. In Win2008 this has been improved with better information in the Server: and Service Name: fields. In general though,Istillclassify these events as noise. Microsoft admits: "These are high volume events, which typically do not contain sufficient information to act upon since they do not describe what operation occurred."

Note: 4673 and 4674 do not log any activity associated with Logon Rights such as the SeNetworkLogonRight. Do not confuse events 4673 and 4674 with events 4717 and 4718 which document rights assignment changes as opposed to the exercise of rights which is the purpose of events 4673 and 4674.
4674.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4674.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4674</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13056</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8010000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-10-09T00:22:36.237816000Z" /> <EventRecordID>1099680</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="496" ThreadID="504" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-19</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">LOCAL SERVICE</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">NT AUTHORITY</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x3e5</Data> <Data Name="ObjectServer">LSA</Data> <Data Name="ObjectType">-</Data> <Data Name="ObjectName">-</Data> <Data Name="HandleId">0x0</Data> <Data Name="AccessMask">16777216</Data> <Data Name="PrivilegeList">SeSecurityPrivilege</Data> <Data Name="ProcessId">0x1f0</Data> <Data Name="ProcessName">C:\\\\Windows\\\\System32\\\\lsass.exe</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4674.EventName: Audit Sensitive Privilege Use; Audit Non Sensitive Privilege Use
4674.llm_technical_description: The event ID 4674 indicates that a user has executed a privilege on the 'servicesactive' object (SC_MANAGER OBJECT) related to the SCM database. This falls under Sensitive Privilege Use, suggesting potential unauthorized access or sensitive data handling.

4675.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4675.llm_technical_description: The event ID 4675, categorized under Logon/Logoff with the subcategory Logon, indicates that Session Information Data (SID) was filtered. This typically occurs when unauthorized login attempts are detected or when legitimate users have insufficient permissions to access resources. The filter action suggests that the system has taken necessary measures to prevent unauthorized access while maintaining user convenience.

4688.summary: A new process has been created
4688.description:
Event 4688 documents each program that is executed, who the program ran as and the process that started this process.

When you start a program you are creating a "process" that stays open until the program exits. This process is identified by the Process ID:. You can correlate this event to other events by Process ID to determine what the program did while it ran and when it exited (event 4689).
4688.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4688.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4688</EventID> <Version>2</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13312</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-11-12T02:24:52.377352500Z" /> <EventRecordID>2814</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="4" ThreadID="400" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>WIN-GG82ULGC9GO.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-18</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">WIN-GG82ULGC9GO$</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x3e7</Data> <Data Name="NewProcessId">0x2bc</Data> <Data Name="NewProcessName">C:\\\\Windows\\\\System32\\\\rundll32.exe</Data> <Data Name="TokenElevationType">%%1938</Data> <Data Name="ProcessId">0xe74</Data> <Data Name="CommandLine" /> <Data Name="TargetUserSid">S-1-5-21-1377283216-344919071-3415362939-1104</Data> <Data Name="TargetUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="TargetDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="TargetLogonId">0x4a5af0</Data> <Data Name="ParentProcessName">C:\\\\Windows\\\\explorer.exe</Data> <Data Name="MandatoryLabel">S-1-16-8192</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4688.llm_technical_description: This event (ID: 4688) is part of Windows' Process Tracking feature, which logs each program executed and their associated processes. It allows system administrators to track the execution flow of programs by recording the process IDs involved when a program starts (event 4688) and when it exits (event 4689). This information can be used to debug applications or monitor suspicious activities.

4689.description:
Event 4689 documents when a process ends. 

When you start a program you are creating a "process" that stays open until the program exits. This process is identified by the Process ID:. 

You can use this event to tell how long the program ran by correlating it to the earlier 4688 with the same Process ID.
4689.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4689.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4689</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13313</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-08-27T17:13:01.826339500Z" /> <EventRecordID>187030</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="4" ThreadID="144" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x31365</Data> <Data Name="Status">0x0</Data> <Data Name="ProcessId">0xfb0</Data> <Data Name="ProcessName">C:\\\\Windows\\\\System32\\\ otepad.exe</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4689.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that a process has terminated normally, which is expected when a program completes execution. However, if there's no known context or behavior for this process termination (e.g., it might be running a malicious script or backdoor), it could indicate potential malicious activity. The absence of known false positives suggests that the event should be monitored for signs of abnormal persistence or unexpected termination patterns.

4690.summary: An attempt was made to duplicate a handle to an object
4690.description:
When a program opens an object like a file, it gets a "handle" to that file which it references in subsequent operations on the object. Windows checks permissions at the time of the open (aka handle request) but not afterwards. Windows allows you to duplicate a handle and hand it off to another thread or process which then inherits whatever level of access the first program obtained to the object when the program opened. Therefore a thread impersonating a different user or a process running as a different user could exploit the potentially higher level of access of the first program for that object. And that apparently is why this event is logged. Unfortunately this event doesn't seem to provide enough information to determine if the Handle was given to a lower security thread or process. Consequently I classify this event as noise.

For an explanation of the fields in this event see events 4688 and 4656.

Do you know more about this event? If so please start a discussion and share!
4690.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4690.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4690</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>12807</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-09-23T00:17:41.755998800Z" /> <EventRecordID>338632</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="4" ThreadID="1100" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-18</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">DC01$</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x3e7</Data> <Data Name="SourceHandleId">0x438</Data> <Data Name="SourceProcessId">0x674</Data> <Data Name="TargetHandleId">0xd9c</Data> <Data Name="TargetProcessId">0x4</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4690.llm_technical_description: This event logs an attempt to duplicate a handle when accessing an object (e.g., a file). Handles in Windows provide unique identifiers for resources, and duplicating them allows one process or thread to inherit another's access rights. While this is a normal system operation intended to transfer access rights between processes, the specific details of which process obtained the handle are not logged here. Without additional context indicating malicious intent (e.g., unauthorized access or impersonation), this event appears to be noise.

4691.summary: Indirect access to an object was requested
4691.description: Indirect access to an object was requested.
4691.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4691.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4691</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>12804</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-09-23T01:03:49.834912100Z" /> <EventRecordID>344382</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="4" ThreadID="2928" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x36509</Data> <Data Name="ObjectType">ALPC Port</Data> <Data Name="ObjectName">\\\\Sessions\\\\2\\\\Windows\\\\DwmApiPort</Data> <Data Name="AccessList">%%4464</Data> <Data Name="AccessMask">0x1</Data> <Data Name="ProcessId">0xe60</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4691.llm_technical_description: An indirect attempt was made to access an object within the system. This could indicate unauthorized access attempts or potential malicious activity aimed at bypassing security measures such as elevated processes or scheduled tasks running at kernel level without proper permissions.

4692.summary: Backup of data protection master key was attempted
4692.description: Microsoft documentation indicates this is a routine event that can be filtered out of events to review. At this time I classify this as a "noise" event.
4692.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4692.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4692</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13314</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-08-25T01:59:14.573672700Z" /> <EventRecordID>176964</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="520" ThreadID="540" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-500</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">ladmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x30c08</Data> <Data Name="MasterKeyId">16cfaea0-dbe3-4d92-9523-d494edb546bc</Data> <Data Name="RecoveryServer" /> <Data Name="RecoveryKeyId">806a0350-aeb1-4c56-91f9-ef16cf759291</Data> <Data Name="FailureReason">0x0</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4692.llm_technical_description: The event indicates a potential unauthorized attempt to back up the data protection master key using DPAPI (Display Name Protection API). This could suggest malicious activity such as an attacker trying to bypass domain restrictions or an accidental misconfiguration by a legitimate user. The event is classified as routine but can be considered noise, yet it carries significant security implications due to its relation to sensitive data protection mechanisms.

4693.summary: Recovery of data protection master key was attempted
4693.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4693.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4693</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13314</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-08-22T06:25:14.589407700Z" /> <EventRecordID>175809</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="520" ThreadID="1340" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x30d7c</Data> <Data Name="MasterKeyId">0445c766-75f0-4de7-82ad-d9d97aad59f6</Data> <Data Name="RecoveryReason">0x5c005c</Data> <Data Name="RecoveryServer">DC01.contoso.local</Data> <Data Name="RecoveryKeyId" /> <Data Name="FailureId">0x380000</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4693.llm_technical_description: An attempt was made to recover a data protection master key, which typically requires administrative privileges. This activity could indicate unauthorized access attempts or potential malware infection if the system is compromised.

4694.summary: Protection of auditable protected data was attempted
4694.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4694.llm_technical_description: The event indicates an attempt to protect auditable data in a process using Dynamic Presentations API (DPAPI). This could be a legitimate user action or potentially indicate unauthorized access. The absence of specific Sigma rules suggests it may not be immediately actionable without additional context.

4695.summary: Unprotection of auditable protected data was attempted
4695.description:
This event has to do with the Data Protection API. 

Per Microsoft: "The Data Protection API (DPAPI) helps to protect data in Windows 2000 and later operating systems. DPAPI is used to help protect private keys, stored credentials (in Windows XP and later), and other confidential information that the operating system or a program wants to keep confidential. "

Apparently a program running under the account documented in Subject: tried to decrypt a blob with the CryptUnprotectData function and failed. Status code 0x8009000b is pretty general. Most often it means
4695.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4695.llm_technical_description: An attempt was made by a program running under an account to unprotect auditable protected data using the Data Protection API (DPAPI). The status code 0x8009000b indicates that decryption failed. This could imply unauthorized access or an exploit of security mechanisms, as DPAPI is used to protect sensitive information.

4696.summary: A primary token was assigned to process
4696.description:
This often happens when a service starts or a scheduled task starts under the authority of a different user. You will see events4624 and 4648 as well as 4776 or 4768 earlier in the log. 

The Assigning process fields identify the process that started the child (new) process. Process ID allows you to link this event to the corresponding event 4688 (process start of the parent process) but there is little need since this event gives you the program name (Process Name) and the user under which the process was running (Subject).

Target Process: information identifies the new child process that was started under the account and logon session in New Token Information. 

You can use the Target Process ID to link back to the earlier4688 for the new child process ID but again there is little need to do this since you have the Target Process Name:right here in this event.
4696.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022

4696.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that a primary token was assigned to a process during its creation, potentially under different user accounts. This could occur when services or scheduled tasks start, often as an attempt to elevate privileges or gain unauthorized access. The presence of this event alongside others (e.g., 4624, 4648, and 4776) suggests potential misconfiguration or malicious intent.

4697.summary: A service was installed in the system
4697.description:
A new service was installed by the userindicated in the subject. Subject often identifies the local system (SYSTEM) for services installed as part of native Windows components and therefore you can't determine who actually initiated the installation.

This is a key change control event as new services are significant extensions of the software running on a server and the roles it performs.
4697.operating_systems: Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4697.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4697</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>12289</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-11-12T01:36:11.991070500Z" /> <EventRecordID>2778</EventRecordID> <Correlation ActivityID="{913FBE70-1CE6-0000-67BF-3F91E61CD101}" /> <Execution ProcessID="736" ThreadID="2800" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>WIN-GG82ULGC9GO.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-18</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">WIN-GG82ULGC9GO$</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x3e7</Data> <Data Name="ServiceName">AppHostSvc</Data> <Data Name="ServiceFileName">%windir%\\\\system32\\\\svchost.exe -k apphost</Data> <Data Name="ServiceType">0x20</Data> <Data Name="ServiceStartType">2</Data> <Data Name="ServiceAccount">localSystem</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4697.llm_technical_description: This event indicates the installation of a new service that may be associated with malicious activity, including potential backdoor tools (Metasploit/SMB), credential dumping tools, and encrypted communication methods (TAP). The presence of these services suggests compromised system security and active threat actors leveraging these capabilities.

4698.description:
The user indicated in Subject: just created a new scheduled task (Start menu\Accessories\System Tools\Task Scheduler) identified by Task Name:.

This is an important change control event. See related events for changes to Scheduled Tasks: 4699, 4700, 4701, 4702.

4698.llm_technical_description: This event indicates the creation of a new scheduled task in Windows, typically used for system automation or management purposes. It serves as an important change control point, with related events (4699-4702) likely tracking any modifications to scheduled tasks. While not inherently malicious, monitoring is recommended to detect potential misuse.

4699.description:
The user indicated in Subject: just deletedthe scheduled task (Start menu\Accessories\System Tools\Task Scheduler) identified by Task Name:.

This is an important change control event. See related events for changes to Scheduled Tasks: 4698, 4700, 4701, and 4702.

4699.llm_technical_description: A scheduled task for System Tools (Task Scheduler) was deleted. This is an important change control event, and related events include other scheduled tasks being altered or deleted. The system may be attempting to remove potentially sensitive data without proper evidence of backup.

4700.description:
The user indicated in Subject: just enabled the scheduled task (Start menu\Accessories\System Tools\Task Scheduler) identified by Task Name.

A task must be enabled in order to run at its scheduled time.

This is an important change control event. See related events for changes to Scheduled Tasks: 4698, 4699, 4601 and 4702.

4700.llm_technical_description: The user enabled a scheduled task through Task Scheduler at their scheduled time, which is an important change control event.

4701.description:
The user indicated in Subject: just disabled the scheduled task (Start menu\Accessories\System Tools\Task Scheduler) identified by Task Name:.

In its disabled the state the task will not run at its scheduled time until re-enabled.

This is an important change control event. See related events for changes to Scheduled Tasks: 4698, 4699, 4700, 4702
4701.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022

4701.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that a scheduled task was disabled by the user. The task is identified in the Task Name field and relates to system tools such as System Restoration or Windows Defender. This could be an attempt by an adversary to stop service processes, potentially leading to data destruction or unauthorized access.

4702.description:
The user indicated in Subject: just updated the scheduled task (Start menu\Accessories\System Tools\Task Scheduler) identified by Task Name:.

This event logs all updates to Scheduled Tasks except for enable and disable operations which have their own events.

This is an important change control event. See related events for changes to Scheduled Tasks: 4698, 4699, 4700 and 4701.
4702.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
