4702.llm_technical_description: This event indicates an update has been made to a scheduled task in the Task Scheduler under Start menu\Accessories\System Tools. Scheduled tasks are typically updated by users, but attackers may exploit changes in these tasks to insert malicious code or cause performance issues.

4703.description: We have not yet observed this event
4703.operating_systems: Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4703.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4703</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13570</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-11-12T20:49:46.365958700Z" /> <EventRecordID>5245</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="4" ThreadID="3632" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>WIN-GG82ULGC9GO.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-18</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">WIN-GG82ULGC9GO$</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x3e7</Data> <Data Name="TargetUserSid">S-1-5-18</Data> <Data Name="TargetUserName">WIN-GG82ULGC9GO$</Data> <Data Name="TargetDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="TargetLogonId">0x3e7</Data> <Data Name="ProcessName">C:\\\\Windows\\\\System32\\\\svchost.exe</Data> <Data Name="ProcessId">0x270</Data> <Data Name="EnabledPrivilegeList">SeAssignPrimaryTokenPrivilege SeIncreaseQuotaPrivilege SeSecurityPrivilege SeTakeOwnershipPrivilege SeLoadDriverPrivilege SeSystemtimePrivilege SeBackupPrivilege SeRestorePrivilege SeShutdownPrivilege SeSystemEnvironmentPrivilege SeUndockPrivilege SeManageVolumePrivilege</Data> <Data Name="DisabledPrivilegeList">-</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4703.EventName: Audit Token Right Adjusted; Audit Authorization Policy Change
4703.llm_technical_description: This event indicates a modification to an authorization policy on Windows systems. The adjustment of a token right suggests a change in system access control mechanisms. While this is not directly indicative of malicious activity, it could signal increased threat activity or potential misconfiguration. The lack of observed events complicates the assessment of its immediate impact.

4704.description:
This event documents a change to user right assignments on this computer including the right anduser or group that received the new right.

Note: "User rights" and "privileges" are synonymous terms used interchangeably in Windows.

Rights, like most other security settings, are defined in group policy objects and applied by the computer. Therefore this event will normally show the Assigned By user as the system itself. To determine who actually made the rights assignment change you must search the domain controllers' security logs for changes to groupPolicyContainer objects (logged by Directory Service auditing). 

Logon ID allows you to link this event to the prior event4624logon event of the user who performed this action. 

Note: This event, 4704, and 4705 do not log changes to logon rights such as "Access this computer from the network" or "Logon as a service". See events 4717 and 4718.
4704.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4704.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4704</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13570</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-10-02T22:08:07.136050600Z" /> <EventRecordID>1049866</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="500" ThreadID="1216" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-18</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">DC01$</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x3e7</Data> <Data Name="TargetSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="PrivilegeList">SeAuditPrivilege SeIncreaseWorkingSetPrivilege</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4704.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that user rights have been modified on the system. The 'User right was assigned' event typically logs changes in user privileges or permissions set by group policies. This could be a legitimate change but might also indicate unauthorized access if not properly monitored.

4705.description:
This event documents a change to user right assignments on this computer including the right anduser or group that lost theright.

Note: "User rights" and "privileges" are synonymous terms used interchangeably in Windows.

Rights, like most other security settings, are defined in group policy objects and applied by the computer. Therefore this event will normally show the Assigned By user as the system itself. To determine who actually made the rights assignment change you must search the domain controllers' security logs for changes to groupPolicyContainer objects (logged by Directory Service auditing). 

Logon ID allows you to link this event to the prior event4624logon event of the user who performed this action. 

Note: This event, 4705, and 4704 do not log changes to logon rights such as "Access this computer from the network" or "Logon as a service". See events 4714 and 4718.

Subject:

The ID and logon session of the user that revoked the right. Unfortunately this is just the local system account - see above.
4705.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4705.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4705</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13570</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-10-02T22:08:07.152488600Z" /> <EventRecordID>1049867</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="500" ThreadID="1216" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-18</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">DC01$</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x3e7</Data> <Data Name="TargetSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="PrivilegeList">SeTimeZonePrivilege</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4705.llm_technical_description: A user right was removed due to a change in policy. This indicates potential unauthorized access or rights revocation, which could lead to Denial of Service if essential permissions were taken away. The system automatically assigns these rights, so manual verification may be needed.

4706.summary: A new trust was created to a domain
4706.description:
This event is logged for all new trust relationships connecting to this domain. While the description says "Trusted" this event applies to both trusted and trusting relationships as documented by Trust Information:.

Subject:

The ID and logon session of the user that excercised created the trust.
4706.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4706.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4706</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13569</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-10-01T20:41:13.189445500Z" /> <EventRecordID>1049759</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="500" ThreadID="4900" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="DomainName">corp.contoso.local</Data> <Data Name="DomainSid">S-1-5-21-2226861337-2836268956-2433141405</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x3e99d6</Data> <Data Name="TdoType">2</Data> <Data Name="TdoDirection">3</Data> <Data Name="TdoAttributes">32</Data> <Data Name="SidFilteringEnabled">%%1796</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4706.llm_technical_description: The creation of a new trust in a domain could indicate unauthorized access attempts if not properly secured. This event (EventID:4706) logs when such trusts are established, potentially from an unauthorized source as legitimate extensions can be false positives.

4707.summary: A trust to a domain was removed
4707.description:
This event is logged for all deleted trust relationships that connected to this domain. While the description says "Trusted" this event applies to both trusted and trusting relationships as documented by Trust Information:.

Subject:

The ID and logon session of the user that excerciseddeleted the trust.
4707.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4707.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4707</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13569</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-10-01T20:41:13.080444700Z" /> <EventRecordID>1049754</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="500" ThreadID="580" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="DomainName">FABRIKAM</Data> <Data Name="DomainSid">S-1-5-21-2226861337-2836268956-2433141405</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x3e99d6</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4707.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a trust relationship to or from a domain was removed. This could be due to policy changes such as moving authentication schemes, enhancing security by reducing unnecessary trusts, or misconfiguration. The ID refers to the user who executed this action.

4709.description: This event is not produced in the default configuration (using Windows Firewall)however event 5478 is produced..
4709.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4709.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that the IPsec service was started as part of a policy change. This could be due to a legitimate configuration update or potentially malicious activity attempting to access internal networks. The similarity to another event (5478) suggests a recurring pattern, but without specific context on what changed, it's challenging to determine if this is unauthorized.

4710.description: In the default configuration this event is not produced when the IPsec Policy agent service is disabled or fails to start.
4710.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4710.llm_technical_description: The IPsec Services was disabled event indicates that the policy change occurred to disable network security services. This could be a potential attempt to disrupt secure communications or gain unauthorized access by disabling critical network traffic controls.

4711.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4711.llm_technical_description: The event indicates a change in policy related to the PAStore Engine, specifically under the category of Filtering Platform Policy Change. This could involve modifications to file access permissions or system protection settings, potentially affecting how data is stored and accessed on the system.

4712.summary: IPsec Services encountered a potentially serious failure
4712.description: In theory this reports when the service cannot perform its required tasks, such as properly processing filters, or cannot protect traffic sent or received by one or more of the network adapters attached to the computer.
4712.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4712.llm_technical_description: The event indicates a potential security vulnerability due to an IPsec service failure caused by a policy change. This could allow unauthorized access or disrupted traffic, posing a high risk of exploitation.

4713.description:
Windows logs 4713 when it detects a change to the the domain's Kerberos policy. Kerberos policy is defined in GPOs linked to the root of the domain under Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Account Policy\Kerberos Policy. 

Unfortunately theSubject fields don't identify who actually changed the policy because Kerberos policy isn't directly configured by administrators. Instead it is edited in a group policy object which then gets applied to the computer. Therefore this event always shows the local computer as the one who changed the policy since the computer is the security principal under which gpupdate runs. 

Subject:

The ID and logon session of the user that changed the policy - always the local system - see note above.
4713.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4713.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4713</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13569</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-10-01T23:15:50.811774300Z" /> <EventRecordID>1049772</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="500" ThreadID="4116" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-18</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">DC01$</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x3e7</Data> <Data Name="KerberosPolicyChange">KerMaxT: 0x10c388d000 (0x861c46800); KerMaxR: 0x19254d38000 (0xc92a69c000);</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4713.llm_technical_description: The Windows Event ID 4713 indicates that the Kerberos policy for the domain has been changed, likely through Group Policy Objects (GPOs). Kerberos policies are managed at the domain level by trusted administrators using tools like gpedit.msc. While this event itself is not malicious, it can be a vector for attackers to attempt privilege escalation or other malicious activities if misconfigured.

4714.summary: Encrypted data recovery policy was changed
4714.description:
This computer's Security Settings\Public Key Policies\Encrypting File System data recovery agent policy was modified - either via Local Security Policy or Group Policy in Active Directory.

Unfortunately theSubject fields don't identify who actually changed the policy because this policy isn't directly configured by administrators. Instead it is edited in a group policy object which then gets applied to the computer. Therefore this event always shows the local computer as the one who changed the policy since the computer is the security principal under which gpupdate runs. Subject:

The ID and logon session of the user that changed the policy - always the local system - see note above.
4714.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4714.llm_technical_description: An encrypted data recovery policy was changed on this computer. This policy, typically modified via Group Policy Objects (GPOs) or Local Security Policies, affects how the system handles file encryption for recovery purposes. The event logs this change but does not specify who made it, as GPO changes are often applied by the affected machine's owner.

4715.summary: The audit policy (SACL) on an object was changed
4715.description: The description is poorly worded but this event is logged whenever you set the security descriptor used to delegate access to the audit policy. You can delegate authority to the system's audit policy using "auditpol /sd:".
4715.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4715.llm_technical_description: The audit policy (SACL) was changed. This event is logged whenever a service account is created or modified for the purpose of delegating access to an audit policy, which can grant access rights to sensitive directories or resources.

4716.description: This event is logged for modifications to trust relationships connecting to this domain. While the description says "Trusted" this event applies to both trusted and trusting relationships as documented by Trust Information.
4716.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4716.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4716</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13569</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-10-01T22:55:54.560735500Z" /> <EventRecordID>1049763</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="500" ThreadID="4920" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x138eb0</Data> <Data Name="DomainName">-</Data> <Data Name="DomainSid">S-1-5-21-2226861337-2836268956-2433141405</Data> <Data Name="TdoType">2</Data> <Data Name="TdoDirection">3</Data> <Data Name="TdoAttributes">32</Data> <Data Name="SidFilteringEnabled">-</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4716.llm_technical_description: This event logs modifications to trust relationships (both trusted and trusting) associated with the domain. Such changes can occur due to legitimate actions like setting up remote access, updating Group Policy Objects (GPOs), or adjusting user permissions. An attacker might exploit these changes if they gain unauthorized control over a Trusted Domain Controller (TDC) to elevate privileges.

4717.summary: System security access was granted to an account
4717.description:
This event documents the grant of logon rights such as "Access this computer from the network" or "Logon as a service". 

Rights, like most other security settings, are defined in group policy objects and applied by the computer. Therefore this event will normally show the Assigned By user as the system itself. To determine who actually made the rights assignment change you must search the domain controllers' security logs for changes to groupPolicyContainer objects (logged by Directory Service auditing). Logon ID allows you to link this event to the prior event 4624 logon event of the user who performed this action. 


This event, 4717,documents the system name for each logon right as opposed to the more familiar description. Click here for a cross reference. 

Note: This event and4718 log changes to strictly logon rights such as "Access this computer from the network" or "Logon as a service" - not to other rights such as "Change the system time" or "Take ownership of files and other objects". See events 4704 and 4705.
4717.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4717.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4717</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13569</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-10-02T00:02:33.213572000Z" /> <EventRecordID>1049777</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="500" ThreadID="2064" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-18</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">DC01$</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x3e7</Data> <Data Name="TargetSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-2104</Data> <Data Name="AccessGranted">SeInteractiveLogonRight</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4717.llm_technical_description: This event logs a change to system-level logon rights such as 'Access this computer from the network' or 'Logon as a service'. The grant of these rights typically occurs when group policy objects are modified, and the system account is often used as the Assigned By user. This can indicate legitimate configuration changes or potential unauthorized access attempts.

4718.summary: System security access was removed from an account
4718.description:
This event documents the revokation of logon rights such as "Access this computer from the network" or "Logon as a service". 

Rights, like most other security settings, are defined in group policy objects and applied by the computer. Therefore this event will normally show the Assigned By user as the system itself. To determine who actually made the rights assignment change you must search the domain controllers' security logs for changes to groupPolicyContainer objects (logged by Directory Service auditing). Logon ID allows you to link this event to the prior event 4624 logon event of the user who performed this action. 

This event, 4718documents the system name for each logon right as opposed to the more familiar description. Click here for a cross reference. 

Note: This event and 4717 log changes to strictly logon rights such as "Access this computer from the network" or "Logon as a service" - not to other rights such as "Change the system time" or "Take ownership of files and other objects". See events 4704 and 4705.
4718.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4718.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4718</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13569</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-10-01T23:35:46.375134200Z" /> <EventRecordID>1049773</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="500" ThreadID="5028" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-18</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">DC01$</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x3e7</Data> <Data Name="TargetSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-2104</Data> <Data Name="AccessRemoved">SeInteractiveLogonRight</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4718.llm_technical_description: The system has removed logon rights from an account under a policy change. This typically affects user access for services like remote connection or service logons, potentially indicating unauthorized changes affecting legitimate users.

4719.description: This computer'ssystem level audit policywas modified - either via Local Security Policy, Group Policy in Active Directory or the audipol command.
4719.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4719.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4719</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13568</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-09-30T19:57:09.668217100Z" /> <EventRecordID>1049418</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="516" ThreadID="4668" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-18</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">DC01$</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x3e7</Data> <Data Name="CategoryId">%%8274</Data> <Data Name="SubcategoryId">%%12807</Data> <Data Name="SubcategoryGuid">{0CCE9223-69AE-11D9-BED3-505054503030}</Data> <Data Name="AuditPolicyChanges">%%8448, %%8450</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4719.llm_technical_description: The system-level audit policy was modified on this computer, which could be due to changes in Local Security Policy, Active Directory Group Policy, or direct edits. This event may indicate potential security concerns such as unauthorized access attempts if auditing is disabled.

4720.description:
The user identified by Subject: created the user identified by New Account:. 

Attributes show some of the properties that were set at the time the account was created. Notice account is initially disabled.

This event is logged both for local SAM accounts and domain accounts.

You will see a series of other User Account Management events after this event as the remaining properties are punched down, password set and account finally enabled.
4720.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4720.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4720</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13824</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-08-20T16:22:02.759912000Z" /> <EventRecordID>175408</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="520" ThreadID="1508" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="TargetUserName">ksmith</Data> <Data Name="TargetDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="TargetSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-6609</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x30dc2</Data> <Data Name="PrivilegeList">-</Data> <Data Name="SamAccountName">ksmith</Data> <Data Name="DisplayName">Ken Smith</Data> <Data Name="UserPrincipalName">ksmith@contoso.local</Data> <Data Name="HomeDirectory">-</Data> <Data Name="HomePath">-</Data> <Data Name="ScriptPath">-</Data> <Data Name="ProfilePath">-</Data> <Data Name="UserWorkstations">-</Data> <Data Name="PasswordLastSet">%%1794</Data> <Data Name="AccountExpires">%%1794</Data> <Data Name="PrimaryGroupId">513</Data> <Data Name="AllowedToDelegateTo">-</Data> <Data Name="OldUacValue">0x0</Data> <Data Name="NewUacValue">0x15</Data> <Data Name="UserAccountControl">%%2080 %%2082 %%2084</Data> <Data Name="UserParameters">-</Data> <Data Name="SidHistory">-</Data> <Data Name="LogonHours">%%1793</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4720.llm_technical_description: A user account was created with initial disablement and subsequent configuration. This event may indicate unauthorized lateral movement or bypass of security restrictions.

4722.description:
The user identified by Subject: enabed the user identified by Target Account:. 

This event is logged both for local SAM accounts and domain accounts.

This event is always logged after event 4720 - user account creation.

You will also see event ID 4738 informing you of the same information.
4722.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4722.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4722</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13824</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-08-21T23:55:11.038308600Z" /> <EventRecordID>175716</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="520" ThreadID="1112" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="TargetUserName">Auditor</Data> <Data Name="TargetDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="TargetSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-2104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x30d5f</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4722.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a user account was enabled as part of the account management process. This action typically follows user account creation (event 4720) and precedes further changes such as enabling domain accounts (event 4738). The enablement could be for system-wide or local administration, potentially indicating legitimate setup steps or unauthorized access attempts.

4723.summary: An attempt was made to change an account's password
4723.description:
The user attempted to change his/her own password. Subject and Target should always match. Don't confuse this event with 4724.

This event is logged as a failure ifhis new password fails to meet the password policy.

If the user fails to correctly enter his old password this event is not logged. Instead, for domain accounts, a 4771 is logged with kadmin/changepw as the service name.

This event is logged both for local SAM accounts and domain accounts.

You will also see event ID 4738 informing you of the same information.
4723.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4723.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4723</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13824</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-08-22T01:32:51.494558000Z" /> <EventRecordID>175722</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="520" ThreadID="1112" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="TargetUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="TargetDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="TargetSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x1a9b76</Data> <Data Name="PrivilegeList">-</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4723.llm_technical_description: This Windows event (ID 4723) logs an attempt to change a user's password. It occurs when the user enters an incorrect old password, resulting in the failure of the change unless it meets the password policy requirements. The event is logged for both local SAM accounts and domain accounts, with a secondary event (4738) logging similar information.

4724.summary: An attempt was made to reset an accounts password
4724.description:
The Subject attempted to reset the password of the Target:

Don't confuse this event with 4723.

This event is logged as a failure ifthe new password fails to meet the password policy.

This event is logged both for local SAM accounts and domain accounts.

You will also see one or more event ID 4738s informing you of the same information.
4724.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4724.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4724</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13824</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-08-22T01:58:21.725864900Z" /> <EventRecordID>175740</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="520" ThreadID="548" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="TargetUserName">User1</Data> <Data Name="TargetDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="TargetSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1107</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x30d5f</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4724.llm_technical_description: An attempt was made to reset an account's password. This event is logged when the new password fails to meet the system's policy, potentially indicating unauthorized changes to password policies or legitimate attempts. The event applies to both local SAM accounts and domain accounts.

4725.description:
The user identified by Subject: disabled the user identified by Target Account:. 

This event is logged both for local SAM accounts and domain accounts.

You will also see event ID4738informing you of the same information.

4727.summary: A security-enabled global group was created
4727.description:
The user in Subject: just created a Security Global group identified in New Group.

In Active Directory Users and Computers"Security Enabled" groupsare simply referred to as Security groups. AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

Global means the group can be granted access in any trusting domain but may only have members from its own domain.

This event is only logged on domain controllers.
4727.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4727.llm_technical_description: The creation of a security-enabled global group in Active Directory (AD) is logged. This action typically occurs during normal user administration tasks and does not inherently pose a security risk unless there are specific configurations or permissions associated with the group that could be misused.

4728.summary: A member was added to a security-enabled global group

The user in Subject: added the user/group/computer in Member: to the Security Global group in Group:.

Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

Global means the group can be granted access in any trusting domain but may only have members from its own domain. 

This event is only logged on domain controllers.

This action typically grants access rights within an organization and could be a legitimate task or potentially malicious activity depending on context.

Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

Global means the group can be granted access in any trusting domain but may only have members from its own domain.

4731.summary: A security-enabled local group was created
4731.description:
The user in Subject: created a Security Local group identified in New Group.

This event is logged on domain controllers for Active Directory domain local groups and member computer for local SAM groups. You can determine if the group is a domain or SAM group by comparing Group Domain: to the Computer: name. If they match you havea SAM group, if they differ you have a domain group.

Active Directory

In Active Directory Users and Computers "Security Enabled" groups are simply referred to as Security groups. AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

A domain local group means the group can only be granted access to objects within its domain but can have members from any trusted domain.

Local SAM

All groups are security groups in the computer's SAM. Local SAM groups can be granted access to objects on the local computer onlybut may have members from the local SAM and any trusted domain.

4744.summary: A security-disabled local group was created
4744.description:
The user in Subject: created a Local Distribution group identified in New Group.

This event is only logged on domain controllers.

In Active Directory Users and Computers "Security Disabled" groups are referred to as Distribution groups. AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

A domain local group can have members from any trusted domain.
4744.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4744.llm_technical_description: A security-disabled local distribution group was created in Active Directory. This is a standard administrative action for setting up read-only distribution lists typically used by IT administrators for internal purposes.

Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

A domain local group can have members from any trusted domain.

Distribution groups are typically used for email lists and cannot be assigned permissions due to being security disabled. This could potentially indicate legitimate activity, such as updating contacts within the group, or malicious activity, such as unauthorized access to sensitive data or resources after the change.

4754.summary: A security-enabled universal group was created
4754.description:
The user in Subject: created a Universal Security group identified in New Group.

In Active Directory Users and Computers"Security Enabled" groups are simply referred to as Security groups. AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

Universal means the group can be granted access in any trusting domain and may have members from any trusted domain.

This event is only logged on domain controllers.
4754.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4754.llm_technical_description: A Security-Enabled Universal Group was created in Active Directory. This type of group grants elevated access to any trusting domain, which can lead to potential security breaches if misused by an attacker. The creation of such a group without proper validation or monitoring could indicate an attempt to elevate privileges, enabling unauthorized access across multiple domains.

4757.llm_technical_description: The removal of a user from a Security group in Active Directory is a standard administrative action typically performed to adjust access permissions. This event does not inherently pose a security risk as it reflects normal user access control management.

4758.summary: A security-enabled universal group was deleted
4758.description:
The user in Subject:deleted theUniversal Security group identified in Deleted Group.

In Active Directory Users and Computers"Security Enabled" groups are simply referred to as Security groups. AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

Universal means the group can be granted access in any trusting domain and may have members from any trusted domain.

This event is only logged on domain controllers.
4758.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4758.llm_technical_description: A user attempted to delete a Security-Enabled Universal Group (SGUG), which can have legitimate purposes such as resource sharing or permissions management. Deleting such groups without proper context might expose sensitive capabilities, potentially leading to unintended access or resource loss.

4759.summary: A security-disabled universal group was created
4759.description:
The user in Subject: created a Universal Distribution group identified in New Group.

This event is only logged on domain controllers.

In Active Directory Users and Computers "Security Disabled" groups are referred to as Distribution groups. AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

Universalgroup may have members from any trusted domain.
4759.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4759.llm_technical_description: A user created a Universal Distribution Group (security disabled) in Active Directory. This group is typically used for Exchange Server purposes, such as distribution lists or email forwarding without assignment permissions.

4760.summary: A security-disabled universal group was changed
4760.description:
The user in Subject: changed the Universal Distribution group identified in Group:.

This event is only logged on domain controllers.

In Active Directory Users and Computers "Security Disabled" groups are referred to as Distribution groups. AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

Universal group may have members from any trusted domain.
4760.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4760.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a user has modified a Universal Distribution Group (security-disabled) in Active Directory. These groups are typically used for Exchange addresses and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. The change is logged on domain controllers, suggesting potential privileged access.

4761.summary: A member was added to a security-disabled universal group
4761.description:
The user in Subject: added the user/group/computer in Member: to the Universal Distribution group in Group:.

This event is only logged on domain controllers.

In Active Directory Users and Computers "Security Disabled" groups are referred to as Distribution groups. AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists.

Universal group may have members from any trusted domain.
4761.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4761.llm_technical_description: A member was added to a Universal Group. This could indicate unauthorized access attempts or legitimate group policy creation. The event logs on domain controllers, suggesting it's a system-level operation.

4762.summary: A member was removed from a security-disabled universal group
4762.description:
The user in Subject: removed the user/group/computer in Member:from the Universal Distribution group in Group:.

This event is only logged on domain controllers.

In Active Directory Users and Computers "Security Disabled" groups are referred to as Distribution groups. AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists.

Universal group may have members from any trusted domain.
4762.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4762.llm_technical_description: The event involves the removal of a member from a Security Disabled Universal Distribution Group in Active Directory. This action is legitimate as these groups are primarily used for distribution lists and cannot be assigned permissions or rights, making such changes less impactful on user access.

4763.summary: A security-disabled universal group was deleted
4763.description:
The user in Subject:deleted theUniversal Distribution group identified in Deleted Group.

This event is only logged on domain controllers.

In Active Directory Users and Computers "Security Disabled" groups are referred to as Distribution groups. AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists.

Universal groups may have members from any trusted domain.
4763.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4763.llm_technical_description: An event occurred where a security-disabled universal group was deleted. Security-disabled groups are typically locked after deletion to prevent accidental or unintended distribution. This event is logged on domain controllers and may indicate legitimate clean-up activity or potentially malicious intent if there's context suggesting unauthorized access.

4764.description:
A group's type or scope was changed by Subject:.

AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

No matter what type the group was before or after the change this event is always logged as subcategory "Security Group Management".

Scope: 
AD has 3 scopes of groups: Local, Global, Universal. See knowledge base article 326265. 

Subject:

The ID and logon session of the user that changed the policy - always the local system - see note above.
4764.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022

4764.llm_technical_description: The event involves a change in the type or scope of a Security or Distribution group managed by the local user. AD groups can be manipulated to alter permissions or enable/disable features, which may indicate unauthorized policy changes aimed at gaining access rights or hindering legitimate users.

4765.summary: SID History was added to an account
4765.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4765.llm_technical_description: This Windows EventLog entry indicates that a system information directory entry (SIDE) was updated for an account. The event ID 4765 is categorized under Account Management with the subcategory User Account Management but lacks specific details on what exactly was added or modified. Without further context, it's challenging to determine if this activity is malicious or part of normal user operations.

4766.summary: An attempt to add SID History to an account failed
4766.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4766.llm_technical_description: The Windows Event with ID 4766 indicates an attempt to add Side Information Directory (SID) History to an account failed. This event is common in legitimate user actions when managing accounts, especially in environments involving Active Directory setups where SIDs are used for user management and permissions. The failure of this action could indicate misconfiguration or potential unauthorized access attempts by an attacker.

4767.description:
The user identified by Subject: unlocked the user identified by Target Account:. 

Note: this event is logged whenever you check the Unlock Account check box on the user's account tab - even if the account is notcurrently locked as a result of failed logon attempts. See event ID 4740.

This event is logged both for local SAM accounts and domain accounts.
4767.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4767.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4767</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13824</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-08-21T22:31:01.871931700Z" /> <EventRecordID>175705</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="520" ThreadID="1520" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="TargetUserName">Auditor</Data> <Data Name="TargetDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="TargetSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-2104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x30d5f</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4767.llm_technical_description: The event logs a user account unlock action when the 'Unlock Account' checkbox is checked. This occurs even if there are no failed logons or lockouts, indicating normal user activity.

4768.summary: A Kerberos authentication ticket (TGT) was requested
4768.description:
This event is logged on domain controllers only and both success and failure instances of this event are logged. 

At the beginning of the day when a user sits down at his or her workstation and enters his domain username and password, the workstation contacts a local DC and requests a TGT. If the username and password are correct and the user account passes status and restriction checks, the DC grants the TGT and logs event ID4768 (authentication ticket granted). 

If the ticket request fails Windows will either log this event, 4768 or 4771 with failure as the type.

The User field for this event (and all other events in the Audit account logon event category) doesn't help you determine who the user was; the field always reads N/A. Rather look at theAccount Information:fields, which identify the user who logged on and the user account's DNS suffix. The User ID field provides theSID of the account.

Windows logs other instances of event ID 4768 when a computer in the domain needs to authenticate to the DC typically when a workstation boots up or a server restarts. In these instances, you'll find a computer name in the User Name and fields. Computer generated kerberos events are always identifiable by the $ after the computer account's name. 

Microsoft's Comments: 

This event records that a Kerberos TGT was granted, actual access will not occur until a service ticket is granted, which is audited by Event 673. If the PATYPE is PKINIT, the logon was a smart card logon.
4768.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4768.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4768</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>14339</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-08-07T18:13:46.074535600Z" /> <EventRecordID>166747</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="520" ThreadID="1496" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="TargetUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="TargetDomainName">CONTOSO.LOCAL</Data> <Data Name="TargetSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="ServiceName">krbtgt</Data> <Data Name="ServiceSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-502</Data> <Data Name="TicketOptions">0x40810010</Data> <Data Name="Status">0x0</Data> <Data Name="TicketEncryptionType">0x12</Data> <Data Name="PreAuthType">15</Data> <Data Name="IpAddress">::ffff:10.0.0.12</Data> <Data Name="IpPort">49273</Data> <Data Name="CertIssuerName">contoso-DC01-CA-1</Data> <Data Name="CertSerialNumber">1D0000000D292FBE3C6CDDAFA200020000000D</Data> <Data Name="CertThumbprint">564DFAEE99C71D62ABC553E695BD8DBC46669413</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4768.llm_technical_description: This event (ID 4768) logs a Kerberos Ticket Granting Ticket (TGT) request during user authentication on domain controllers. It is typically logged when users successfully authenticate, either upon boot or server restart. If the TGT request fails, it may also be logged with the failure type. The User field is always N/A, so the Account Information field must be examined to determine the user and account details. The presence of unusual fields (e.g., $ in computer names) could indicate malicious activity.

4769.summary: A Kerberos service ticket was requested
4769.description:
Windows uses this event ID for both successful and failed service ticket requests. If it is a failure event see Failure Code: below.

Whereas event ID 4768 lets you track initial logons through the granting of TGTs, this lets you monitor the granting of service tickets. Service tickets are obtained whenever a user or computer accesses a server on the network. For example, when a user maps a drive to a file server, the resulting service ticket request generates event ID4769 on the DC.
4769.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4769.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4769</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>14337</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-08-07T18:13:46.043256100Z" /> <EventRecordID>166746</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="520" ThreadID="1496" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="TargetUserName">dadmin@CONTOSO.LOCAL</Data> <Data Name="TargetDomainName">CONTOSO.LOCAL</Data> <Data Name="ServiceName">WIN2008R2$</Data> <Data Name="ServiceSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-2102</Data> <Data Name="TicketOptions">0x40810000</Data> <Data Name="TicketEncryptionType">0x12</Data> <Data Name="IpAddress">::ffff:10.0.0.12</Data> <Data Name="IpPort">49272</Data> <Data Name="Status">0x0</Data> <Data Name="LogonGuid">{F85C455E-C66E-205C-6B39-F6C60A7FE453}</Data> <Data Name="TransmittedServices">-</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4769.llm_technical_description: This event logs instances where users or computers attempt to access servers via service tickets, either successfully or with errors. The presence of RC4 encryption suggests potential unauthorized access attempts, as well as failed Kerberos ticket requests which could indicate manipulation by attackers.

4770.summary: A Kerberos service ticket was renewed
4770.description: Kerberos limits how long a ticket is valid. If a ticket expires when the user is still logged on, Windows automatically contacts thedomain controllerto renew the ticket which triggers this event.
4770.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4770.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4770</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>14337</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-08-07T03:26:23.466552900Z" /> <EventRecordID>166481</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="520" ThreadID="1084" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="TargetUserName">WIN2008R2$@CONTOSO.LOCAL</Data> <Data Name="TargetDomainName">CONTOSO.LOCAL</Data> <Data Name="ServiceName">krbtgt</Data> <Data Name="ServiceSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-502</Data> <Data Name="TicketOptions">0x2</Data> <Data Name="TicketEncryptionType">0x12</Data> <Data Name="IpAddress">::ffff:10.0.0.12</Data> <Data Name="IpPort">49964</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4770.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that a Kerberos service ticket was renewed as part of the user logon process. The ticket is automatically renewed by Windows when it expires during user login, triggering this event. This is a normal system activity managed by the Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) and should be monitored for anomalies such as repeated occurrences or unusual behavior that could indicate misconfiguration or abuse.

4771.description:
This event is logged on domain controllers only and only failure instances of this event are logged. 

At the beginning of the day when a user sits down at his or her workstation and enters his domain username and password, the workstation contacts a local DC and requests a TGT. If the username and password are correct and the user account passes status and restriction checks, the DC grants the TGT and logs event ID 4768 (authentication ticket granted). 

If the ticket request fails Windows will either log this event, failure 4771, or 4768 if the problem arose during "pre-authentication". In Windows Kerberos, password verification takes place during pre-authentication.

The User field for this event (and all other events in the Audit account logon event category) doesn't help you determine who the user was; the field always reads N/A. Rather look at theAccount Information:fields, which identify the user who logged on and the user account's DNS suffix. The User ID field provides theSID of the account.

Windows logs other instances of event ID 4768 when a computer in the domain needs to authenticate to the DC typically when a workstation boots up or a server restarts. In these instances, you'll find a computer name in the User Name and fields. Computer generated kerberos events are always identifiable by the $ after the computer account's name.
4771.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4771.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4771</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>14339</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8010000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-08-07T18:10:21.495462300Z" /> <EventRecordID>166708</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="520" ThreadID="1084" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="TargetUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="TargetSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="ServiceName">krbtgt/CONTOSO.LOCAL</Data> <Data Name="TicketOptions">0x40810010</Data> <Data Name="Status">0x10</Data> <Data Name="PreAuthType">15</Data> <Data Name="IpAddress">::ffff:10.0.0.12</Data> <Data Name="IpPort">49254</Data> <Data Name="CertIssuerName" /> <Data Name="CertSerialNumber" /> <Data Name="CertThumbprint" /> </EventData> </Event>
4771.llm_technical_description: This event (ID 4771) indicates a Kerberos pre-authentication failure during user login attempts on domain controllers. A successful login request is logged as event ID 4768, while authentication ticket grant failures are logged here. This could signify unauthorized access attempts or configuration issues in the Windows Domain environment.

4772.summary: A Kerberos authentication ticket request failed
4772.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4772.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that there was an attempt to authenticate using the Kerberos ticket system, which failed. This could imply unauthorized access or misconfiguration, potentially indicating malicious intent.

4773.summary: A Kerberos service ticket request failed
4773.description: Windows does not log this event. Instead it logs event ID 4769 with keyword Failure Audit.
4773.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4773.llm_technical_description: The Kerberos service ticket request failed (Event ID: 4773). This event is related to Account Logon processes and specifically involves the creation or handling of Kerberos authentication tickets. The failure could indicate issues such as misconfigured Kerberos services, unauthorized attempts to log in using unauthenticated Windows accounts, or potential exploitation of unauthenticated Windows account access.

4774.summary: An account was mapped for logon
4774.description: I have not actually seen this event logged by Windows but suspect that if it is logged at all it would be in conjunction with IIS's certificate mapping capability where users are authenticated via a client certificate which is then mapped to a Windows user account according to mapping rules defined in IIS.
4774.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4774.llm_technical_description: This Windows event indicates that an account was mapped for logon, potentially indicating an attempt at unauthorized access or misconfiguration within the system's user authentication processes. The event description suggests a possible association with IIS (Internet Information Services), where client certificates are used to map to Windows accounts. Such events can be indicative of malicious activities like certificate injection attacks or brute-force attempts if they occur frequently.

4775.summary: An account could not be mapped for logon
4775.description:
I have not actually seen this event logged by Windows but suspect that it if it is logged at all it would be in conjunction with IIS's certificate mapping capability where users are authenticated via a client certificate which is then mapped to a Windows user account according to mapping rules defined in IIS.

I haven't been able to produce this event. Have you? If so, please start a discussion (see above) and post a sample along with any comments you may have! Don't forget to sanitize any private information
4775.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4775.llm_technical_description: The event indicates an account could not be mapped during a logon process. This may occur when using IIS for certificate-based authentication where user credentials are mapped to Windows accounts according to defined rules in IIS. Such failures can indicate issues like misconfigured IIS settings or unauthorized access attempts.

4776.summary: The domain controller attempted to validate the credentials for an account
4776.description:
Despite what this event says, the computer is not necessarily a domain controller; member servers and workstations also log this event for logon attempts with local SAM accounts.

Whena domain controllersuccessfully authenticates a user via NTLM (instead of Kerberos), the DC logs this event. This specifies which user account who logged on (Account Name) as well as the client computer's name from which the user initiated the logon in the Workstation field.
4776.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4776.llm_technical_description: The domain controller attempted to validate credentials for an account. While typically associated with NTLM authentication on domain controllers, this event also occurs on other machines (member servers and workstations) when users successfully log in using their local SAM accounts.

4777.summary: The domain controller failed to validate the credentials for an account
4777.description: This event does not seem to exist. I have never observed it. Furthermore, 4776 is logged for both success and failure.
4777.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4777.llm_technical_description: The domain controller failed to validate credentials for an account, which could indicate a potential security breach or unauthorized access attempt by an external entity. The fact that event 4776 has been logged with both success and failure suggests it may be a pattern of attempted credential validation attempts, possibly indicating an attacker attempting to gain access through compromised credentials.

4778.summary: A session was reconnected to a Window Station
4778.description:
Windows logs this event when a user reconnects to a disconnected terminal server (aka Remote Desktop) session as opposed to a fresh logon which is reflected by event 4624. 

This event is also logged when a user returns to an existing logon session via Fast User Switching.

You can distinguish between instances of this event associated with Fast User Switching and Remote Desktop by Client Name: and Client Address: which in the case of Remote Desktop will normally be different than the local computer. The session name also indicates Remote Desktop with "RDP" as shown in the example.

With console logons and Fast User Switching the session name will be "Console" and Client Name and Address will be "unknown".
4778.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4778.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4778</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>12551</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-09-10T23:05:29.743867200Z" /> <EventRecordID>237651</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="504" ThreadID="2212" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="AccountName">ladmin</Data> <Data Name="AccountDomain">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="LogonID">0x1e01f6</Data> <Data Name="SessionName">RDP-Tcp\\#6</Data> <Data Name="ClientName">WIN81</Data> <Data Name="ClientAddress">10.0.0.100</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4778.llm_technical_description: This event occurs when a user reconnects to an existing terminal server (RDP) session or returns to a logon session via Fast User Switching. It is logged differently from fresh logons, which are identified by the Windows event 4624. This event can also be indicative of legitimate activities such as accessing remote resources or switching sessions without unauthorized access.

4779.summary: A session was disconnected from a Window Station
4779.description:
Windows logs this event when a user disconnects from a terminal server (aka remote desktop) session as opposed to an full logoff which triggers event 4647 or 4634.

This event is also logged when a user returns to an existing logon session via Fast User Switching.

You can distinguish between instances of this event associated with Fast User Switching and Remote Desktop by Client Name: and Client Address: which in the case of Remote Desktop will normally be different than the local computer. The session name also indicates Remote Desktop with "RDP" as shown in the example.

With console logons and Fast User Switching the session name will be "Console" and Client Name: and Client Address: will be "unknown".
4779.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4779.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4779</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>12551</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-09-10T23:04:41.044489800Z" /> <EventRecordID>237646</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="504" ThreadID="524" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="AccountName">ladmin</Data> <Data Name="AccountDomain">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="LogonID">0x1e01f6</Data> <Data Name="SessionName">RDP-Tcp\\#3</Data> <Data Name="ClientName">WIN81</Data> <Data Name="ClientAddress">10.0.0.100</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4779.llm_technical_description: This event occurs when a user disconnects from a terminal server (RDP) session or returns to an existing logon session via Fast User Switching. It logs sessions disconnected without full logoff and distinguishes between RDP and console logons.

4780.summary: The ACL was set on accounts which are members of administrators groups
4780.description:
This event, 4780, is logged whenever Windows modifies the ACL of a member of Domain Admins or Administrators to match the standard ACL in theAdminSDHolder object. AdminSDHolderdefines a stricter ACL to protect members of admin groups from being modified and taken over by other privileged users like Account Operators. 

Windows logs this event only for accounts where it actually has to change the ACL because of it being different from AdminSDHolder. Typically you will only see it once, sometime after adding an account to Domain Admins or Administrators.

You will also see event ID 4738 informing you of the same information.
4780.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4780.llm_technical_description: This event logs when Windows modifies an account's ACL to match the AdminSDHolder object, typically after adding a user to Domain Admins or Administrators. It ensures sensitive permissions are not accidentally altered.

4781.summary: The name of an account was changed
4781.description:
The user identified by Subject: changed either the normal logon name or the pre-Win2k logonnameof the user identified by Target Account:. Event 4738 actually provides better information on this change.

This event is logged both for local SAM accounts and domain accounts.

You will also see event ID 4738 informing you of the same information.
4781.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4781.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4781</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13824</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-08-22T02:41:09.737420900Z" /> <EventRecordID>175754</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="520" ThreadID="1112" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="OldTargetUserName">Admin</Data> <Data Name="NewTargetUserName">MainAdmin</Data> <Data Name="TargetDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="TargetSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-6117</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x30d5f</Data> <Data Name="PrivilegeList">-</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4781.llm_technical_description: The account name change event indicates that a user has modified their login credentials either through the normal logon name or pre-Win2k domain local account name. This could be a legitimate action, such as resetting a password after an incident, but may also indicate unauthorized changes if performed without proper verification.

4782.summary: The password hash an account was accessed
4782.description: This typically happens when something like the Active Directory Migration Tool (ADMT) is moving password data.
4782.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4782.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4782</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13829</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-08-18T21:23:46.435367800Z" /> <EventRecordID>174829</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="512" ThreadID="1232" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="TargetUserName">Andrei</Data> <Data Name="TargetDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-18</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">DC01$</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x3e7</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4782.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that an attacker has accessed the password hash of an account. This typically occurs during processes like Active Directory Migration Tool (ADMT) usage, which is often performed for legitimate purposes such as moving user credentials. Accessing a password hash can imply unauthorized access or accidental exposure, potentially leading to further security breaches.

4783.summary: A basic application group was created
4783.description:
The user in Subject: created an application group identified in Group:.

Application groups are part of Windows's role based access control for applications and are maintained in the Authorization Manager MMC snap-in.

This event does not report the common name (cn) of the group you are accustomed to seeing in Authorization Manager where application groups are maintained. This is really bad because the account name reported in this event isn't displayed anywhere in Authorization Manager. To find out the common name of the group look for the Directory Service Changes events immediately following this event which do report the common name.
4783.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4783.llm_technical_description: An application group was created without reporting its common name. This is concerning as it deviates from standard practices where such information is typically visible in Authorization Manager. Users are directed to Directory Service Changes events for the common name.

4784.summary: A basic application group was changed
4784.description:
The user in Subject: changed the application group identified in Group:.

Application groups are part of Windows's role based access control for applications and are maintained in the Authorization Manager MMC snap-in.

This event does not report the common name (cn) of the group you are accustomed to seeing in Authorization Manager where application groups are maintained.
