This is really bad because the account name reported in this event isn't displayed anywhere in Authorization Manager. To find out the common name of the group look for the Directory Service Changes events immediately following this event which do report the common name.
4784.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4784.llm_technical_description: An application group was modified in Windows Role-Based Access Control (RBAC). The event does not include the common name of the group, which is typically displayed in Authorization Manager. This omission can lead to confusion about changes made by users.

4785.summary: A member was added to a basic application group
4785.description:
The user in Subject: added Member: to the application group identified in Group:.

Application groups are part of Windows's role based access control for applications and are maintained in the Authorization Manager MMC snap-in.

This event does not report the common name (cn) of the group you are accustomed to seeing in Authorization Manager where application groups are maintained. This is really bad because the account name reported in this event isn't displayed anywhere in Authorization Manager. To find out the common name of the group look for the Directory Service Changes events immediately following this event which do report the common name.
4785.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4785.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that a user has added a member to an application group managed through Windows's Authorization Manager (AM) MMC snap-in. The common name of the group is not directly reported in this event and can be found in subsequent Directory Service Changes events.

4786.summary: A member was removed from a basic application group
4786.description:
The user in Subject: removed Member: from the application group identified in Group:.

Application groups are part of Windows's role based access control for applications and are maintained in the Authorization Manager MMC snap-in.

This event does not report the common name (cn) of the group you are accustomed to seeing in Authorization Manager where application groups are maintained. This is really bad because the account name reported in this event isn't displayed anywhere in Authorization Manager. To find out the common name of the group look for the Directory Service Changes events immediately following this event which do report the common name.
4786.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4786.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that a user was removed from an application group within the Windows system. Application groups manage access permissions for applications and are maintained in the Authorization Manager MMC snap-in. The removal of a member could potentially grant unauthorized access if misconfigured or if the group contains sensitive resources. Further details about the group's common name can be found through subsequent Directory Service Changes events.

4787.summary: A non-member was added to a basic application group
4787.description: Apparently this event is supposed to be logged when you add an exclusion to a basic application group but instead Windows logs 4785 with no indication that the member is an excluded member.
4787.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4787.llm_technical_description: The logged event (4787) is intended to capture when a non-member is added to an application group with exclusion settings. However, the system logs 4785 instead of indicating that the member was excluded. This discrepancy suggests either logging errors or intentional bypass of exclusions.

4788.summary: A non-member was removed from a basic application group..
4788.description: Apparently this event is supposed to be logged when you remove an exclusionfrom a basic application group but instead Windows logs 4786 with no indication that the member is an excluded member.
4788.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4788.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a non-member was removed from a Basic Application Group. This is a legitimate action as Basic Groups automatically include any member with appropriate permissions without explicit listing. The event does not imply any malicious activity but may indicate misconfiguration or normal system behavior.

4789.summary: A basic application group was deleted
4789.description:
The user in Subject: deleted the application group identified in Group:.

Application groups are part of Windows's role based access control for applications and are maintained in the Authorization Manager MMC snap-in.

This event does not report the common name (cn) of the group you are accustomed to seeing in Authorization Manager where application groups are maintained. This is really bad because the account name reported in this event isn't displayed anywhere in Authorization Manager. To find out the common name of the group look for the Directory Service Changes events immediately following this event which do report the common name.
4789.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4789.llm_technical_description: An application group was deleted as part of Windows's role-based access control system. This event provides limited information about the common name of the group since the Authorization Manager does not report it here, requiring further investigation through Directory Service Changes events.

4790.summary: An LDAP query group was created
4790.description:
This event also applies to Business Rule Application Groups.

The user in Subject: created an LDAP Query group or Business Rule Application Group(BRAP) identified in Group:.

Query and BRAP groups are part of Windows's role based access control for applications and are maintained in the Authorization Manager MMC snap-in.

This event does not report the common name (cn) of the group you are accustomed to seeing in Authorization Manager where application groups are maintained. This is really bad because the account name reported in this event isn't displayed anywhere in Authorization Manager. To find out the common name of the group look for the Directory Service Changes events immediately following this event which do report the common name.
4790.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4790.llm_technical_description: An LDAP Query group or Business Rule Application Group (BRAP) was created under the Category: Account Management and Subcategory: Application Group Management. This event is related to Windows's role-based access control system for applications, which maintains these groups in the Authorization Manager MMC snap-in. The common name of the group is not directly reported by this event but can be found in subsequent Directory Service Changes events.

4791.summary: A basic application group was changed
4791.description:
The user in Subject: changed the LDAP Query group or Business Rule Application Group(BRAP) identified in Group:.

The event should actually say "An LDAP query group was changed" instead of basic application group.

This event also applies to Business Rule Application Groups

The other crazy thing about this event is that if you change the LDAP query of this group (arguably the most important property) Windows fails to log this event 4791.

Query and BRAP groups are part of Windows's role based access control for applications and are maintained in the Authorization Manager MMC snap-in.

This event does not report the common name (cn) of the group you are accustomed to seeing in Authorization Manager where application groups are maintained. This is really bad because the account name reported in this event isn't displayed anywhere in Authorization Manager. To find out the common name of the group look for the Directory Service Changes events immediately following this event which do report the common name.
4791.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4791.llm_technical_description: An LDAP Query group or Business Rule Application Group (BRAP) was changed by a user in Subject: within the Group:. This event does not log the common name of the group and requires checking subsequent events for this information. Such changes can impact role-based access control, potentially granting unauthorized access if misconfigured.

4792.summary: An LDAP query group was deleted
4792.description:
This event also applies to Business Rule Application Groups.

The user in Subject: deleted theLDAP Query group or Business Rule Application Group(BRAP) identified in Group:.

Query and BRAP groups are part of Windows's role based access control for applications and are maintained in the Authorization Manager MMC snap-in.

This event does not report the common name (cn) of the group you are accustomed to seeing in Authorization Manager where application groups are maintained. This is really bad because the account name reported in this event isn't displayed anywhere in Authorization Manager. To find out the common name of the group look for the Directory Service Changes events immediately following this event which do report the common name.
4792.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4792.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a user attempted to delete an LDAP Query group or Business Rule Application Group (BRAP). However, the common name of this group is not reported here, requiring subsequent Directory Service Changes events to identify it. This may suggest potential unauthorized access control changes, as BRAPs are critical for role-based access control.

4793.summary: The Password Policy Checking API was called
4793.description: Microsoft says this is "typical behavior" and can be ignored. I concur. You may frequently see it on SQL Servers.
4793.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4793.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4793</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13829</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-08-18T02:37:46.322424300Z" /> <EventRecordID>172342</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="520" ThreadID="2964" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x36f67</Data> <Data Name="Workstation">DC01</Data> <Data Name="TargetUserName">-</Data> <Data Name="Status">0x0</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4793.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that the Password Policy Checking API was accessed, which is typically done on SQL Server to enforce account policies. While this is considered normal behavior, improper password policies could pose security risks.

4794.summary: An attempt was made to set the Directory Services Restore Mode administrator password
4794.description:
This event is logged whenever you successfully set the DSRM administrator password such as with ntdsutil.

This password is important since it controls someone's ability to enter DSRM and potentially restore or other wise access the Active Directory database.
4794.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4794.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4794</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13824</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-08-18T02:49:26.087748900Z" /> <EventRecordID>172348</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="520" ThreadID="2964" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x36f67</Data> <Data Name="Workstation">DC01</Data> <Data Name="Status">0x0</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4794.llm_technical_description: An attempt was made to modify the Directory Services Restore Mode (DSRM) administrator password. This event could indicate unauthorized access or an attempt to gain persistence by changing the critical DSRM admin password. The password for this account is essential for maintaining secure Active Directory database access, and any unauthorized changes could lead to significant security risks.

4797.summary: An attempt was made to query the existence of a blank password for an account
4797.description: There is a lot of confusion about this event and no good explanation.  If you see this event for many different target account names I would investigate.  Or if you see this event on many different systems where caller workstation name is the same.  Otherwise ignore.
4797.operating_systems: Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4797.llm_technical_description: An attempt was made to query the existence of a blank password for an account. This activity may indicate unauthorized attempts to gain access to accounts, potentially following a compromised password scenario.

4798.summary: A user's local group membership was enumerated.
4798.description: Windows logs this event when a process enumerates the local groups to which a the specified user belongs on that computer.
4798.operating_systems: Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4798.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4798</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13824</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-11-12T04:14:17.436787700Z" /> <EventRecordID>691</EventRecordID> <Correlation ActivityID="{CBAEDE08-1CF0-0000-50DE-AECBF01CD101}" /> <Execution ProcessID="744" ThreadID="3928" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>WIN10-1.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="TargetUserName">Administrator</Data> <Data Name="TargetDomainName">WIN10-1</Data> <Data Name="TargetSid">S-1-5-21-1694160624-234216347-2203645164-500</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-1377283216-344919071-3415362939-1104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x72d9d</Data> <Data Name="CallerProcessId">0xc80</Data> <Data Name="CallerProcessName">C:\\\\Windows\\\\System32\\\\mmc.exe</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4798.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a user has been added to or removed from a local group, which is part of normal user account management activities.

4799.summary: A security-enabled local group membership was enumerated
4799.description: Windows logs this event when a process enumerates the members of the specified local group on that computer.
4799.operating_systems: Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4799.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4799</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13826</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-11-12T03:50:23.625407600Z" /> <EventRecordID>685</EventRecordID> <Correlation ActivityID="{CBAEDE08-1CF0-0000-50DE-AECBF01CD101}" /> <Execution ProcessID="744" ThreadID="188" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>WIN10-1.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="TargetUserName">Administrators</Data> <Data Name="TargetDomainName">Builtin</Data> <Data Name="TargetSid">S-1-5-32-544</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-1377283216-344919071-3415362939-1104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x72d9d</Data> <Data Name="CallerProcessId">0xc80</Data> <Data Name="CallerProcessName">C:\\\\Windows\\\\System32\\\\mmc.exe</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4799.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a process has enumerated members of a local security group, which is typically done when users join or leave groups. This could be indicative of unauthorized actions by an attacker aiming to elevate privileges or gather sensitive information.

4800.description:
When either a user manually lockshis workstation or the workstation automatically locks its console after a period of inactivity this event is logged.

To find out when the user returned and unlocked the workstation look for event ID 4801.

If a screen saver is used, there is a relationship between this event and 4802/4803 See event ID4802 for an explanation of the sequence of events.
4800.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4800.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4800</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>12551</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-09-10T23:47:02.430644500Z" /> <EventRecordID>237655</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="504" ThreadID="2568" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="TargetUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="TargetUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="TargetDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="TargetLogonId">0x759a9</Data> <Data Name="SessionId">3</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4800.llm_technical_description: This event (ID: 4800) logs when a user manually locks their workstation or the system locks automatically after inactivity. The event is part of normal user activity and screen saver functionality, as indicated by related events (4801 and 4802-4803).

4801.description:
When a user unlockshis workstation you will see this event.

To find out when the workstation was previously lockedlook backwards in time for for event ID 4800.

If a screen saver is used, there is also arelationship between this event and 4802 (screen saver invoked) and 4803 (screen saver dismissed). For Interactive logons you may see this event or 4803. See event ID 4802 for the sequence of events.
4801.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4801.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4801</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>12551</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-09-10T23:47:05.886096400Z" /> <EventRecordID>237657</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="504" ThreadID="4540" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="TargetUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="TargetUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="TargetDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="TargetLogonId">0x759a9</Data> <Data Name="SessionId">3</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4801.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that the workstation was unlocked without logging in. This is typically done by unauthorized users or attackers attempting to access sensitive data or resources without proper authentication.

4802.description:
When the workstation activates the screen saver in response toa period of inactivity this event is logged.

To find out when the user returned and unlocked the workstation look for event ID 4803.

There is a relationship between this event and 4800 (workstation locked). For Interactive logons you may see the following sequence:
4802.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4802.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4802</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>12551</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-09-11T00:16:32.377883700Z" /> <EventRecordID>237662</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="504" ThreadID="1676" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="TargetUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="TargetUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="TargetDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="TargetLogonId">0x759a9</Data> <Data Name="SessionId">3</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4802.llm_technical_description: The event ID 4802 indicates that the screen saver was invoked in response to inactivity at the workstation. This is typically done by users when they intend to return after some period of time without being logged on or interacting with their system. The screen saver helps conserve battery life and extends the time between logons, which can be a sign of normal user behavior.

4803.description:
When a user unlockshis workstation you will see this event.

To find out when the screen saver previously kicked in look backwards in time for for event ID 4802.

There is a relationship between this event and 4800/4801 (workstation unlocked). For Interactive logons you may see this event or 4801. See event ID 4802 for an explanation of the sequence.
4803.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4803.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4803</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>12551</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-09-11T00:19:09.576094500Z" /> <EventRecordID>237663</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="504" ThreadID="524" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="TargetUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="TargetUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="TargetDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="TargetLogonId">0x759a9</Data> <Data Name="SessionId">3</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4803.llm_technical_description: The screen saver was dismissed when a user unlocked their workstation. This event typically occurs after a legitimate login. If this event happens frequently or in conjunction with other unusual activities (like multiple logouts without user input), it may indicate unauthorized system access.

4816.summary: RPC detected an integrity violation while decrypting an incoming message
4816.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4816.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that an RPC (Remote Procedure Call) message was decrypted and an integrity violation occurred during the decryption process. This suggests potential unauthorized modification of encrypted data being passed through RPC, which could indicate malicious activity such as a brute force attack or unauthorized access to sensitive information.

4817.summary: Auditing settings on object were changed.
4817.description: Auditing settings on object were changed.
4817.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4817.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4817</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13568</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-11-10T01:26:33.191368500Z" /> <EventRecordID>1192270</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="516" ThreadID="3048" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-18</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">DC01$</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x3e7</Data> <Data Name="ObjectServer">LSA</Data> <Data Name="ObjectType">Global SACL</Data> <Data Name="ObjectName">Key</Data> <Data Name="OldSd" /> <Data Name="NewSd">S:(AU;SA;RC;;;S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104)</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4817.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that an object has had its auditing settings modified. This could involve changes in how system events are recorded or tracked, potentially indicating unauthorized modification of audit policies.

4818.summary: Proposed Central Access Policy does not grant the same access permissions as the current Central Access Policy
4818.operating_systems: Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4818.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4818</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>12813</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-09-30T16:37:29.473472100Z" /> <EventRecordID>1049324</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="516" ThreadID="524" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-2104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">Auditor</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x1e5f21</Data> <Data Name="ObjectServer">Security</Data> <Data Name="ObjectType">File</Data> <Data Name="ObjectName">C:\\\\Finance Documents\\\\desktop.ini</Data> <Data Name="HandleId">0xc64</Data> <Data Name="ProcessId">0x4</Data> <Data Name="ProcessName" /> <Data Name="AccessReason">%%1538: %%1801 D:(A;ID;0x1200a9;;;BU) %%1541: %%1801 D:(A;ID;0x1200a9;;;BU) %%4416: %%1801 D:(A;ID;0x1200a9;;;BU) %%4419: %%1801 D:(A;ID;0x1200a9;;;BU) %%4423: %%1801 D:(A;ID;0x1200a9;;;BU)</Data> <Data Name="StagingReason">%%1538: %%1814Finance Documents Rule %%1541: %%1814Finance Documents Rule %%4416: %%1814Finance Documents Rule %%4419: %%1814Finance Documents Rule %%4423: %%1814Finance Documents Rule</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4818.llm_technical_description: The event indicates a mismatch between the proposed Central Access Policy and the current one during Central Policy Staging. This could imply intentional misconfiguration or unauthorized access attempts.

4819.summary: Central Access Policies on the machine have been changed
4819.operating_systems: Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4819.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4819</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13573</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-11-10T01:00:34.352877700Z" /> <EventRecordID>1187659</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="516" ThreadID="3500" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-18</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">DC01$</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x3e7</Data> <Data Name="ObjectServer">LSA</Data> <Data Name="ObjectType">Central Access Policies</Data> <Data Name="AddedCAPs">Main POlicy</Data> <Data Name="DeletedCAPs" /> <Data Name="ModifiedCAPs" /> <Data Name="AsIsCAPs" /> </EventData> </Event>
4819.llm_technical_description: The event indicates a change in central access policies on the machine, which could imply unauthorized access attempts or legitimate system management activities. Without specific details from Sigma rules, potential threats cannot be definitively assessed.

4820.summary: A Kerberos Ticket-granting-ticket (TGT) was denied because the device does not meet the access control restrictions
4820.description: This event is new to Server 2012 R2. It does not appear in earlier versions.
4820.operating_systems: Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4820.llm_technical_description: An attempt to logon was denied due to access control restrictions in the Kerberos Authentication Service, indicating possible unauthorized activity. This event is specific to Server 2012 R2 and may suggest either legitimate access control issues or malicious attempts.

4821.summary: A Kerberos service ticket was denied because the user, device, or both does not meet the access control restrictions
4821.description: This event is new to Server 2012 R2. It does not appear in earlier versions.
4821.operating_systems: Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4821.llm_technical_description: A Kerberos service ticket was denied due to access control issues. This event is specific to Server 2012 R2 and may indicate misconfigurations or potential unauthorized access attempts if recurring.

4822.summary: NTLM authentication failed because the account was a member of the Protected User group
4822.description: This event is new to Server 2012 R2. It does not appear in earlier versions.
4822.operating_systems: Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4822.llm_technical_description: This event indicates a failed NTLM authentication attempt because the account belongs to the Protected User group, which typically restricts access to sensitive system resources. The fact that this occurred only in Server 2012 R2 suggests it may be due to an unintended change in user permissions or misconfiguration.

4823.summary: NTLM authentication failed because access control restrictions are required
4823.description: This event is new to Server 2012 R2. It does not appear in earlier versions.
4823.operating_systems: Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4823.llm_technical_description: This event indicates a failed NTLM authentication attempt due to access control restrictions in Server 2012 R2. It suggests potential unauthorized login attempts or misconfigured permissions, which could indicate an attacker's attempt to gain access without meeting the necessary system requirements.

4824.summary: Kerberos preauthentication by using DES or RC4 failed because the account was a member of the Protected User group
4824.description: This event is new to Server 2012 R2. It does not appear in earlier versions.
4824.operating_systems: Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4824.llm_technical_description: The Kerberos preauthentication attempt failed when an account was a member of the Protected User group, which is new to Server 2012 R2. This could indicate potential misconfiguration or unauthorized access attempts.

4825.summary: A user was denied the access to Remote Desktop. By default, users are allowed to connect only if they are members of the Remote Desktop Users group or Administrators group
4825.operating_systems: Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4825.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that a user was denied access to Remote Desktop Services (RDS) despite being authorized or having appropriate permissions. The denial typically occurs when an authenticated user not permitted for remote access attempts to connect via RDP. This could be indicative of unauthorized login attempts, potential attacker probe activities, or system misconfigurations.

4826.description: Windows logs this event at startup to document the current Boot Configuration Data settings with particular security relevance. BCD data is configured with bcdedit.exe.
4826.operating_systems: Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4826.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4826</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13573</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-11-13T00:59:57.553201100Z" /> <EventRecordID>751</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="4" ThreadID="164" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>WIN10-1</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-18</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">-</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">-</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x3e7</Data> <Data Name="LoadOptions">-</Data> <Data Name="AdvancedOptions">%%1843</Data> <Data Name="ConfigAccessPolicy">%%1846</Data> <Data Name="RemoteEventLogging">%%1843</Data> <Data Name="KernelDebug">%%1843</Data> <Data Name="VsmLaunchType">%%1848</Data> <Data Name="TestSigning">%%1843</Data> <Data Name="FlightSigning">%%1843</Data> <Data Name="DisableIntegrityChecks">%%1843</Data> <Data Name="HypervisorLoadOptions">-</Data> <Data Name="HypervisorLaunchType">%%1848</Data> <Data Name="HypervisorDebug">%%1843</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4826.llm_technical_description: The event 'Boot Configuration Data loaded' occurs at system startup and logs the current BCD (Boot Configuration Data) settings, including security-relevant information such as hardware identifiers and driver configurations. This logging can potentially expose sensitive data if unauthorized access is gained, especially since it's configured using bcdedit.exe, which might be vulnerable to exploitation.

4830.summary: SID History was removed from an account
4830.description: We have not yet seen this event
4830.operating_systems: Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4830.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that the Session Information Directory (SID) history for an account was removed. This is significant because SID stores sensitive session data, including login attempts and failed log-ons. Removing SID history could indicate unauthorized access or an attempt to erase evidence of a security incident. Since this event has not been previously observed, it may signal an unusual activity that warrants investigation.

4864.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4864.llm_technical_description: A namespace collision was detected, which typically occurs when multiple processes attempt to access the same namespace resource without proper synchronization. This can lead to conflicts where resources are shared or not properly handled between different processes, potentially causing performance issues or crashes if not resolved correctly.

4865.summary: A trusted forest information entry was added
4865.description:
This event is logged cross-forest trust relationships are created or modified. You will get several of these events per trust. 

Windows stores trust relationships as Trusted Domain Objects (see events 4706, 4707, 4716) but cross-forest trusts require extra information stored in several entries in the TDO's Forest Trust Information attribute (aka FTInfo). FTInfo includes the all namespaces that a trusted forest manages, withother fields that indicate whether each claim is actually trusted by the trusting (this) forest.

This event, 4865, documents creation of each ofsuch entries. You can link all the entries created at one time by the Operation ID:.

Not all elements are filled in for each entry type.
4865.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4865.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4865</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13569</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-10-02T03:11:33.397715700Z" /> <EventRecordID>1049810</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="500" ThreadID="4808" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="ForestRoot">Fabrikam.local</Data> <Data Name="ForestRootSid">S-1-5-21-2703072690-1374247579-2643703677</Data> <Data Name="OperationId">0x648620</Data> <Data Name="EntryType">2</Data> <Data Name="Flags">0</Data> <Data Name="TopLevelName">-</Data> <Data Name="DnsName">Fabrikam.local</Data> <Data Name="NetbiosName">FABRIKAM</Data> <Data Name="DomainSid">S-1-5-21-2703072690-1374247579-2643703677</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x138eb0</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4865.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that a trusted forest's information entry was added or modified. This can relate to changes in cross-forest trust relationships, which are often associated with certificate revocation lists (CRLs) or manipulating trust chains for malicious purposes such as generating certificates for attacks like certificate spoofing.

4866.summary: A trusted forest information entry was removed
4866.description:
This event is logged cross-forest trust relationships are deleted or modified. You will get several of these events per trust. 

Windows stores trust relationships as Trusted Domain Objects (see events 4706, 4707, 4716) but cross-forest trusts require extra information stored in several entries in the TDO's Forest Trust Information attribute (aka FTInfo). FTInfo includes the all namespaces that a trusted forest manages, withother fields that indicate whether each claim is actually trusted by the trusting (this) forest.

This event, 4865, documents deletion of each ofsuch entries. You can link all the entries created at one time by the Operation ID:.

Not all elements are filled in for each entry type.
4866.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4866.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that a trusted forest information entry has been removed under an Authentication Policy Change. Trusted forests manage trust relationships between domains using TDOs and their FTInfo attributes. Removing these entries without proper justification can lead to misconfigurations, potentially exploited by attackers for privilege escalation or unauthorized access.

4867.summary: A trusted forest information entry was modified
4867.description:
This event is logged cross-forest trust relationships are modified. You will get several of these events per trust. 

Windows stores trust relationships as Trusted Domain Objects (see events 4706, 4707, 4716) but cross-forest trusts require extra information stored in several entries in the TDO's Forest Trust Information attribute (aka FTInfo). FTInfo includes the all namespaces that a trusted forest manages, withother fields that indicate whether each claim is actually trusted by the trusting (this) forest.

This event, 4865, documents creation of each ofsuch entries. You can link all the entries modified at one time by the Operation ID:.

Not all elements are filled in for each entry type.
4867.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4867.llm_technical_description: An attacker may have attempted to modify trust relationships between domains by altering entries in the forest trust information attribute (FTInfo). This event logs such changes, which could bypass security checks if not properly verified. The modification of cross-forest trusts might allow unauthorized access or bypass authentication policies.

4868.summary: The certificate manager denied a pending certificate request
4868.description:
Certification Authorities and Certificate Templates can be configured to require approval by an administrator or certificate manager before the certificate is signed and issued by the CA. In such cases the certificate request is accepted into the Pending Requests folder of the Certification Authority MMC snap-in. The certificate manager can then Issue or Deny the request. This event is logged when the manager denies the request.

To get the details on the request including who requested it you will need to look in the log forotherevents with the same Request ID.

This event event is only logged if "Issue and manage certificate requests" is enabled on the Audit tab of the CA's properties in Certificate Services MMC snap-in and of course if the Certificate Services audit subcategory is enabled with auditpol.
4868.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4868.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a pending certificate request was denied by an administrator or certificate manager in the Certification Services MMC snap-in. This can occur if there is an attempt to bypass system security controls, such as misconfigured settings or malicious actors exploiting vulnerabilities to gain administrative access.

4869.summary: Certificate Services received a resubmitted certificate request
4869.description: This event gets logged more than the description would indicate. It seems to be logged whenever
4869.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4869.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that Certificate Services has received a resubmitted certificate request. This is typically a normal operation when an organization renews its digital certificates, modifies parameters, or requests a new one after expiration.

4870.description:
When an administrator revokes a certificate the certificate is moved to the Revoked Certificates folder and this event is logged. Reason for revocation noted below.

Unfortunately Windows does not report who revoked the certificate, just that it happened. To find out what certificate was revoked look in Revoked Certificates for the Serial Number reported herein. 

Serial Number: the serial number of the certificate see the Details tab of the certificate's Properties dialog.

This event event is only logged if "Revoke certificates and publish CRLs" is enabled on the Audit tab of the CA's properties in Certificate Services MMC snap-in and of course if the Certificate Services audit subcategory is enabled with auditpol.
4870.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4870.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that an administrator revoked a certificate in the system, moving it to the Revoked Certificates folder. This is typically done for legitimate purposes such as updating certificates or managing security keys. However, if this action is logged without proper context or authorization checks, it could be a sign of potential misuse, such as accidental revocation or unauthorized access.

4871.summary: Certificate Services received a request to publish the certificate revocation list (CRL)
4871.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4871.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that Certificate Services received a request to publish a certificate revocation list (CRL). This typically occurs when a trusted certificate is revoked. Attackers may exploit this by tricking a CA into revoking legitimate certificates or publishing CRLs without proper authorization, leading to potential unauthorized access or data exposure.

4872.summary: Certificate Services published the certificate revocation list (CRL)
4872.description:
Certification Authorities as a normal course of operation periodically publish an updated CRL and this event is logged at that time.

This event event is only logged if "Revoke certificates and publish CRLs" is enabled on the Audit tab of the CA's properties in Certificate Services MMC snap-in and of course if the Certificate Services audit subcategory is enabled with auditpol.

Base CRL: Yes or No - A base CRL is every certificate ever revoked; a delta CRL is an update to the base CRL and preceding deltas.

CRL Number: incremented each time CRL published

Key Container: unknown. if you have information on this field please share it in a discussion below.

Next Publish: The next time an updated CRL will be published

Publish URLs: the URLs where the CRL was published including file system paths, ldap/Active Directory and on the web via http
4872.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4872.llm_technical_description: The event indicates a normal operation by a Certificate Authority (CA), where a certificate revocation list (CRL) was published. CAs periodically publish updated CRLs to reflect revoked certificates. This event is logged under the 'Revoke certificates and publish CRLs' setting in the CA's properties within the Object Access category. The CRL number increments each time a new CRL is issued, while base CRLs are for all revoked certificates and deltas update existing ones.
4872.llm_security_impact: The event itself does not indicate malicious activity but could be a sign of compromised certificate authority operations if followed by other suspicious activities like certificate revocation or key compromise. Attackers might misuse this process to revoke legitimate certificates or impersonate CAs.

4873.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4873.llm_technical_description: The event (ID: 4873) indicates a change in a certificate request extension within the Certification Services category under Object Access. However, without detailed context or known false positives from Sigma rules, it's challenging to determine if this is malicious or legitimate.

4874.summary: One or more certificate request attributes changed.
4874.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4874.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that one or more certificate request attributes have been changed, possibly within the context of Certification Services in Windows. This could involve changes to trust certificates, which might be legitimate but could also indicate malicious behavior if misconfigured.

4875.summary: Certificate Services received a request to shut down
4875.description:
Having tested for this event by shutting down Certificate Services I conclude this event does not seem to get logged at all despite MS documentation. 

However check out events 4880 and 4881 which log startup and shutdown of Certificate Services.
4875.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4875.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that Certificate Services received a request to shut down. However, based on the provided information, this event is not being logged despite standard practices suggesting that such operations should be logged (as seen in events 4880 and 4881). This could indicate an attempt to bypass logging mechanisms or unauthorized access.

4876.description:
Logged each time the Certification Authorities backup starts. Event indicates type of backup below. Next, event 4877 shows when the backup completes.

This event event is only logged if "Backup and restore the CA database" is enabled on the Audit tab of the CA's properties in Certificate Services MMC snap-in and of course if the Certificate Services audit subcategory is enabled with auditpol.
4876.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4876.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a backup job for the CA database has started. This is typically enabled by an administrator through the Audit tab in Certificate Services MMC snap-in, and it occurs whenever the backup starts.

4877.description:
Certificate Services backup completed. To find out when the backup started and what type of backup it was look earlier in the log for 4876.

This event event is only logged if "Backup and restore the CA database" is enabled on the Audit tab of the CA's properties in Certificate Services MMC snap-in and of course if the Certificate Services audit subcategory is enabled with auditpol.
4877.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4877.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that the Certificate Services backup was completed successfully. This is a system-level activity related to automation or scheduled operations for Certificate Services on Windows systems.

4878.description:
self explanatory

To find out when the restore ended look later in the log for 4879.

This event event is only logged if "Backup and restore the CA database" is enabled on the Audit tab of the CA's properties in Certificate Services MMC snap-in and of course if the Certificate Services audit subcategory is enabled with auditpol
4878.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4878.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a backup and restore operation for the CA (Certificate Authority) database has begun, as configured in Certificate Services MMC snap-in. This is typically done during scheduled maintenance or after an attack/compromise to ensure data integrity. The event is logged under specific conditions related to audit settings.

4879.description:
self explanatory

To find out when the restore started look earlier in the log for 4878.
4879.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4879.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a Certificate Services restore was completed. This could be related to legitimate reasons such as maintenance or updates, but it could also be suspicious if there are indicators of compromise (e.g., a compromised CRL). The typical behavior for certificate services is to restart periodically, and any deviation from this pattern should be investigated.

4880.description:
This event is logged each time the Active Directory Certificate Services service starts.

This event event is only logged if "Start and stop Active Directory Certificate Services" is enabled on the Audit tab of the CA's properties in Certificate Services MMC snap-in and of course if the Certificate Services audit subcategory is enabled with auditpol.
4880.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4880.llm_technical_description: The event ID 4880 indicates that the Active Directory Certificate Services started. This event is logged based on specific configurations in the Certificate Services MMC snap-in, namely 'Start and stop Active Directory Certificate Services' being enabled on the Audit tab of the CA's properties, along with the audit subcategory being enabled using auditpol. The occurrence of this event suggests normal operation or potential unauthorized modifications to these settings.

4881.description:
This event is logged each time the Active Directory Certificate Services service is stopped.

This event event is only logged if "Start and stop Active Directory Certificate Services" is enabled on the Audit tab of the CA's properties in Certificate Services MMC snap-in and of course if the Certificate Services audit subcategory is enabled with auditpol.
4881.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4881.llm_technical_description: The Active Directory Certificate Services service has been stopped. This event is logged under specific conditions: when 'Start and stop Active Directory Certificate Services' is enabled in the CA properties and if the audit subcategory is enabled with auditpol. Such stopping could indicate unauthorized access or misconfiguration, potentially signaling malicious activity.

4882.summary: The security permissions for Certificate Services changed
4882.description:
This event documents a change to the access control list of the Certification Authority itself. The ACL governs who can perform CA level operations documented below.

You can reach the ACL by opening the Properties dialog of the CA in the Certification Authority MMC snap-in.

This event event is only logged if "Change CA security settings" is enabled on the Audit tab of the CA's properties in Certificate Services MMC snap-in and of course if the Certificate Services audit subcategory is enabled with auditpol.

Allow user/group

 permission/role

 permission/role

 permission/role... Allow user/group

 permission/role

 permission/role

 permission/role... Allow user/group

 permission/role

 permission/role

 permission/role... Allow user/group

 permission/role

 permission/role

 permission/role...
4882.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4882.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that the security permissions for Certificate Services have been modified. Specifically, an access control list (ACL) of a Certification Authority has had its permissions altered. This event is logged when changes to CA security settings are enabled in the Audit tab of the CA's properties within the Certificates MMC snap-in and the Certificate Services audit subcategory is enabled with auditpol. The change could potentially grant unauthorized users or processes access to critical operations, posing a security risk.

4883.summary: Certificate Services retrieved an archived key
4883.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4883.llm_technical_description: The event ID 4883 indicates that the system retrieved a key from an archive under Certificate Services in the Certification Services category. This typically occurs within the system's certificate trust store, which could be part of normal operations such as updating certificates or managing keys. The technical implication is that this action might be legitimate but should be monitored for any signs of unauthorized access or tampering.
4883.llm_security_impact: The security impact depends on context; it can range from LOW to HIGH based on whether the key retrieval involves unauthorized access, malicious intent, or system compromise.
4883.llm_recommended_monitoring: YES (if monitoring for unusual patterns or potential tampering)

4884.summary: Certificate Services imported a certificate into its database
4884.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4884.llm_technical_description: The event involves importing a certificate into the system's database by Certificate Services under Object Access. This is typically a normal operation for managing digital certificates such as revocation or renewal requests.

4885.summary: The audit filter for Certificate Services changed
4885.description:
Windows logs this event whenever you modify the Auditing tab of the Properties dialog of the CA in the Certification Authority MMC snap-in. The Audit tab controls which CA releated events are reported to the security log.

The Filter: field below is a bitwise representation of the check boxes on the Audit tab mentioned above.
4885.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4885.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that the user has modified the audit filter settings in the CA MMC snap-in properties dialog. This is part of system configuration and typically triggers a logging event to record this action.

4886.summary: Certificate Services received a certificate request
4886.description:
When the Certification Authority receives a certificate reqeuest it logs this event. 

Then it evaluates the request, loading the relavent certificate template if appropriate (event 4898). Then the CA will place the request into the Pending Requests folder (4889), immediately issue (4887) or deny it (4888). 

This event event is only logged if "Issue and manage certificate requests" is enabled on the Audit tab of the CA's properties in Certificate Services MMC snap-in and of course if the Certificate Services audit subcategory is enabled with auditpol.

Request ID: The certificate request is identified by the Request ID. To get the details on the request including who requested it you will need to look in the log forotherevents with the same Request ID.

Requester:the account that requested the certificate
Attributes: unknown. if you have information to share on this event please start a discussion.

Attributes: attributes taken from the certificate template and request

UserAgent: the browser ID or other program that submitted the request 

ccm: apparently the computer name of the client
4886.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4886.llm_technical_description: This event logs when a Certificate Authority receives and processes a certificate request, which is part of normal system security operations. It can be monitored for potential attacks or misuse by checking against Sigma detection rules.

4887.summary: Certificate Services approved a certificate request and issued a certificate
4887.description: This event is logged when a certificate is issued as a result of either:
4887.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4887.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that Certificate Services issued a certificate as part of a request. This could be related to digital certificates used for SSL/TLS in web communications. The event may suggest potential malicious activity if the certificate issuance is unauthorized, such as being issued for a malicious domain or due to misconfigured CA settings.

4888.summary: Certificate Services denied a certificate request
4888.description: This event event is only logged if "Issue and manage certificate requests" is enabled on the Audit tab of the CA's properties in Certificate Services MMC snap-in and of course if the Certificate Services audit subcategory is enabled with auditpol.
4888.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4888.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that Certificate Services has denied a certificate request, likely due to system configuration such as necessary access controls or audit checks. The denial occurs under specific conditions related to the CA's properties and audit subcategory settings.

4889.summary: Certificate Services set the status of a certificate request to pending
4889.description:
Certification Authorities and Certificate Templates can be configured to require approval by an administrator or certificate manager before the certificate is signed and issued by the CA. 

In such cases the certificate request is received (event 4886) and placedinto the Pending Requests folder of the Certification Authority MMC snap-in. 

This event, 4889,is logged when the request is submitted to Pending. The certificate manager can then Issue (event 4887)or Deny (event ID 4868)the request.

This event event is only logged if "Issue and manage certificate requests" is enabled on the Audit tab of the CA's properties in Certificate Services MMC snap-in and of course if the Certificate Services audit subcategory is enabled with auditpol.

Request ID: To get the details on the request including who requested it you will need to look in the log forotherevents with the same Request ID.

Requester:the account that requested the certificate

Attributes: unknown. if you have information to share on this event please start a discussion.

UserAgent: the browser ID or other program that submitted the request 

ccm: apparently <ca computer name>.<domain name>
4889.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4889.llm_technical_description: The event logs the submission of a certificate request status to pending by the Certificate Services MMC snap-in on a CA computer. This is part of the normal workflow where the certificate manager can issue or deny the request.

4890.summary: The certificate manager settings for Certificate Services changed.
4890.description: This event is logged when you modify the settings in the Certificate Managers tab of the CA properties dialog in Certification Authority MMC snap-in.
4890.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4890.llm_technical_description: The certificate manager settings in Certificate Services have been modified. This could indicate a potential security concern if unauthorized changes were made by an attacker aiming to manipulate digital certificate trust management, potentially leading to unauthorized access or distribution of malicious content.

4891.summary: A configuration entry changed in Certificate Services
4891.description:
Windows logs this event to document changes to Certificate Services registry entries many of which correspond to properties in the CA Properties dialog of Certification Authority MMC snap-in. 

You can learn more about the various entries athttp://technet2.microsoft.com/windowsserver/en/library/7fe116af-971b-44d3-809e-00606c080a191033.mspx?mfr=true

Node: the subkey path under HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\CertSvc\Configuration\ca name

Entry: The registry value name

Value: the data of the value
4891.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4891.llm_technical_description: The event indicates a change made to the CAName registry entry under the CertSvc configuration in Windows. This reflects an attempt to modify system-wide trust store settings without user interaction, which could facilitate Credential Access Attacks (CAA) by altering user trust configurations.

4892.summary: A property of Certificate Services changed
4892.description: A property of Certificate Services changed.
4892.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4892.llm_technical_description: The event indicates a property change in Certificate Services. This service is responsible for managing digital certificates and private key forest encryption. While this could generally relate to legitimate system operations, such events should still be monitored for signs of unauthorized modification or exploitation.

4893.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4893.llm_technical_description: This event involves the archive of a certificate key by an account using Windows Server 2016 or later. This typically occurs when an account lockout policy is enforced during a successful sign-on attempt.

4894.summary: Certificate Services imported and archived a key
4894.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4894.llm_technical_description: Importing and archiving a key in Certificate Services under Object Access: Certification Services indicates that the system has added a digital certificate for storage. This could be a legitimate operation, such as adding a public key for managing SSL/TLS certificates. However, if unauthorized or excessive operations occur, it may suggest malicious activity like unauthorized access attempts or misconfigured trust chains.

4895.summary: Certificate Services published the CA certificate to Active Directory Domain Services
4895.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4895.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that the Certificate Services (CS) published a CA certificate to Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS). This is typically part of the normal digital certificate issuance process, such as when legitimate certificates are issued. However, if there is an unauthorized modification or substitution of this CA certificate, it could indicate potential misconfiguration or malicious activity by an attacker who might exploit this to impersonate trusted entities or disrupt legitimate certificate issuance.

4896.summary: One or more rows have been deleted from the certificate database
4896.description: Certificate Services published the CA certificate to Active Directory Domain Services.
4896.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4896.llm_technical_description: The deletion of one or more rows from the certificate database indicates unauthorized access or tampering with digital certificates, particularly affecting the root Certificate Authority (CA). This action could signal malicious intent as attackers may revoke CA certificates to compromise client SSL/TLS trust, enabling MitM attacks or unauthorized access.

4897.description:
This event is logged whenever CS starts and whenever role separation is actually changed.

Role separation is a form of "separation of duty" control that you can optionally enable on your Certification Authority to ensures that the compromise of a user's account - or a user going "rogue" - does not compromise the entire CA administered by the user
4897.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4897.llm_technical_description: Role separation enabled means the system has separated user roles to enhance security controls within the Certification Services (CS) environment. This event is triggered whenever the role separation configuration is changed or when CS starts.

4898.description: Windows logs this event when CS loads a certificate template in order to evaluate a new certificate request
4898.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4898.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that Certificate Services loaded a template in order to evaluate a new certificate request. This could be indicative of an attempt to create or validate a malicious certificate, such as a self-signed certificate with private key information potentially containing the attacker's IP address.

4899.summary: A Certificate Services template was updated
4899.description: Having tested for this event by making changes to certificate templates I conclude Windows fails to log this event.
4899.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4899.llm_technical_description: The event ID 4899 refers to a Certificate Services template update under Object Access > Certification Services. However, during testing with modified templates, Windows did not log this event. This could indicate potential issues such as misconfiguration, tampering, or an issue with the detection mechanism for changes in certificate services. The absence of logging may suggest that either the rule is not properly configured, there is a security bypass, or it is being intentionally avoided.

4900.summary: Certificate Services template security was updated
4900.description: Windows logs this event when you modify the ACL on a certificate template.
4900.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4900.llm_technical_description: This event logs when an ACL (Access Control List) is modified on a certificate template within the Windows system. This typically occurs during legitimate updates or configuration changes related to digital certificates used for secure communications. While this is generally a normal operation, its implications depend on whether it was done with elevated privileges or as part of unauthorized access attempts.

4902.summary: The Per-user audit policy table was created
4902.description: This is a routine event logged at system startup and can be regarded as noise.
4902.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4902.llm_technical_description: The creation of an audit policy table at the user level is a system-level action typically performed as part of maintaining security policies. This event is logged during system startup, indicating it may be routine and not indicative of malicious activity.

4904.summary: An attempt was made to register a security event source
4904.description: Windows allows applications to report their own security events to the security log by registering with Authorization Manager as a security event source using the AuthzRegisterSecurityEventSource function. Windows logs this event, 4904, when such an application calls AuthzRegisterSecurityEventSource and thus provides an audit trail of applications that report custom security events. It is normal to see this event logged for several built-in components of Windows including IIS and DFS-R.
4904.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4904.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4904</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13568</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-10-01T00:53:01.030688000Z" /> <EventRecordID>1049538</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="520" ThreadID="548" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-18</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">DC01$</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x3e7</Data> <Data Name="AuditSourceName">FSRM Audit</Data> <Data Name="EventSourceId">0x1cc4e</Data> <Data Name="ProcessId">0x688</Data> <Data Name="ProcessName">C:\\\\Windows\\\\System32\\\\svchost.exe</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4904.llm_technical_description: This event (4904) is part of Windows' normal process where applications register as security event sources using the Audit Manager. It logs audit trails for built-in components like IIS and DFS-R, which is expected during normal operations.

4905.summary: An attempt was made to unregister a security event source
4905.description:
Windows allows applications to report their own security events to the security log by registering through Authorization Manager with LSA as a security event source using the AuthzRegisterSecurityEventSource function. 

Later applications can unregister by calling AuthzUnregisterSecurityEventSource. Windows logs this event, 4904, when such an application calls AuthzUnregisterSecurityEventSource and thus provides an audit trail of applications that report custom security events. It is normal to see this event logged for several built-in components of Windows including IIS and DFS-R.
4905.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4905.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4905</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13568</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-10-01T17:39:12.039825000Z" /> <EventRecordID>1049718</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="500" ThreadID="1888" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-18</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">DC01$</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x3e7</Data> <Data Name="AuditSourceName">IIS-METABASE</Data> <Data Name="EventSourceId">0x20c15f</Data> <Data Name="ProcessId">0xd90</Data> <Data Name="ProcessName">-</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4905.llm_technical_description: The attempt to unregister a security event source (event ID 4905) is part of the Windows process for auditing applications that report custom security events. This event, along with its preceding ID 4904, occurs when an application unregisters itself as a security event source using the AuthzUnregisterSecurityEventSource function. The Sigma rule VSSAudit Security Event Source Registration detects this activity and may trigger alerts if it occurs during legitimate operations like volume shadow copy or backup processes.

4906.description: This event is logged when you change the value of the security option "Audit: Shut down system immediately if unable to log security audits" which can be used to make the system crash with blue screen if the security log fills and configured to not overwrite or autobackup.
4906.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4906.llm_technical_description: The system logs an event when the 'Audit: Shut down system immediately if unable to log security audits' option is changed. This can result in a blue screen crash if the security log fills without being overwritten or backed up.

4907.summary: Auditing settings on object were changed
4907.description: When you change the audit SACL of an object, such as a file or folder, Windows logs this event. In the example below, Administrator configured a new audit policy on C:\Users\Administrator\testfolder.
4907.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
