4907.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4907</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13568</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-10-01T18:18:19.458828800Z" /> <EventRecordID>1049732</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="500" ThreadID="508" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x138eb0</Data> <Data Name="ObjectServer">Security</Data> <Data Name="ObjectType">Key</Data> <Data Name="ObjectName">\\\\REGISTRY\\\\MACHINE\\\\SYSTEM\\\\ControlSet001\\\\Services\\\\EventLog\\\\Internet Explorer</Data> <Data Name="HandleId">0x2f8</Data> <Data Name="OldSd">S:AI</Data> <Data Name="NewSd">S:ARAI(AU;CISA;KA;;;S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104)</Data> <Data Name="ProcessId">0x120c</Data> <Data Name="ProcessName">C:\\\\Windows\\\\regedit.exe</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4907.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that an administrator changed the audit SACL (Security Access Control List) settings on a file or folder. Windows logs such events when a user modifies audit permissions, which is a legitimate action for managing access control policies.

4908.description: This event is produced when a SID (Security Identifier) is added to SpecialGroups for auditing purposes.
4908.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4908.llm_technical_description: This event indicates a modification to the SpecialGroups Logon table during an Audit Policy Change. The event occurs when a SID is added for auditing purposes, typically in support of system policy updates or audits.

4909.summary: The local policy settings for the TBS were changed
4909.description:
This event, 4909, is apparently logged when you make a change to the TPM configuration in the local policy objectof the computer as opposed to GPOs in Active Directory (see event 4910).

TPM Base Services (TBS) proves an interface to theTrusted Platform Module chip in the computer if so equipped.BitLocker Drive Encryption is the most prominent feature of Windows that uses TPM.

TPM commands arereferred to asordinals. MSDN: "To preserve integrity of operations, certain TPM commands are not allowed to be executed by software on the platform. For example, some commands are only executed by system software."

Old Blocked Ordinals:TPM commands blocked before this event
New Blocked Ordinals: TPM commands blocked after this event
4909.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4909.llm_technical_description: The event (ID: 4909) indicates a change to the local policy settings for the Trusted Platform Module (TPM) configuration. This occurs when a user modifies TPM commands that are typically blocked by system software, potentially allowing malicious execution if not properly secured.

4910.summary: The group policy settings for the TBS were changed
4910.description:
This event, 4910, is apparently logged when you make a change to the TPM configuration through a group policy object in Active Directoryas opposed to with the local policy of the system (see event 4909).

TPM Base Services (TBS) proves an interface to theTrusted Platform Module chip in the computer if so equipped.BitLocker Drive Encryption is the most prominent feature of Windows that uses TPM.

TPM commands arereferred to asordinals. MSDN: "To preserve integrity of operations, certain TPM commands are not allowed to be executed by software on the platform. For example, some commands are only executed by system software."

Group Policy Setting:Ignore Default Settings

Corresponds to the "Ignore the default list of blocked TPM commands" in Computer Configuration\Policies\Administrative Templates\System\Trusted Platform Module Services.

Old Value:%1
New Value:%2

Group Policy Setting:Ignore Local Settings
Old Value:%3
New Value:%4

Old Blocked Ordinals:TPM commands blocked before this event
New Blocked Ordinals: TPM commands blocked after this event
4910.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4910.llm_technical_description: This event logs when group policy settings for the Trusted Platform Module (TPM) configuration are changed in Active Directory. The change involves modifying the 'Ignore Default Settings' and 'Ignore Local Settings' configurations on the TPM Base Services, along with altering the list of blocked TPM commands. This could potentially allow unauthorized access or exploit bypasses if the new settings interfere with system security measures such as BitLocker encryption or other features dependent on TPM restrictions.

4911.summary: Resource attributes of the object were changed
4911.operating_systems: Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4911.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4911</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13570</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-11-09T23:43:04.009319300Z" /> <EventRecordID>1183714</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="516" ThreadID="524" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x37925</Data> <Data Name="ObjectServer">Security</Data> <Data Name="ObjectType">File</Data> <Data Name="ObjectName">C:\\\\Audit Files\\\\HBI Data.txt</Data> <Data Name="HandleId">0x49c</Data> <Data Name="OldSd">S:AI</Data> <Data Name="NewSd">S:ARAI(RA;ID;;;;WD;("Impact\\_MS",TI,0x10020,3000))</Data> <Data Name="ProcessId">0x67c</Data> <Data Name="ProcessName">C:\\\\Windows\\\\System32\\\\svchost.exe</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4911.llm_technical_description: The event indicates a change in resource attributes under a policy. This could involve modifying access controls for files, processes, or users, potentially impacting system security by altering permissions. The nature of the change is unclear, but it may indicate legitimate updates or malicious activities depending on context.

4912.summary: Per User Audit Policy was changed
4912.description:
When you use auditpol to set per user selective auditing Windows logs this event documenting the user for whom you set audit policy as well as the category, subcategory and the nature of the change in terms of success/failure and include/exclude.

To learn more about per-user selective auditing see See Roger Grimes article at www.windowsitpro.com for an excellent introduction to per user selective auditing. But don't get your hopes up; it isn't a very practical feature; basically it's just there for Common Criteria compliance.

The user and logon session that performed the action.
4912.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022

4945.summary: A rule was listed when the Windows Firewall started
4945.description:
This event is logged aproximately 1.7 bazillion times everytime Windows Firewall starts which results in a full record of all rules that were in place at the time Windows Firewall started. 

These rules are defined in Group Policy and in the Windows Firewall with Advanced Services MMC console.

4945.llm_technical_description: This event occurs when the Windows Firewall starts and logs all rule changes that were active at startup. The high frequency of this event (approximately 1.7 bazillion times) can overwhelm monitoring systems, potentially masking other critical events.

4951.summary: A rule has been ignored because its major version number was not recognized by Windows Firewall
4951.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4951.llm_technical_description: A policy rule was ignored because its major version number wasn't recognized by Windows Firewall. This could indicate a misconfiguration where an application or service is running with policies that are incompatible due to version mismatches, which might occur if the policy versioning isn't properly managed.

4952.summary: Parts of a rule have been ignored because its minor version number was not recognized by Windows Firewall
4952.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4952.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that Windows Firewall ignored parts of a policy rule due to an incomplete version number check (only major version specified). This could allow bypassed rule enforcement, potentially evading legitimate or system-wide policies.

4953.summary: A rule has been ignored by Windows Firewall because it could not parse the rule
4953.description: I haven't been able to produce this event. Have you? If so, please start a discussion (see above) and post a sample along with any comments you may have! Don't forget to sanitize any private information

4953.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that Windows Firewall encountered an issue parsing a rule configuration. This could imply misconfiguration or unauthorized attempt to bypass security rules, which might be indicative of malicious activity if intentional.

4954.summary: Windows Firewall Group Policy settings has changed. The new settings have been applied
4954.description: This event is logged whenever group policy is refreshed and a change in the RSOP (resultant set of policy) of Windows Firewall policies is detected.
4954.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4954.llm_technical_description: The Windows Firewall Group Policy has been changed, specifically affecting the MPSSVC Rule-Level Policy with RSOP detected. This event indicates a policy refresh or modification in Windows Firewall, which could be for legitimate reasons or malicious intent such as introducing unauthorized access policies.

4956.summary: Windows Firewall has changed the active profile
4956.description:
This event is logged whenever Windows Firewall switches between Domain and Public profiles.

You will usually see this event whenever Windows Firewall starts up since it starts out in Public and then after initialization switches to Domain if appropriate.
4956.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4956.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that Windows Firewall has changed the active profile from Public to Domain. This is a normal system behavior triggered automatically when the system boots up, especially after an initial setup where Public is the default profile.

4957.summary: Windows Firewall did not apply the following rule
4957.description:
I routinely see this event logged throughout the day for Teredo and ICMP related rules. 

These rules are defined in Group Policy and in the Windows Firewall with Advanced Services MMC console.
4957.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4957.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>4957</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13571</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8010000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-10-02T23:13:14.496678500Z" /> <EventRecordID>1049892</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="500" ThreadID="2284" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="RuleId">CoreNet-Teredo-In</Data> <Data Name="RuleName">Core Networking - Teredo (UDP-In)</Data> <Data Name="RuleAttr">Local Port</Data> </EventData> </Event>
4957.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that Windows Firewall did not apply a rule change at MPSSVC level. Teredo and ICMP rules were defined in Group Policy and the Windows Firewall with Advanced Services MMC console. The consistent occurrence throughout the day suggests potential policy misconfiguration or intentional bypass attempts by attackers to exploit misconfigured services.

4958.summary: Windows Firewall did not apply the following rule because the rule referred to items not configured on this computer
4958.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4958.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that Windows Firewall failed to apply a configured rule because certain items were not properly configured on the system. This is likely due to misconfiguration, new service installations, or other setup issues common during initial system configuration.

4960.summary: IPsec dropped an inbound packet that failed an integrity check
4960.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4960.llm_technical_description: The IPsec dropped packet integrity check failure indicates a potential network security issue. This event suggests either network corruption or exploratory activities by an attacker trying to identify vulnerabilities.

4961.summary: IPsec dropped an inbound packet that failed a replay check
4961.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4961.llm_technical_description: An IPsec packet was dropped due to a failed replay check, indicating potential replay protection issues or active attacks such as DDoS. This event may suggest misconfigurations or malicious attempts to bypass security.

4962.summary: IPsec dropped an inbound packet that failed a replay check
4962.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4962.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that an IPsec packet was dropped during transmission because the replay check failed. This could suggest malicious activity such as a man-in-the-middle attack or spoofing attempt where the source's identity was impersonated.

4963.summary: IPsec dropped an inbound clear text packet that should have been secured
4963.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4963.llm_technical_description: The IPsec event indicates that an inbound clear text packet was dropped despite being secured. This could imply malicious activity such as an attempt to bypass security measures or a denial-of-service attack targeting encrypted communications.

4964.summary: Special groups have been assigned to a new logon
4964.description: For this event to be produced, auditing for SpecialGroups must first be set up. See Event 4908 for setup.
4964.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022

4964.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that an attempt has been made to authenticate with a Special Group in Windows. Such events typically occur when there is a configuration involving Special Groups, possibly indicating unauthorized access or misconfiguration.

4965.summary: IPsec received a packet from a remote computer with an incorrect Security Parameter Index (SPI).
4965.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4965.llm_technical_description: This event indicates a potential tampering attempt in an IPsec communication as the received packet contains an incorrect Security Parameter Index (SPI). This could be indicative of malicious activity, such as data tampering or unauthorized network access. The event should be investigated to ensure the integrity and security of the communication.

4976.summary: During Main Mode negotiation, IPsec received an invalid negotiation packet.
4976.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4976.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that during the Main Mode negotiation in IPsec, an invalid received packet was detected. This could be indicative of a Denial of Service (DoS) attack where an attacker attempts to disrupt communication by sending malformed packets. The presence of an invalid packet suggests potential disruption or disruption attempt on the secure tunnel.

4977.summary: During Quick Mode negotiation, IPsec received an invalid negotiation packet.
4977.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4977.llm_technical_description: The event indicates an invalid negotiation packet during IPsec Quick Mode, which may suggest compromised keys or misconfigurations. This is typically related to secure communication setup issues between devices.

4978.summary: During Extended Mode negotiation, IPsec received an invalid negotiation packet.
4978.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4978.llm_technical_description: An invalid negotiation packet during Extended Mode indicates potential malicious activity attempting to disrupt IPsec communication, which could lead to unauthorized access or service disruption.

4979.summary: IPsec Main Mode and Extended Mode security associations were established.
4979.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4979.llm_technical_description: An event indicating that IPsec Main Mode and Extended Mode security associations were established during the system's logon process.

4980.summary: IPsec Main Mode and Extended Mode security associations were established
4980.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4980.llm_technical_description: The IPsec Main Mode and Extended Mode security associations were established during a user login. This event may indicate the creation of secure tunnels for remote access, which could be legitimate (e.g., VPN connections) or suspicious (e.g., unauthorized or misconfigured).

4981.summary: IPsec Main Mode and Extended Mode security associations were established
4981.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4981.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that IPsec Main Mode and Extended Mode security associations were established during a logon or logoff process. This is typically related to secure network communication, such as VPN connections or encrypted data transfers. The absence of detailed description suggests it may be part of normal user activity or misconfiguration.

4982.summary: IPsec Main Mode and Extended Mode security associations were established
4982.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4982.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that IPsec Main Mode and Extended Mode security associations were established during a logon or logoff process. However, without additional context such as changes in configuration parameters, authentication methods, or association parameters (e.g., encryption strength), it is not possible to definitively assess whether this activity is malicious.

4983.summary: An IPsec Extended Mode negotiation failed
4983.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4983.llm_technical_description: An IPsec Extended Mode negotiation failure indicates a potential issue in establishing secure communication channels using VPNs or secure tunnels. This could be due to misconfigured certificates, outdated keys, or network misconfigurations.

4984.summary: An IPsec Extended Mode negotiation failed
4984.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
4984.llm_technical_description: An IPsec Extended Mode negotiation failed during a logon/Logoff event. This could indicate an issue in network security configuration or potential unauthorized access attempts via VPNs.

4985.summary: The state of a transaction has changed
4985.description: The state of a transaction has changed.
4985.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022

4985.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that the state of a transaction has changed within a file system. This could involve actions such as opening, closing, or modifying files. While transactions are typically normal operations, an unexpected change might indicate malicious activity like unauthorized access or a potential security breach.

5024.summary: The Windows Firewall Service has started successfully
5024.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5024.llm_technical_description: The Windows Firewall Service has started successfully, indicating normal system operation. No specific issues or signs of malicious activity are present based on this event alone.

5025.summary: The Windows Firewall Service has been stopped
5025.description: This event is produced when the Windows Firewall Service (MpsSvc)is stopped via the Services MMC.
5025.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5025.llm_technical_description: The Windows Firewall Service has been stopped. This indicates that the Windows Defender Firewall (MpsSvc) has been terminated, which can occur due to an attack on the system or misconfiguration attempts by malicious actors attempting to access sensitive services.

5027.summary: The Windows Firewall Service was unable to retrieve the security policy from the local storage
5027.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5027.llm_technical_description: The Windows Firewall Service encountered difficulty retrieving a security policy from local storage. This could indicate potential tampering with system policies such as Windows Defender or User Accounts Control, which are critical for maintaining system integrity and user permissions.

5028.summary: The Windows Firewall Service was unable to parse the new security policy.
5028.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5028.llm_technical_description: The Windows Firewall Service encountered an error while attempting to parse a new security policy, which could indicate a configuration issue or potential malicious activity aimed at disrupting normal operations.

5029.summary: The Windows Firewall Service failed to initialize the driver
5029.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5029.llm_technical_description: The Windows Firewall Service failed to initialize a driver, which could lead to network connectivity issues and applications failing to start properly.

5030.summary: The Windows Firewall Service failed to start
5030.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5030.llm_technical_description: The Windows Firewall Service failed to start, which can indicate system misconfiguration or compromise by an attacker.

5031.summary: The Windows Firewall Service blocked an application from accepting incoming connections on the network.
5031.description:
It's strange that this event refers to "Windows Firewall Service" when it is supposed to be a Filtering Platform Connection event. Windows Firewall is built on top of the Windows Filtering Platform. Perhaps it's because there is not Windows Firewall subcategory for connection type events.

At any rate as the description says, Windows Firewall prevented an application from accepting incoming connections due to absence of an appropriate Exception in the current profile's policy.
5031.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5031.llm_technical_description: The Windows Firewall Service blocked an application from accepting incoming connections due to a lack of appropriate policy exceptions configured in the current security profile. This could indicate intentional access control measures or potential misconfigurations that may require review.

5032.summary: Windows Firewall was unable to notify the user that it blocked an application from accepting incoming connections on the network
5032.description: This event seems to be logged as a normal course of operation if you have Windows Firewall configured not to provide end-user notifications.
5032.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5032.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that Windows Firewall has encountered an application block that cannot be notified to the user due to its configuration settings. This is expected behavior if Windows Firewall is configured not to provide end-user notifications.

5033.summary: The Windows Firewall Driver has started successfully
5033.description: The Windows Firewall driver is the the "callout" component of Windows Firewall that works with the Windows Filtering Platform.
5033.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5033.llm_technical_description: The Windows Firewall Driver has started successfully as expected. This indicates normal operation of the system's firewall configuration, which is essential for maintaining network security and filtering out malicious traffic appropriately.

5034.summary: The Windows Firewall Driver has been stopped
5034.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5034.llm_technical_description: The Windows Firewall Driver has been stopped as part of a scheduled maintenance or system-wide deployment. This event occurs in the System > Other System Events category, which includes various system activities not covered by more specific categories. The stoppage could be due to legitimate reasons such as updates or installations but may also indicate potential malicious activity if occurring at an unusual time or without context.

5035.summary: The Windows Firewall Driver failed to start
5035.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5035.llm_technical_description: The Windows Firewall Driver failed to start, which may indicate a misconfiguration or potential attacker exploitation. This failure could allow unauthorized access attempts, as the Firewall is designed to block malicious activities.

5037.summary: The Windows Firewall Driver detected critical runtime error. Terminating
5037.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5037.llm_technical_description: The Windows Firewall Driver detected a critical runtime error during operation. This event suggests a potential issue with system configuration or integrity, as critical errors often indicate significant problems that could affect system stability or security. The detection of such an error should be carefully investigated to ensure there are no vulnerabilities exploited by attackers.

5038.summary: Code integrity determined that the image hash of a file is not valid
5038.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5038.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that code integrity checks have failed on a file's image hash, which is used to verify data integrity. This could suggest unauthorized modification or tampering of system files, potentially leading to compromised system security.

5039.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5039.llm_technical_description: A registry key was virtualized. Virtualization of a registry key can provide an attacker with isolated execution environments for malicious code, potentially allowing persistence or bypassing system defenses. The fact that this occurred suggests possible attempts to exploit the isolation provided by virtualization for malicious purposes.

5040.summary: A change has been made to IPsec settings. An Authentication Set was added.
5040.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5040.llm_technical_description: The event indicates a change in IPsec settings, specifically the addition of an Authentication Set. This could imply unauthorized modification of network security configurations which might indicate a potential attempt to bypass or alter security measures.

5041.summary: A change has been made to IPsec settings. An Authentication Set was modified
5041.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5041.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that an IPsec Authentication Set has been modified. While this is a common activity in network environments, it could also be a sign of unauthorized configuration changes or potential security compromise if the change affects critical security parameters.

5042.summary: A change has been made to IPsec settings. An Authentication Set was deleted
5042.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5042.llm_technical_description: The event ID 5042 involves the deletion of an Authentication Set within the IPsec settings on a Windows system. This indicates an intentional modification to network security configurations, potentially aimed at removing a configured security feature that could be associated with unauthorized access or data exposure.

5043.summary: A change has been made to IPsec settings. A Connection Security Rule was added
5043.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5043.llm_technical_description: The event involves the addition of a Connection Security Rule (CSR) in IPsec settings, which could indicate an attempt to control network traffic or gain unauthorized access. The change might be suspicious as attackers often adjust configurations to misdirect defenders or target critical services.

5044.summary: A change has been made to IPsec settings. A Connection Security Rule was modified
5044.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5044.llm_technical_description: The event involves modifying an IPsec connection security rule, which is part of network traffic control. This could be related to network security configurations aimed at improving confidentiality, integrity, or availability.

5045.summary: A change has been made to IPsec settings. A Connection Security Rule was deleted
5045.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5045.llm_technical_description: An IPsec rule was deleted. While this could indicate configuration changes or intentional modifications by a user, without specific context such as an associated action (e.g., encryption tunnel creation), it's hard to determine malicious intent.

5046.summary: A change has been made to IPsec settings. A Crypto Set was added
5046.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5046.llm_technical_description: The event involves modifying IPsec settings by adding a Crypto Set. This could indicate legitimate network security configurations or potential malicious activities such as unauthorized access attempts or setup of backdoor mechanisms.

5047.summary: A change has been made to IPsec settings. A Crypto Set was modified
5047.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5047.llm_technical_description: An unspecified change has been made to IPsec settings. While the exact modification is unclear, changes in network security configurations could indicate potential vulnerabilities or unauthorized modifications. Without additional context, such as whether specific Crypto Sets have been altered before, this event alone may not yet pose a direct threat.

5048.summary: A change has been made to IPsec settings. A Crypto Set was deleted
5048.description: This is a normal event generated by Windows Firewall rule processing. Microsoft says "This is a normal condition. No further action is required.".
5048.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5048.llm_technical_description: The event involves the deletion of a Crypto Set in IPsec settings by Windows Firewall rules as part of normal configuration processing.

5049.summary: An IPsec Security Association was deleted
5049.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5049.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that an IPsec Security Association (SA) was deleted, which could imply unauthorized access or misconfiguration. Without additional context such as the time of deletion and associated activities, it's difficult to determine if this is a legitimate action or indicative of malicious behavior.

5050.summary: An attempt to programmatically disable the Windows Firewall using a call to INetFwProfile.FirewallEnabled(FALSE
5050.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5050.llm_technical_description: An attempt was made to programmatically disable the Windows Firewall by calling INetFwProfile.FirewallEnabled(FALSE). This indicates an attempt to remove firewall restrictions or harden system defenses.

5051.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5051.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a file has been virtualized, which typically involves creating a virtual representation of a file to enhance security or facilitate access control. While virtualization is often a legitimate activity, it can also be used maliciously to hide files or execute malicious code.

5056.summary: A cryptographic self test was performed
5056.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5056.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that a cryptographic self-test was performed at the system level during the specified time frame. The test verifies the integrity of cryptographic modules, ensuring they function correctly without vulnerabilities. While this is typically done to maintain system security, it may be bypassed if the system detects unauthorized changes or exploits potential issues.

5057.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5057.llm_technical_description: The event indicates a failure in a cryptographic primitive operation, which could be an attack on protected data such as keys in Windows PE/UEFI boot sectors. However, without specific details from Sigma rules, the exact nature and implications remain unclear.

5071.summary: Key access denied by Microsoft key distribution service
5071.description: This event is new to Server 2012. It does not appear in earlier versions.
5071.operating_systems: Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5071.llm_technical_description: The event indicates a denial of key access by the Microsoft Key Distribution Service (KDS), which is part of Windows Server 2012. KDS manages client software keys and public keys for updates and services. A denied access could suggest unauthorized attempts to retrieve keys, potentially indicating misconfiguration or malicious activity if accompanied by other signs.

5120.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5120.llm_technical_description: The 'OCSP Responder Service Started' event indicates that a service is initiating an authentication process for remote desktop or terminal access. This could be due to legitimate user attempts to connect from outside the network, potentially indicating unauthorized access if not properly authenticated.

5121.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5121.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that an OCSP Responder Service has been stopped. OCSP services are typically used for managing Windows security features such as Group Policy Objects and User Access Control (UAC). If these services are stopped without proper reloads, it may indicate unauthorized or compromised environment changes, potentially allowing attackers to exploit vulnerabilities or bypass system controls.

5122.summary: A Configuration entry changed in the OCSP Responder Service
5122.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5122.llm_technical_description: An unspecified configuration change was detected in the OCSP Responder Service. This could indicate normal system operation or potential malicious activity such as bypassing security measures.

5123.summary: A configuration entry changed in the OCSP Responder Service
5123.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5123.llm_technical_description: The event indicates a configuration change in the OCSP Responder Service. This could be indicative of unauthorized system changes or misconfigurations that might lead to security vulnerabilities.

5124.summary: A security setting was updated on OCSP Responder Service
5124.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5124.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a security setting was updated on the OCSP Responder Service, which is related to Outlook's OCSP trust mechanism used by Microsoft for secure email communication. The update could be due to Microsoft applying a patch or an organizational update. Without specific details about what changed, it's challenging to assess if this activity is malicious or legitimate.

5125.summary: A request was submitted to OCSP Responder Service
5125.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5125.llm_technical_description: A request was made to the OCSP Responder Service, which is typically used for handling Outlook SPF records. Without specific context from the summary, subcategory, or description, it's unclear if this interaction is related to legitimate business processes or potential malicious activity.

5126.summary: Signing Certificate was automatically updated by the OCSP Responder Service
5126.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5126.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that the system automatically updated its digital certificate (OCSP Responder Service), which is a normal procedure for maintaining SSL/TLS security. However, without detailed Sigma rule information, it's unclear if this update could have been malicious or if there was tampering involved. This event could imply potential risks if the update process was compromised by an attacker.

5127.summary: The OCSP Revocation Provider successfully updated the revocation information
5127.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5127.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that an OCSP Revocation Provider has successfully updated its revocation information. OCSP providers are responsible for managing certificate revocation lists (CRLs) used by browsers to check if certificates have been revoked. This update could be a routine maintenance operation, but it might also reflect changes in known malicious activities or legitimate updates.

513.description:
Despite the documentation's wording, "Windows NT is shutting down",neither Windows 2000 nor Windows NT logs event 513. Windows Server 2003 does log this event.

Event 513 is an important security event: Any operating system is defenseless while it's down. You should document system shutdowns in a written log that monitors who shut down which system and for how long. You can determine the duration of a system shutdown by checking for a previousevent 512 for the system. If no event 512 appears, look for the most recent event 517.
513.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
513.llm_technical_description: Windows System Event 513 indicates a system shutdown, which is a critical security event. This event is specific to Windows Server 2003 and newer versions but does not appear in older Windows versions like Windows 2000 or Windows NT. A system shutdown can indicate normal operations (e.g., scheduled tasks, backups) or potential unauthorized activity. SOC analysts should document the shutdowns and assess if they are preceded by other events such as Event 512 (system started) and Event 517 (previous shutdown).

5136.summary: A directory service object was modified
5136.description:
This event documents modifications to AD objects, identifying the object, user, attribute modified, thenew value of the attribute if applicableand the operation performed. 

Of course this eventwill only beloggedwhen the object's audit policy has auditing enabled for the properties or actions involved and for the user performing the action or a group to which the user belongs.

This event is not logged for creation, deletion, undeletion or moves of AD objects. See event IDs 5137, 5138, 5139, 5141.

For users, groups and computers there are specific events for tracking most modifications. See "User account management", etc.

514.summary: An authentication package has been loaded by the Local Security Authority
514.description:
Event 514 is logged once at startup for each authentication package on the system. 

An authentication package is a DLL that encapsulates a given form of authentication, such as NTLM or Kerberos. The Local Security Authority calls into the appropriate authentication package during the logon process to find out if the user is authentic. 

Although a third party can develop an authentication package, few do so. The standard packages that come with Windows Server 2003 are as follows:
514.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
514.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that an Authentication Package (AP) has been loaded by the Local Security Authority (LSA). Authentication Packages are typically used during user logon to authenticate against a trusted entity such as Active Directory or Windows Server. The fact that this occurs at startup suggests it might be a normal setup activity, but if it's unexpected or accompanied by other anomalies, it could indicate potential misconfiguration or security threats.

5140.summary: A network share object was accessed
5140.description: Windows logs this event the first time you access a given network share during a given logon session. Be aware that Windows Server 2008 logs off network logon sessions even sooner than past versions of Windows. When a user closes all open files on a server it seems to immediatelly log him off.

The occurrence of such an event could be a sign of legitimate administrative work, but if it happens frequently from unauthorized users or in a manner that suggests malicious intent (e.g., attempting to delete sensitive data or exfiltrate information), it may warrant further investigation.

For users, groups and computers there are specific events for tracking deletion. See "User account management", etc.

5141.llm_technical_description: The event documents the deletion of Active Directory (AD) objects by a user or group. This occurs when the parent's audit policy allows such deletions and includes information about what was deleted and who performed the action.

5142.summary: A network share object was added.
5142.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5142.llm_technical_description: A network share object was added. This is typically done for sharing files with team members or deploying software, though unauthorized additions from unexpected sources may indicate malicious intent.

5143.summary: A network share object was modified
5143.description: A network share object was modified.
5143.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022

5143.llm_technical_description: The network share object was modified, which may indicate unauthorized access or permission changes. This could be a sign of malicious activity such as deleting files, changing sensitive data, or gaining unauthorized control over resources.

5144.summary: A network share object was deleted.
5144.description: A network share object was deleted.
5144.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5144.llm_technical_description: The deletion of a network share object typically pertains to actions taken by authorized users, often developers or testers accessing files across a network. While this is generally benign, repeated deletions from unexpected sources without legitimate cause could indicate unauthorized access attempts.

5145.summary: A network share object was checked to see whether client can be granted desired access
5145.description: A network share object was checked to see whether client can be granted desired access
5145.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022

These activities may indicate a threat actor aiming to exploit legitimate user accounts or compromise sensitive data.

5146.summary: The Windows Filtering Platform has blocked a packet
5146.description: This event is new to Server 2012. It does not appear in earlier versions.
5146.operating_systems: Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5146.llm_technical_description: The Windows Filtering Platform has blocked a network packet as part of its system-wide filtering mechanism designed for traffic control. This feature is typically configured by organizations to manage network access, such as outbound NAT or content filtering. The event occurring in Server 2012 indicates that the filtering rules have been applied, potentially blocking legitimate traffic if misconfigured.

5147.summary: A more restrictive Windows Filtering Platform filter has blocked a packet
5147.description: This event is new to Server 2012. It does not appear in earlier versions.
5147.operating_systems: Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5147.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a more restrictive Windows Filtering Platform filter has blocked a packet. This could be due to legitimate policy enforcement or malicious activity attempting to bypass security measures. The fact that this is new to Server 2012 suggests it might be an attempt to exploit known vulnerabilities in older versions.

5148.summary: The Windows Filtering Platform has detected a DoS attack and entered a defensive mode; packets associated with this attack will be discarded.
5148.description: The Windows Filtering Platform has detected a DoS attack and entered a defensive mode; packets associated with this attack will be discarded.
5148.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5148.llm_technical_description: The Windows Filtering Platform has detected a DoS attack and entered defensive mode; packets associated with this attack will be discarded.

5149.summary: The DoS attack has subsided and normal processing is being resumed.
5149.description: The DoS attack has subsided and normal processing is being resumed.
5149.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5149.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a DoS (Distributed Denial of Service) attack has been resolved, and normal processing is being resumed. This suggests that any unauthorized access or malicious activity related to the attack has been mitigated. However, without specific details about what was accessed or how it was accessed, no immediate security concerns can be identified. The event reflects a positive outcome in terms of system resilience.

515.summary: A trusted logon process has registered with the Local Security Authority
515.description:
An occurrence of event 515 is logged at startup and occasionally afterwards for each logon process on the system. 

A logon process is a trusted part of the operating system and handles the overall logon function for different logon methods including incoming RAS connections, RunAs, interactive logons initiated by CtrlAltDel, and network logons (as in drive mappings). 

Because logon processes are such trusted functions, a rogue logon process would be a devastating security breach--but an improbable one, given the effort and skill required. 

Standard logon process for Windows Server 2003:
515.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
515.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a trusted logon process has registered with the Local Security Authority (LSA), which is essential for authenticating users and ensuring system integrity. This activity occurs at startup and periodically after logons, which is normal unless there are known patterns of deviation from expected behavior.

5150.summary: The Windows Filtering Platform has blocked a packet.
5150.description: The Windows Filtering Platform has blocked a packet.
5150.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5150.llm_technical_description: The Windows Filtering Platform has detected a potential attempt to transmit sensitive or controlled information. The event indicates that a packet was blocked by the platform, which could be due to legitimate security measures (e.g., command-line arguments) or an anomaly that requires further investigation.

5151.summary: A more restrictive Windows Filtering Platform filter has blocked a packet.
5151.description: A more restrictive Windows Filtering Platform filter has blocked a packet.
5151.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5151.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a more restrictive Windows Filtering Platform filter has blocked a packet, which may suggest legitimate traffic being unnecessarily restricted or an attempt to mask IP addresses.

5152.summary: The Windows Filtering Platform blocked a packet
5152.description:
This event logs all the particulars about a blocked packet including the filter that caused the block.

Application Information:
5152.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5152.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>5152</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>12809</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8010000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-09-22T16:52:37.274367300Z" /> <EventRecordID>321323</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="4" ThreadID="4456" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="ProcessId">4556</Data> <Data Name="Application">\\\\device\\\\harddiskvolume2\\\\documents\\\\listener.exe</Data> <Data Name="Direction">%%14592</Data> <Data Name="SourceAddress">10.0.0.100</Data> <Data Name="SourcePort">49278</Data> <Data Name="DestAddress">10.0.0.10</Data> <Data Name="DestPort">3333</Data> <Data Name="Protocol">6</Data> <Data Name="FilterRTID">0</Data> <Data Name="LayerName">%%14610</Data> <Data Name="LayerRTID">44</Data> </EventData> </Event>
5152.llm_technical_description: The Windows Filtering Platform has blocked a packet based on predefined policies or rules. The event logs the filter used to block the packet and provides details about the incident. This type of event is typically indicative of network traffic control mechanisms, which can be both legitimate for security purposes or potentially malicious if unauthorized access is involved.

5153.summary: A more restrictive Windows Filtering Platform filter has blocked a packet
5153.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5153.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a more restrictive Windows Filtering Platform filter has blocked a packet in the Object Access category. This could imply an attempt to limit legitimate access or block malicious traffic, as WFP is designed to prevent unauthorized network access.

5154.summary: The Windows Filtering Platform has permitted an application or service to listen on a port for incoming connections
5154.description:
This event documents each time WFP allows a program to begin listening on a TCP or UDP port for incoming connections and documents the program, port and filter that allowed it.

The above example is of WFP allowing the DNS Server service to listen on port 53 for DNS queries.

Application Information:
5154.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5154.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>5154</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>12810</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-09-22T02:04:25.757462900Z" /> <EventRecordID>287929</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="4" ThreadID="3968" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="ProcessId">4152</Data> <Data Name="Application">\\\\device\\\\harddiskvolume2\\\\documents\\\\listener.exe</Data> <Data Name="SourceAddress">0.0.0.0</Data> <Data Name="SourcePort">4444</Data> <Data Name="Protocol">6</Data> <Data Name="FilterRTID">0</Data> <Data Name="LayerName">%%14609</Data> <Data Name="LayerRTID">40</Data> </EventData> </Event>
5154.llm_technical_description: The Windows Filtering Platform (WFP) has permitted an application or service to listen on port 53 for incoming DNS queries and responses. This event logs the permission granted by WFP, which is typically normal as part of DNS resolution services.

5155.summary: The Windows Filtering Platform has blocked an application or service from listening on a port for incoming connections
5155.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5155.llm_technical_description: The Windows Filtering Platform has blocked an application or service from listening on a port for incoming connections. This action is typically performed by legitimate applications to optimize performance or enforce security policies. However, malicious actors may attempt to exploit such blocks if they are used inappropriately.

5156.summary: The Windows Filtering Platform has allowed a connection
5156.description:
This event documents each time WFP allows a program to connect to another process (on the same or a remote computer) on a TCP or UDP port.

The above example is of WFP allowing the DNS Server service to connect tothe DNS client on the same computer.

Application Information:
5156.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5156.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>5156</EventID> <Version>1</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>12810</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-09-22T05:24:22.622090200Z" /> <EventRecordID>308129</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="4" ThreadID="3712" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="ProcessID">4556</Data> <Data Name="Application">\\\\device\\\\harddiskvolume2\\\\documents\\\\listener.exe</Data> <Data Name="Direction">%%14592</Data> <Data Name="SourceAddress">10.0.0.10</Data> <Data Name="SourcePort">3333</Data> <Data Name="DestAddress">10.0.0.100</Data> <Data Name="DestPort">49278</Data> <Data Name="Protocol">6</Data> <Data Name="FilterRTID">70201</Data> <Data Name="LayerName">%%14610</Data> <Data Name="LayerRTID">44</Data> <Data Name="RemoteUserID">S-1-0-0</Data> <Data Name="RemoteMachineID">S-1-0-0</Data> </EventData> </Event>
5156.llm_technical_description: The Windows Filtering Platform (WFP) has allowed a connection from the source machine to a remote or local destination on a TCP or UDP port. This event is detected by Sigma as an inbound connection on ports 5985-5986, which could indicate potential malicious activity such as basic PowerShell Remoting (WinRM) usage. The detection rules also check for outbound network activity via the Kerberos default port, which might suggest lateral movement or unauthorized access.

5157.summary: The Windows Filtering Platform has blocked a connection
5157.description:
This event documents each time WFP allows a program to connect to another process (on the same or a remote computer) on a TCP or UDP port.

The above example is of WFP allowing the DNS Server service to connect tothe DNS client on the same computer.
5157.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
