5157.llm_technical_description: The Windows Filtering Platform has blocked a connection between the DNS Server service and another process on the same computer, which is intended behavior to allow necessary connections for security operations. This event occurs when WFP filters are applied to prevent EDR agents from reporting security events.

5158.summary: The Windows Filtering Platform has permitted a bind to a local port
5158.description:
This event is logged every time a client or server application binds to a port. Binding is the first step in TCP/UDP communications. For server applications, subsequent to this event you will see 5154 or 5031when the server attempts to begin listening on the port. 

The example above is the system binding to TCP port 3389 for Remote Desktop connections. 

Application Information:
5158.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5158.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>5158</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>12810</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-09-22T05:24:03.376171200Z" /> <EventRecordID>308122</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="4" ThreadID="3712" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="ProcessId">4556</Data> <Data Name="Application">\\\\device\\\\harddiskvolume2\\\\documents\\\\listener.exe</Data> <Data Name="SourceAddress">0.0.0.0</Data> <Data Name="SourcePort">3333</Data> <Data Name="Protocol">6</Data> <Data Name="FilterRTID">0</Data> <Data Name="LayerName">%%14608</Data> <Data Name="LayerRTID">36</Data> </EventData> </Event>
5158.llm_technical_description: The Windows Filtering Platform has permitted a bind to a local port, which typically occurs when an application establishes communication endpoints. This event is logged for every client or server binding, and subsequent events like 5154 or 5031 may follow if the server begins listening on the port. The example provided involves binding to TCP port 3389 for Remote Desktop connections.

5159.summary: The Windows Filtering Platform has blocked a bind to a local port
5159.description:
This event is logged every timeWFP prevents aclient or server application binds to a port. Binding is the first step in TCP or UDP communications.

Application Information:
5159.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5159.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>5159</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>12810</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8010000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2019-04-19T07:36:55.955388300Z" /> <EventRecordID>44097</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="4" ThreadID="6480" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="ProcessId">7924</Data> <Data Name="Application">\\device\\harddiskvolume2\\users\\test\\desktop\ etcat\ c.exe</Data> <Data Name="SourceAddress">0.0.0.0</Data> <Data Name="SourcePort">5555</Data> <Data Name="Protocol">6</Data> <Data Name="FilterRTID">84614</Data> <Data Name="LayerName">%%14608</Data> <Data Name="LayerRTID">36</Data> </EventData> </Event>
5159.llm_technical_description: The Windows Filtering Platform (WFP) has blocked a bind attempt to a local port. This event occurs when WFP prevents a client or server application from binding to a port, which is typically the first step in establishing TCP or UDP communication. While this is generally a security measure to prevent unauthorized access, the frequency or manner of such blocks could indicate potential malicious activity if there are known false positives or if it's part of an attacker's attempt to gain control over network services.

516.summary: Internal resources allocated for the queuing of audit messages have been exhausted, leading to the loss of some audits
516.description: Event 516 indicates that an extremely high period of activity prevented Windows from logging %1 number of security events.
516.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
516.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that during an extremely high period of activity, Windows' internal resources for logging audit messages were exhausted, resulting in the loss of some security events. This could imply a potential denial-of-service (DoS) attack or excessive system resource consumption, which might target legitimate logging processes.

5168.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5168.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>5168</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>12808</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8010000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-09-18T17:53:40.294859800Z" /> <EventRecordID>268946</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="4" ThreadID="80" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0xd0cd4</Data> <Data Name="SpnName">N/A</Data> <Data Name="ErrorCode">0xc0000022</Data> <Data Name="ServerNames">CONTOSO;contoso.local;DC01.contoso.local;DC01;LocalHost;</Data> <Data Name="ConfiguredNames">N/A</Data> <Data Name="IpAddresses">127.0.0.1;::1;10.0.0.10;;fe80::31ea:6c3c:f40d:1973;;fe80::5efe:10.0.0.10;</Data> </EventData> </Event>
5168.llm_technical_description: The SMB/SMB2 Spn check failure indicates a potential issue with file share sessions. This occurs when an SMB resource is discovered but the Session Joiner Point (SJP) fails to establish a secure connection, prompting the client to attempt manual session establishment.

5169.summary: A directory service object was modified
5169.operating_systems: Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5169.llm_technical_description: A modification was made to a directory service object, which could indicate unauthorized or malicious activity such as permission changes or sensitive data access.

517.description:
Event 517 is logged whenever the Security log is cleared, REGARDLESS of the status of the Audit System Events audit policy. 

The Primary User Name and Client User Name fields will identify the user who cleared the log. Primary User Name will correspond to the system, and Client user name will indicate the user who cleared the log.
517.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
517.llm_technical_description: The audit log was cleared on system-level Security logs without regard to the Audit System Events policy, indicating that system users can clear Security Logs regardless of any configured Audit policies.

5170.summary: A directory service object was modified during a background cleanup task
5170.description: We have not yet seen this event
5170.operating_systems: Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5170.llm_technical_description: A directory service object was modified during a background cleanup task, which may indicate unauthorized or malicious activity. This event suggests potential system file corruption or configuration changes intended for attackers rather than legitimate users.

518.summary: A notification package has been loaded by the Security Account Manager
518.description: An occurrence of Event 518 is logged for each notification package on the system.
518.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
518.llm_technical_description: The notification package has been loaded by the Security Account Manager, logged for each occurrence on the system. This event is typically benign but could indicate malicious activity if unexpected or suspicious behavior is observed.

519.summary: A process is using an invalid local procedure call (LPC) port
519.description: Event 519 appears in Microsoft documenation but hasn't been confirmed through testing.
519.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a process is attempting to use an invalid local procedure call (LPC) port. This type of activity can sometimes be indicative of unauthorized or malicious behavior, such as attempts to exploit system vulnerabilities or gain unauthorized access. The fact that the event appears in Microsoft documentation but has not been confirmed through testing suggests it may be legitimate or could indicate a potential security concern.

520.description: Process name, explained below, indicates how the time waschanged.
520.llm_technical_description: The system time was changed, which could be part of a legitimate operation such as advancing the clock for daylight saving or manually setting it. However, if performed programmatically, this might indicate potential attacker activity aiming to bypass security measures or cause confusion during network outages.

521.summary: Unable to log events to security log
521.description: This event is logged if Windows was unable to write events to the Security event log.
521.llm_technical_description: The inability to log events to the Security event log in Windows suggests that there may be an issue with writing events to this critical system component. This could be due to hardware failure (e.g., a disk drive issue) or misconfiguration.

528.description: Event 528 is logged whenever an account logs on to the local computer, except for in the event of network logons (see event 540). Event 528 is logged whether the account used for logon is a local SAM account or a domain account.
528.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
528.llm_technical_description: This event indicates a successful logon attempt on the local computer system. It is logged for both SAM accounts and domain accounts but not when using network logons (event 540). High volume of these events could indicate normal user activity, while unusual patterns may suggest potential security issues such as unauthorized access attempts or misconfigurations.

529.summary: Logon Failure - Unknown user name or bad password
529.description: Event 529 is logged on the workstation or server where the user failed to log on.
529.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
529.llm_technical_description: A logon failure occurred where the user either entered an incorrect username or provided a wrong password. This could indicate user error or unauthorized access attempts.

530.summary: Logon Failure - Account logon time restriction violation
530.description:
The logon failed because the user attempted to log on outside the account's hour or day of week restrictions. To determine if the user was present at this computer or elsewhere on the network, seethe LogonTypes chart in event 528. 

Event 530 is logged on the workstation or server where the user failed to log on. Event 530 is logged on a domain controller only when a user fails to log on to the domain controller itself (such as at the console or through failure to connect to a shared folder). On workstations and servers, event 530 will be generated only by an attempt to log on with a domain account; local accounts do not offer time restrictions. 

To identify the source of network logon failures, check the Workstation Name and Source Network Address fields. 

Logon Process and Authentication Package will vary according to the type of logon and authentication protocol used.
530.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
530.llm_technical_description: This event indicates a user attempted to logon outside their defined time restrictions, which could suggest unauthorized access attempts from another network location or potentially brute-force password attempts.

531.description:
Event 531 is logged on the workstation or server where the user failed to log on. To determine if the user was present at this computer or elsewhere on the network, see theLogon Typeschart in 528. Event 531 is logged on a domain controller only when a user fails to log on to the domain controller itself (such as at the console or through failure to connect to a shared folder). On workstations and servers, this event can be generated by an attempt to log on with a domain or local SAM account. In the latter case, there will be a corresponding failure event from the Account Logon category. 

To identify the source of network logon failures, check the Workstation Name and Source Network Address fields. 

Logon Process and Authentication Package will vary according to the type of logon and authentication protocol used.
531.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
531.llm_technical_description: The Logon Failure - Account currently disabled event indicates that a user has failed to log in, with the account marked as disabled. This could result from the user not being present on-premises or lacking proper credentials. Attackers may attempt to exploit this by using outdated passwords, stolen credentials, or brute-force attacks.

532.summary: Logon Failure - The specified user account has expired
532.description:
Do not confuse event 532 with password expiration. 

Event 532 is logged on the workstation or server where the user failed to log on. To determine if the user was present at this computer or elsewhere on the network, see the Logon Types chartin event 528. Event 532 is logged on a domain controller only when a user fails to log on to the domain controller itself (such as at the console or through failure to connect to a shared folder). On workstations and servers, this event will be generated only by an attempt to log on with a domain account; local accounts do not offer account expiration. 

To identify the source of network logon failures, check the Workstation Name and Source Network Address fields. 

Logon Process and Authentication Package will vary according to the type of logon and authentication protocol used. 

Logon Type: See chart in event 528.
532.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
532.llm_technical_description: The Logon Failure - The specified user account has expired event indicates that an attempt was made to log in with a user account that has expired. This could be due to the account being invalidated by a legitimate reason such as reaching its expiration date or due to malicious activity like unauthorized login attempts. The event logs where the failure occurred whether on a workstation, server, or domain controller. It is important to investigate this event for potential unauthorized access attempts.

533.summary: Logon Failure - User not allowed to logon at this computer
533.description:
Event 533 is logged on the workstation or server where the user failed to logon. To determine if the user was present at this computer or elsewhere on the network, see the Logon Types chart in event 528. This event is logged on domain controllers only when a user fails to log on to the domain controller itself (such as at the console or through failure to connect to a shared folder). On workstations and servers, this event will be generated only by an attempt to log on with a domain account; local accounts do not offer workstation logons. 

To identify the source of network logon failures, check the Workstation Name and Source Network Address fields. 

Logon Process and Authentication Package will vary according to the type of logon and authentication protocol used. 

Logon Type: See the chart in event 528.
533.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
533.llm_technical_description: The Logon Failure event (ID 533) indicates that a user attempted to log in but was denied access. This could be due to unauthorized access attempts or misconfigurations. The event occurs specifically when users use domain accounts, not local ones.

534.summary: Logon Failure - The user has not been granted the requested logon type at this machine
534.description:
Event 534 is logged on the workstation or server where the user failed to logon. To determine if the user was present at this computer or elsewhere on the network, see theLogon Types chart in event 528. Event 534 is logged on domain controllers only when a user fails to log on to the domain controller itself (such as at the console or through failure to connect to a shared folder). On workstations and servers, this event could be generated by an attempt to log on with a domain or local SAM account. In the latter case, there will be a corresponding failure event from the Account Logon category. 

To identify the source of network logon failures, check the Workstation Name and Source Network Address fields. 

Logon Process and Authentication Package will vary according to the type of logon and authentication protocol used.
534.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
534.llm_technical_description: This event indicates a failed attempt to log in, which could be due to unauthorized access or other malicious activities such as brute-force attacks. The failure could occur from an unexpected source, indicating potential threats.

535.summary: Logon Failure - The specified account's password has expired
535.description:
Event 535 is logged on the workstation or server where the user failed to logon. To determine if the user was present at this computer or elsewhere on the network, see theLogon Types chart in event 528. Event 535 is logged on domain controllers only when a user fails to log on to the domain controller itself (such as at the console or through failure to connect to a shared folder). On workstations and servers, event 535 could be generated by a an attempt to log on with a domain or local SAM account. In the latter case, there will be a corresponding failure event from the Account Logon category. 

To identify the source of network logon failures, check the Workstation Name and Source Network Address fields. 

Logon Process and Authentication Package will vary according to the type of logon and authentication protocol used.
535.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
535.llm_technical_description: This event indicates a failed attempt to log in because the account password has expired. This is a sign of unauthorized access attempts, which could suggest potential security vulnerabilities such as weak passwords or brute-force attacks. The frequency and distribution of these events may indicate compromised user credentials.

536.summary: Logon Failure - The NetLogon component is not active
536.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
536.llm_technical_description: The event 'Logon Failure - The NetLogon component is not active' indicates a potential issue with user authentication mechanisms. If observed frequently without corresponding login attempts, it could suggest unauthorized access attempts or service misconfigurations.

537.summary: Logon failure - The logon attempt failed for other reasons.
537.description: Thanks toIsaac at Prism Microsystems (EventTracker) for this explanation:
537.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
537.llm_technical_description: A logon attempt failed for other reasons. This could indicate unauthorized access or a misconfiguration. The implications depend on the context, such as whether there were subsequent unauthorized actions.

5376.summary: Credential Manager credentials were backed up
5376.description: Credential Manager is the stored passwords feature in Windows that allows Windows to remember passwords for websites, shared folders, VPNs, etc. From Control Panel\User Accounts\Manage your network passwords you can backup these stored credentials and/or restore them. This event is logged when you back them up.
5376.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5376.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that Credential Manager credentials have been backed up. This action is typically performed by users to restore forgotten credentials or after a security incident. From a security perspective, unauthorized backups could indicate potential compromise of user accounts. The event should be monitored for unusual patterns as they might signal unauthorized access attempts.

5377.summary: Credential Manager credentials were restored from a backup
5377.description: Credential Manager is the stored passwords feature in Windows that allows Windows to remember passwords for websites, shared folders, VPNs, etc. From Control Panel\User Accounts\Manage your network passwords you can backup these stored credentials and/or restore them. This event is logged when you restore them.
5377.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5377.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that Credential Manager credentials were restored from a backup, which can potentially expose sensitive information if not properly managed. The restoration process may be normal user activity but can also be exploited by attackers to bypass security measures or gain unauthorized access.

5378.summary: The requested credentials delegation was disallowed by policy
5378.description: This event is probably connected with the "Account is trusted for delegation" account option needed for the application server account of some applications that impersonate the client user before accessing resources on their behalf as well as the related account option, "Account is sensitive and cannot be delegated".
5378.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5378.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>5378</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>12551</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8010000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-11-11T03:23:48.502346900Z" /> <EventRecordID>1198733</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="500" ThreadID="4308" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x2b1e04</Data> <Data Name="Package">CREDSSP</Data> <Data Name="UserUPN">dadmin@contoso</Data> <Data Name="TargetServer">WSMAN/dc01.contoso.local</Data> <Data Name="CredType">%%8098</Data> </EventData> </Event>
5378.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that the 'Account is trusted for delegation' setting was attempted but disallowed due to policy enforcement. This could imply unauthorized access attempts or impersonation of another user's account to gain access to sensitive resources, potentially indicating malicious activity such as phishing attacks or misconfigured system permissions.

5379.description: This is event is new in Windows Server 2019.This event occurs when a user performs a read operation on stored credentials in Credential Manager.
5379.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that credentials were read from Credential Manager. This is a normal system operation when users access stored credentials. However, if this read operation is linked to extracting password-protected ZIP files with suspicious filenames (e.g., 'invoice', 'new order'), it may indicate unauthorized access or malicious activity such as phishing or malware attempts.

538.description:
Ostensibly, event 538 is logged whenever a user logs off, whether from a network connection, interactive logon, or otherlogon type. (See event 528 for a chart of logon types)However, this event is not dependably logged, for a variety of reasons. In a nutshell, there is no way to reliably track user logoff events in the Windows environment. 

Note: Beginning with Windows Server 2003, logoffs of logon type 2 sessions are logged with event 551. 

For network connections (such as to a file server), it will appear that users log on and off many times a day. This phenomenon is caused by the way the Server service terminates idle connections. 

If a user turns off his/her computer, Windows does not have an opportunity to log the logoff event until the system restarts. Therefore, some logoff events are logged much later than the time at which they actually occur. 

Sometimes Windows simply doesn't log event 538. 

Microsoft's comments: 

This event does not necessarily indicate the time that a user has stopped using a system. For example, if the computer is shut down or loses network connectivity it may not record a logoff event at all.
538.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
538.llm_technical_description: This event logs when a user attempts to log off from their account on Windows. However, due to system limitations, this event is unreliable as it may not consistently track actual logoff events in real-time, especially in cases of network connections or system restarts. This unreliability could indicate potential malicious activities where users attempt to log out without proper evidence, such as lateral movement within a network or silent shutdowns.

5380.description: This event is new in Windows Server 2019.This event occurs when a user finds stored vault credentials.
5380.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that a user has retrieved vaulted credentials from a system where they previously stored them, likely as part of an unauthorized or misconfigured account access. This could be indicative of compromised organizational resources such as Active Directory or Share Point, and may suggest potential unauthorized access attempts.

5381.description: This event is new in Server 2019.This event occurs when a user enumerates stored vault credentials.
5381.llm_technical_description: The system event (ID: 5381) indicates that a user has attempted to enumerate stored vault credentials. This is an unusual activity as users typically do not enumerate vaults unless there is unauthorized access or malicious intent.

5382.description: This event is new in Server 2019. It is very similar to 5381.This event occurs when a user reads a stored vault credential.
5382.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that a user has read a vault credential, which typically occurs when accessing sensitive data using legitimate means such as Group Policy Objects (GPOs) or Windows Key Wrap. The presence of this event alone may not be malicious unless it correlates with unauthorized access to other resources.

539.description:
Do not confuse this with event 644. 

This event is logged on the workstation or server where the user failed to logon. To determine if the user was present at this computer or elsewhere on the network, seeevent 528 for a list of logon types

This event is only logged on domain controllers when a user fails to logon to the DC itself such at the console or through failure to connect to a shared folder. On workstations and servers this event could be generated by a an attempt to logon with a domain or local SAM account. If a local SAM account, there will be a corresponding failure event from the Account Logon category. 

Logon Type: See event 528.

To identify the source of network logon failures check the Workstation Name and Source Network Address fields. 

Logon Process and Authentication Package will vary according to the type of logon and authentication protocol used.
539.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
539.llm_technical_description: This event indicates a user failed to log on to their workstation or server. It could be due to unauthorized access attempts from an external source or an attack vector that has been exploited multiple times before being detected.

540.description: Event 540 gets logged when a user elsewhere on the network connects to a resource (e.g. shared folder) provided by the Server service on this computer. The Logon Type will always be 3 or 8, both of which indicate a network logon.
540.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
540.llm_technical_description: This event indicates a successful network logon with Logon Type 3 or 8, which typically correspond to Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) connections. This could be normal user access from another computer on the network or potentially an attempt by an attacker to gain lateral movement between servers.

5440.summary: The following callout was present when the Windows Filtering Platform Base Filtering Engine started
5440.description: I haven't been able to produce this event. Have you? If so, please start a discussion (see above) and post a sample along with any comments you may have! Don't forget to sanitize any private information
5440.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5440.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that there has been a change in the Windows Filtering Platform Policy Change category. The event is triggered when such a policy update occurs and may relate to changes that could impact user experience or security, as legitimate users are not able to reproduce it.

5441.summary: The following filter was present when the Windows Filtering Platform Base Filtering Engine started
5441.description:
This event is logged for each filter of each WFP provider at startup. For more information on WFP and providers see 5442.

The fields in this event provide all the details about the filter and serves to document the provider's entire policy at the time of startup.
5441.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5441.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that a custom filter named containing 'Custom Outbound Filter' was added during the startup of the Windows Filtering Platform Base Filtering Engine. According to Sigma detection rules, this could be indicative of malicious activity where an attacker is attempting to abuse the Windows Filtering Platform (WFP) by adding filters with hardcoded names related to blocking outbound traffic from EDR agents.

5442.summary: The following provider was present when the Windows Filtering Platform Base Filtering Engine started
5442.description:
This event is logged for each Windows Filtering Platform Provider present when the base engine starts as part of Windows boot up.

The Windows Filtering Platform is a foundation component of Windows that provides an API and base filtering engine upon which other network filtering applications are built including several other Windows networking components and potentially 3rd party applications.

A WFP Provider is a Windows component or 3rd party application that that has built a solution on WFP. The default, built-in providers are:
5442.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5442.llm_technical_description: The event logs the presence of Windows Filtering Platform (WFP) providers during the boot process when the base filtering engine starts. WFP includes essential networking components like Windows Networking and Sharing (WNS). This event helps identify if any unexpected or malicious providers are enabled early in the system startup, which could potentially expose sensitive services.

5443.summary: The following provider context was present when the Windows Filtering Platform Base Filtering Engine started
5443.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5443.llm_technical_description: The Windows Filtering Platform Base Filtering Engine started due to a Policy Change in the category of Filtering Platform Policy Change. This event is typically indicative of an unauthorized or misconfigured system policy change, potentially indicating compromised system settings or configuration that could hide malicious activities.

5444.summary: The following sub-layer was present when the Windows Filtering Platform Base Filtering Engine started
5444.description:
This event is logged for sub-layer of each WFP provider at startup. For more information on WFP and providers see 5442.

A sublayer is a collection of filters assigned to a layer within WFP. For more information on the sub-layer fields of this event see the FWPM_SUBLAYER0structure in MSDN.

This event does not indicate a change - it just documents the providers present at the time of startup.
5444.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5444.llm_technical_description: The event logs a sub-layer of the Windows Filtering Platform (WFP) Base Filtering Engine at startup. It documents the presence of WFP providers without indicating any policy changes or malicious activity.

5446.summary: A Windows Filtering Platform callout has been changed
5446.description:
A WFP callout is aet of functions in a driver used for specialized filtering. Callouts can block, permit, modify and secure network traffic.For more information on WFP and providers see 5442.

This event is logged whenever a callout is added or deleted.
5446.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5446.llm_technical_description: A Windows Filtering Platform (WFP) policy change has been detected. WFP is used to manage network traffic filtering rules on Windows machines. This event occurs when a callout is added or deleted, which can block, permit, modify, or secure network traffic. Potential malicious activity could include unauthorized changes intended to alter network behavior or protect sensitive data.

5447.summary: A Windows Filtering Platform filter has been changed
5447.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5447.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>5447</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13573</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-10-07T23:51:12.191198900Z" /> <EventRecordID>1060216</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="524" ThreadID="3784" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="ProcessId">284</Data> <Data Name="UserSid">S-1-5-19</Data> <Data Name="UserName">NT AUTHORITY\\\\LOCAL SERVICE</Data> <Data Name="ProviderKey">{DECC16CA-3F33-4346-BE1E-8FB4AE0F3D62}</Data> <Data Name="ProviderName">Microsoft Corporation</Data> <Data Name="ChangeType">%%16385</Data> <Data Name="FilterKey">{91334E6D-FFAB-40F1-8C43-5554965C228D}</Data> <Data Name="FilterName">Port Scanning Prevention Filter</Data> <Data Name="FilterType">%%16388</Data> <Data Name="FilterId">100100</Data> <Data Name="LayerKey">{AC4A9833-F69D-4648-B261-6DC84835EF39}</Data> <Data Name="LayerName">Inbound Transport v4 Discard Layer</Data> <Data Name="LayerId">13</Data> <Data Name="Weight">13835058055315718144</Data> <Data Name="Conditions">Condition ID: {632ce23b-5167-435c-86d7-e903684aa80c} Match value: No flags set Condition value: 0x00000003</Data> <Data Name="Action">%%16391</Data> <Data Name="CalloutKey">{EDA08606-2494-4D78-89BC-67837C03B969}</Data> <Data Name="CalloutName">WFP Built-in Silent Drop Transport v4 Discard Layer Callout</Data> </EventData> </Event>
5447.llm_technical_description: The Windows Filtering Platform policy change indicates a filter name modification potentially involving 'Custom Outbound Filter'. This aligns with the Sigma rule for EDRSilencer execution detection, suggesting possible malicious intent targeting EDR agents by blocking outbound traffic.

5448.summary: A Windows Filtering Platform provider has been changed
5448.description:
This event is logged when a WFP provider is added or there is a change to an existing provider. 

For more information on WFP and providers see 5442.

In my testing this event is logged at startup for non persistent provider WFKMP which no doubt has something to do with Windows Firewall.
5448.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5448.llm_technical_description: The event indicates a policy change in the Windows Filtering Platform (WFP), specifically related to filtering platform providers. This could be due to normal configuration updates, misconfigurations, or attempts by an attacker to bypass system restrictions for malicious purposes.

5449.summary: A Windows Filtering Platform provider context has been changed
5449.description:
A provider context is a blob used by a WFP provider to store its state information. For more information on WFP and providers see 5442.

This event is logged whenever a provider context is added or deleted.
5449.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5449.llm_technical_description: The event indicates a change in a provider context related to the Windows Filtering Platform (WFP). Provider contexts are temporary storage areas used by WFP providers. This change could be due to legitimate system updates or potential malicious tampering, as unauthorized modifications might indicate attacker attempts to alter system state.

5450.summary: A Windows Filtering Platform sub-layer has been changed
5450.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5450.llm_technical_description: The event indicates a change in the Windows Filtering Platform policy, which is used to detect malicious activities by monitoring system behavior. The exact nature of the change (e.g., new rules, removed rules) isn't specified, but such updates can enhance security by improving threat detection or potentially introduce vulnerabilities if not properly vetted.

5451.summary: An IPsec Quick Mode security association was established
5451.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5451.llm_technical_description: An IPsec Quick Mode security association was established during the Logon/Logoff process. This typically occurs when two Windows devices establish secure communication automatically upon connection.

5452.summary: An IPsec Quick Mode security association ended
5452.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5452.llm_technical_description: The event 'An IPsec Quick Mode security association ended' occurred during a Logon/Logoff process. This typically happens when an IPsec Quick Mode tunnel is closed, which can occur for legitimate reasons such as reaching the end of a session or being disconnected from the network. The absence of a description makes it difficult to determine if this event indicates malicious activity without additional context.

5453.summary: An IPsec negotiation with a remote computer failed because the IKE and AuthIP IPsec Keying Modules (IKEEXT) service is not started
5453.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5453.llm_technical_description: An IPsec negotiation attempt failed during a logon process because the IKEEXT service was not started. This indicates potential configuration issues or an attempt by an attacker to exploit this misconfiguration.

5456.summary: PAStore Engine applied Active Directory storage IPsec policy on the computer
5456.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5456.llm_technical_description: The PAStore Engine applied an Active Directory storage IPsec policy on the computer, which is a legitimate action typically performed to ensure secure communication between the client and Active Directory. This event indicates that the system has configured its network security settings for compliance with Active Directory policies.

5457.summary: PAStore Engine failed to apply Active Directory storage IPsec policy on the computer
5457.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5457.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that the PAStore Engine failed to apply an Active Directory storage IPsec policy on a computer, which is critical for user authentication and session management. This failure could lead to compromised security by allowing unauthorized access or data breaches if misconfigured.

5458.summary: PAStore Engine applied locally cached copy of Active Directory storage IPsec policy on the computer
5458.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5458.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that the PAStore Engine has applied a locally cached copy of an Active Directory storage IPsec policy. This suggests a potential change in network security policies related to IPsec, which is often used for secure remote access. The implication is that there may be unauthorized modifications to network security configurations.

5459.summary: PAStore Engine failed to apply locally cached copy of Active Directory storage IPsec policy on the computer
5459.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5459.llm_technical_description: The PAStore Engine failed to apply the locally cached IPsec policy from Active Directory due to its removal. This indicates a potential misconfiguration where local network security policies are not being enforced correctly, which could allow unauthorized access or bypass authentication checks.

5460.summary: PAStore Engine applied local registry storage IPsec policy on the computer
5460.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5460.llm_technical_description: The PAStore Engine applied a local registry storage IPsec policy change on the computer. This event indicates that an action was taken to update a security policy related to IPsec for storage devices. While this could be a legitimate system management task, it may also indicate unauthorized or malicious activity if not properly audited.

5461.summary: PAStore Engine failed to apply local registry storage IPsec policy on the computer
5461.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5461.llm_technical_description: The PAStore Engine failed to apply a local registry storage IPsec policy on the computer. This event falls under Policy Change, specifically a Filtering Platform Policy Change. The failure may indicate a misconfiguration in network security policies related to storage, which could be a potential vulnerability for attackers.

5462.summary: PAStore Engine failed to apply some rules of the active IPsec policy on the computer
5462.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5462.llm_technical_description: The event indicates a failed attempt to apply IPsec policy rules in the PAStore Engine, which affects network security configurations. This could lead to unauthorized traffic access or legitimate traffic blocking, potentially allowing attackers to exploit misconfigured firewall rules.

5463.summary: PAStore Engine polled for changes to the active IPsec policy and detected no changes
5463.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5463.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that the PAStore Engine performed a check on the active IPsec policy and found no changes. This is typically part of routine network security operations, such as scheduled policy refreshes or updates.

5464.summary: PAStore Engine polled for changes to the active IPsec policy, detected changes, and applied them to IPsec Services
5464.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5464.llm_technical_description: The event indicates a change in the active IPsec policy, which could signal unauthorized modifications or intentional attempts to alter network security configurations. This might be an attempt to bypass previous security measures or adjust policies that could affect traffic filtering and overall security posture.

5465.summary: PAStore Engine received a control for forced reloading of IPsec policy and processed the control successfully
5465.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5465.llm_technical_description: The PAStore Engine processed a control for forced reloading of an IPsec policy successfully. This event falls under Policy Change and Filtering Platform Policy Change categories. The successful processing may indicate an attempt to update or modify security configurations, which could be an unauthorized change potentially leading to vulnerabilities.

5466.summary: PAStore Engine polled for changes to the Active Directory IPsec policy, determined that Active Directory cannot be reached, and will use the cached copy of the Active Directory IPsec policy instead
5466.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5466.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that the PAStore Engine detected an unreachable Active Directory IPsec policy and defaulted to using a cached copy. This suggests potential configuration issues with IPsec, which can expose network resources to attack vectors like remote desktop or file replication tunnels.

5467.summary: PAStore Engine polled for changes to the Active Directory IPsec policy, determined that Active Directory can be reached, and found no changes to the policy
5467.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5467.llm_technical_description: The PAStore Engine detected that Active Directory is reachable but found no changes to the IPsec policy. This could indicate an attempt to modify or disrupt the Active Directory configuration without success, potentially as part of a malicious activity aimed at gaining unauthorized access or disrupting services.

5468.summary: PAStore Engine polled for changes to the Active Directory IPsec policy, determined that Active Directory can be reached, found changes to the policy, and applied those changes
5468.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5468.llm_technical_description: The PAStore Engine detected and applied changes to the Active Directory IPsec policy, indicating an internal configuration update that may have been altered maliciously or is part of legitimate system settings. This could disrupt network security if tampered with, potentially leading to unauthorized access or increased traffic anomalies.

5471.summary: PAStore Engine loaded local storage IPsec policy on the computer
5471.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5471.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that the PAStore Engine loaded an IPsec policy for local storage during the session. This action typically occurs when system administrators configure security settings for network-attached or virtual storage devices using Windows Platform Security (WPS). The event itself is a normal operation unless there's evidence of unauthorized changes, which could be suspicious.

5472.summary: PAStore Engine failed to load local storage IPsec policy on the computer
5472.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5472.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that the PAStore Engine failed to load an IPsec policy on local storage, which could imply a misconfiguration or unauthorized access attempt. This might be related to network security vulnerabilities where sensitive data is exposed or unauthorized users have access.

5473.summary: PAStore Engine loaded directory storage IPsec policy on the computer
5473.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5473.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a PAStore engine loaded a directory storage IPsec policy on the computer, suggesting a potential attempt to modify system policies without proper logging or monitoring.

5474.summary: PAStore Engine failed to load directory storage IPsec policy on the computer
5474.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5474.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that the PAStore Engine failed to load a directory storage IPsec policy on the computer due to a policy change in the filtering platform. This could imply unauthorized or attempted configuration changes affecting network security.

5477.summary: PAStore Engine failed to add quick mode filter
5477.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5477.llm_technical_description: PAStore Engine failed to add a quick mode filter as per policy change. This indicates an issue where attempting to disable quick mode filtering for an application or file was not handled correctly by PAStore. Quick mode filtering is an optimization feature that excludes certain files from being copied unless explicitly allowed, and disabling it without proper handling could allow attackers to exploit misconfigured application packaging to gain unauthorized access.

5478.description: This event is produced when the IPsec Policy Agent service starts.
5478.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5478.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that the IPsec Policy Agent service has started successfully. This service is responsible for managing secure IPsec tunnels between networks and typically runs in a non-malicious context unless there are specific security configurations or vulnerabilities present.

5479.summary: IPsec Services has been shut down successfully
5479.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5479.llm_technical_description: The IPsec Services have been shut down successfully as part of normal system operations.

5480.summary: IPsec Services failed to get the complete list of network interfaces on the computer
5480.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5480.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that the IPsec services failed to collect the complete list of network interfaces on the computer. This could result in incomplete or misconfigured VPN setups, potentially exposing the system to increased security risks such as unauthorized remote access.

5483.summary: IPsec Services failed to initialize RPC server. IPsec Services could not be started
5483.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5483.llm_technical_description: IPsec Services failed to initialize an RPC server, indicating a potential misconfiguration or service dependency issue that prevents secure communication.

5484.summary: IPsec Services has experienced a critical failure and has been shut down
5484.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5484.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that IPsec Services has experienced a critical failure and has been shut down. This could be due to misconfiguration, an attack on the system, or another security-related issue affecting network communication. The shutdown of IPsec Services may allow unauthorized access or disrupt secure communication channels.

5485.summary: IPsec Services failed to process some IPsec filters on a plug-and-play event for network interfaces
5485.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5485.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that the IPsec Services failed to process some IPsec filters during a plug-and-play network interface setup. This could be due to incorrect installation, misconfigured settings, or hardware issues, which might require manual intervention.

551.description: A user that had logged on interactively (type 2) or by terminal services hasstarted the logoff process. Event ID 538 will usually follow. If Event ID 538 does not follow, it could be that the system shut down before the process could complete or a program (or process) is not managing the access tokens correctly.
551.llm_technical_description: The user initiated a logoff, which typically occurs after logging in interactively or via terminal services. This event may indicate an issue if Event ID 538 does not follow, such as a system shutdown or incorrect access token management by a program or process.

552.description:
Event 552 is logged when a process logs on as a different account such as when the Scheduled Tasks service starts a task as the specified user. Logged on user: specifies the original user account. 

User whose credentials were used: specifies the new user account. Caller process ID: the process that performed this action. Look for a prior event 592 with the same process id. Target Server Name and Info have always been observed as "local host" and source network address and port as empty.
552.llm_technical_description: A logon attempt was detected using explicit credentials (username and password). This event occurs when a process logs in as a different account, such as when Scheduled Tasks runs under a specified user. The original user is 'specified', and the target account is the new user. Caller process ID indicates which service initiated this action.

560.description:
Events of this category allow you to track failed and successful attempts to access files and other Windows objects. 

Event 560 is logged whenever a program opens an object where: 

- the type of access requested has been enabled for auditing in the audit policy for this object 

- the result (success/failure) has been enabled for auditing for this object 

- the account the program is running under is included in the users and/or groups specified for auditing in the audit policy for this object
560.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
560.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that a program attempted to open an object (file or Windows object) where the system has enabled auditing for both success and failure outcomes. The attempt was unsuccessful, likely due to permission issues or other legitimate reasons. However, if these attempts are coming from known malicious users or follow a suspicious pattern, it could indicate potential unauthorized access or compromise of sensitive data.

561.llm_technical_description: The Handle Allocated event typically occurs when an application requests memory for its processes. This event is usually normal and part of routine operations, especially in systems with multiple applications running simultaneously.

562.description:
After successfully opening an object, a program eventually closes it which is documented by this event. Event 562 helps you determine how long the object was open. For this event to be useful you must link it back to the earlier event ID560 with the same handle ID. 

See eventID560 for explanation of Process ID and Image File Name. 

Microsoft's comments: 

Always records as a success.
562.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
562.llm_technical_description: This Handle Closed event (ID 562) indicates that a program successfully closed an object after opening it. The event helps determine the duration the object was open. It should be linked with ID 560, which documents the opening of the same handle. Typically recorded as successful.

563.description: Event 563 does not get logged on normal file deletes. MS documentation says "An attempt was made to open an object with the intent to delete it. Note: This is used by file systems when the FILE_DELETE_ON_CLOSE flag is specified in Createfile().". For files opened exclusively by another program this flag is the only way to delete them.
563.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
563.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that an attempt was made to open an object for deletion. In normal file operations, this event isn't logged because the file system handles such deletions through Createfile(). However, if a file is opened exclusively by another program with the FILE_DELETE_ON_CLOSE flag set, this event is triggered. This could suggest unauthorized access or deletion attempts on sensitive files.

5632.summary: A request was made to authenticate to a wireless network
5632.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022

5632.llm_technical_description: This event indicates a user attempt to authenticate to a wireless network. Authentication attempts can be normal and are often expected during login or logout processes.

5633.summary: A request was made to authenticate to a wired network
5633.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022

5633.llm_technical_description: The event indicates a request to authenticate to a wired network during a Logon/Logoff category. The description is blank, so no additional context can be inferred.

564.description: When an object for which successful delete access has been enabled for auditing, Event 564 is logged upon actual deletion. To determine the name of the object deleted look for a prior event 560 with the same handle ID. Normally event 560 and event 564 will be in close proximity but it is theoretically possible for a process to open an object (560) for delete access and then actually delete it much later. See event 560 for further information.
564.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
564.llm_technical_description: The Object Deleted event (ID 564) occurs when an object with delete access enabled for auditing is deleted. A prior event (560) with the same handle ID can provide the object's name, aiding in debugging and monitoring unauthorized deletions.

565.description:
This event varies depending on the OS. 

Win2000 

Event 565 allows you to track changes to Active Directory objects down to the property level. While Account Management provides more useful auditing for changes to users, groups and computers, Directory Service Access events are the only way to monitor potentially far reaching effects of changes to organizational units, group policy objects, domains and site related objects. 

Event 565 is similar to event 560 but is limited to recording open events on Active Directory objects. Event 565 is therefore only logged on domain controllers. 

Auditing on desired container and leaf objects must be enabled for event 565 to be logged. Open properties dialog of object, select Security tab, click Advanced and select Auditing tab. Event 565 allows you to track new objects created in AD, changes to existing object and deletes. 

Object Type specifies the class object as specified in the schema for this forest. Common object types: 
user 
group 
gpContainer (group policy object) 
dnsDomain (domain) 
organizational unit 

Object Name: X500 distinguished name of the object. 

Primary fields: always correspond to the directory service process and domain controller account. 

Client fields: identify the user (usually some level of an administrator) that accessed the object. 

Accesses: Identify the permissions requested by user/program to the object. These accesses directly correspond to the object level and property level permissions you see in the access control list of the associated object in Active Directory. Write Property and Read Property accesses will be followed by the actual properties written to or read. 

Object types and property names can be cryptic. Use the Active Directory Schema Management MMC snap-in to understand the meaning. 

Write_DAC indicates the user/program attempted to change the permissions on the object. 

You will only see event 565 on domain controllers. 

Win2003 

Additional fields are logged for this event by W3 including: 

Process Name: name of the executable that accessed the object. 

You will only see event 565 on domain controllers.
565.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
565.llm_technical_description: This is an Object Open event (Event 565) for Active Directory. It logs when a user or program accesses an object in the directory service, such as a user account, group, or domain controller. The event includes details like the object type, primary fields from the domain controller account, access types, and properties accessed.

566.description:
Whereas event 565 logs the permissions requested by user/program, event 566 logs the permissions actually exercised by the user/program after opening it. While an object may accessed several times during the same open, Windows only logs event 566 the first time a given permission is actually exercised. This event is similar to 567 but is limited to Active Directory object accesses. 

This event is part of operation based auditing which is new to W3. 

You will only see event 566 on domain controllers.
566.llm_technical_description: This event logs the actual permissions exercised by users or programs accessing Active Directory objects after opening them. It is part of operation-based auditing, which was deprecated in Windows 2003 and removed from newer versions. This event occurs only on domain controllers.

567.description:
Event 567 logs the actual permissions exercised by the user/program on the object after opening it. While event 560 logs the permissions the user/program obtained to the file or other object at the time it was opened, Event 567 asserts that the Accesses where actually used. 

For this event to be useful - that is to identify the object accessed - you must find the preceding event 560 with the corresponding Handle ID. 

While a user/program may repeatedly perform an operation on an open object, Windows only logs the first time a given permission is used. (I.E. a user may open a file and repeatedly save it while working on the file, but Windows will only log the first time WriteData permission was exercised to save the file) 

See event ID560 for additional information.
567.llm_technical_description: This event logs the actual permissions used by a user or program after accessing an object, complementing Event 560 which logs initial access permissions. It is useful for detecting unauthorized access attempts where permissions are changed in an unexpected manner.

5712.summary: A Remote Procedure Call (RPC) was attempted
5712.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5712.llm_technical_description: The event details are limited (ID 5712, Summary: A Remote Procedure Call (RPC) was attempted, Category: Process Tracking, Subcategory: RPC Events, Description: nan). Without additional context or description, it is difficult to determine the exact nature of the event. The detection logic from Sigma rules is unavailable, making it impossible to assess if this event should be monitored.

576.summary: Special privileges assigned to new logon
576.description:
Some user rights (aka privileges) are exercised so frequently that the system and security log would quickly become overwhelemed if Windows were to log every single instance these "high volume" rights were used. For these rights (e.g. backup, restore, etc) Windows elects to simply note the fact that a user has such rights at the time the user logs on with this event. You will normally see event 576 in close succession to logon event 528 or 540. 

Click here for an explanation of Se[privilege names]. 

User Name and Domain: user who just logged on. 

Logon ID: corresponds to the Logon ID of the preceding event 528 or 540. 

Do not confuse user rights (aka privileges) with object permissions despite the fact that MS documentation uses these terms inconsistently. 

Most user rights are not logged by event 576 and instead are logged at the actual time they are exercised using either event 577 or 578.. 

Some of these high-volume rights can be logged each time they are exercised if you enable FullPrivilegeAuditing. To enable auditing of these privileges, add the following key 

Hive: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM 

Key: System\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa 

Name: FullPrivilegeAuditing 

Type: REG_BINARY 

Value: 1 

Note: Events 576, 577 or 578do not log any activity associated with Logon Rights such as the SeNetworkLogonRight. 

Do not confuse events 576, 577 or 578 with events 608, 609, 620 or 621 which document rights assignment changes as opposed to the exercise of rights which is the purpose of events 576, 577 or 578.
576.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
576.llm_technical_description: Event 576 indicates the assignment of special privileges during a new logon attempt. This can include system-wide rights like backup or restore operations that are executed frequently, potentially indicating elevated privileges usage.

577.description:
Event 577 indicates that the specified user exercised the user right specified in the Privileges field. To understand Primary and User fields see event 560. 

Some user rights are logged by this event - others by 578. Still other, ""high-volume"" rights are not logged when they are exercised but simply noted as being held by a user at the time th user logs by event 576. 

Click here for a cross reference of Se[privilege names] translated to user right names: 

Note: 576, 577 and 578 do not log any activity associated with Logon Rightssuch as the SeNetworkLogonRight.
577.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
577.llm_technical_description: The event ID 577 indicates a user has executed a privilege specified by the privileges field in the event log. This could imply elevated access to system resources such as services, which might be suspicious if it occurs without a legitimate reason.

578.description:
This event indicates that the specified user exercised the user right specified in the Privileges field. To understand Primary and User fields see event 560. 

Some user rights are logged by this event - others by 577. Still other, "high-volume" rights are not logged when they are exercised but simply noted as being held by a user at the time th user logs by event 576. 

On Windows Server 2000, this event is logged for the "SeSecurityPrivilege" whenever the security log is viewed or cleared because these operations require the use of the "Manage auditing and security log right" (aka SeSecurityPrivilege). For some reason Windows Server 2003, in the same situation, does not log this event. Occurrences for SeTakeOwnershipPrivilege also appear however the object handle can't be found in any other events in the log so there is no way to identify the object that the "client" user took ownership of. Likewise, Windows Server 2003 does not log this event. 
Note: 576, 577, and 578 do not log any activity associated with LogonRights such as the SeNetworkLogonRight. 

Do not confuse 576, 577 or 578 with events 608, 609, 620 and 621 which document rights assignment changes as opposed to the exercise of rights which is the purpose of 576, 577 and 578. 

Microsoft's Comments: 

These are high volume events, which typically do not contain sufficient information to act upon since they do not describe what operation occurred.
578.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
578.llm_technical_description: The Privileged Object Operation (Event ID 578) indicates that a user has exercised their privileges as specified in the Privileges field. This event is high volume and typically logs user actions without detailed operation descriptions, which can be useful for normal user activity monitoring but may also hide malicious activities if unusual patterns emerge.

5888.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that an object in the COM+ Catalog was modified. This could imply unauthorized access or data tampering. Without specific context, it may suggest malicious activity such as unauthorized modification of sensitive data or creation of backdoors.

5889.summary: An object was deleted from the COM+ Catalog
5889.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
