5889.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that an object was deleted from the COM+ Catalog. This could potentially affect clients relying on that control in legitimate environments or disrupt services if accessed maliciously.

5890.summary: An object was added to the COM+ Catalog
5890.description: An object added to the Com+ Catalog
5890.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
5890.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>5890</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>12290</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-09-23T19:45:04.239886800Z" /> <EventRecordID>344980</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="516" ThreadID="2856" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-3457937927-2839227994-823803824-1104</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">dadmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserDomainName">CONTOSO</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">222443</Data> <Data Name="ObjectCollectionName">Roles</Data> <Data Name="ObjectIdentifyingProperties">ApplId = {1D34B2DC-0E43-4040-BA7B-2F1C181FD86A} Name = CreatorOwner</Data> <Data Name="ObjectProperties">Description =</Data> </EventData> </Event>
5890.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that an object was added to the COM+ Catalog, which is typically used for resource information storage. This action may involve system integrity checks but doesn't inherently pose a security risk without additional context.

592.summary: A new process has been created
592.description:
This event allows you to monitor each program as it is executed. Image File Name identify) the executable. Prior to w2k, image file name did not include the path - just the file name itself. 

New Process ID: allows you to link this event to other events such as object accesses. To determine when the program ended look for a subsequent event 593 with the same Process ID. 

Creator Process ID:identifies the processes that started this process. Look for a preceding event 592 with a New Process ID that matches this Creator Process process ID. 

Username and domain identify the user who started the process. 

Logon ID can be used to find related object accessand other events that have the same Logon ID including the event 528 and 540 logon events.
592.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
592.llm_technical_description: The creation of a new process (event ID 592) allows system administrators to monitor program execution in detail. By tracking the New Process ID, one can identify when the program ends by checking event 593 with the same ID. The Creator Process ID reveals who initiated the process, while Username and Domain identify the account used. Logon ID provides additional context through related events like logons.

593.description:
The program identified in Image File Name was closed or terminated. To find out when the program started, look for the preceding 592 with the same Process ID. 

In Windows 2000 there is no image file Name field. So to determine the name of the program you must find the preceding event 592. 

To identify the program on Windows Server 2003 you can simply use the image name which is supplied in this event.
593.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
593.llm_technical_description: The process identified by Image File Name has exited or terminated. On Windows 2000, the preceding event (592) is required to determine the program name, while on Windows Server 2003, the image name is provided directly in this event.

594.summary: A handle to an object has been duplicated
594.description:
This simply means that the program obtained another handle to an object (e.g. file) that it already had open under a different handle. This handle may be passed on to a child process but in any case it will have the same level of access as the handle the file was originally opened under. To determine what file is involved, find the accompanying event 560 for with a handle ID that matches this event's source handle ID. 

Microsoft's comments: 

Expected activity.
594.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
594.llm_technical_description: Duplicate file handle duplication may indicate unauthorized or malicious activity if used improperly by attackers, as seen in processes passing handles to child processes. This could facilitate unauthorized file sharing or malware distribution.

595.summary: Indirect access to an object has been obtained
595.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
595.llm_technical_description: The event ID 595 indicates that an indirect access to a system object has been observed. This type of event typically relates to the tracking of process activities, where the operating system is monitoring how processes interact with certain objects or resources. In this case, no specific details are provided about the nature of the indirect access, which makes it difficult to determine if this activity is unauthorized or part of a potential threat. The Microsoft Comments suggest that such events are expected behavior under normal circumstances.

596.summary: Backup of data protection master key
596.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
596.llm_technical_description: The event ID 596 indicates that a backup of the data protection master key was performed. This falls under the category of Process Tracking, which suggests it is related to system-level activities rather than user or application-specific processes. The absence of specific details about the backup operation (e.g., frequency, purpose) makes it challenging to determine if this activity is normal or potentially malicious. However, since data protection master keys are critical to system security, any unauthorized or unusual backup operation could indicate a potential risk.

600.summary: A process was assigned a primary token
600.description:
This often happens when a service starts or a scheduled task starts under the authority of a different user. You will see events 528/540 and 552 as well as 680 or 672 earlier in the log. 

The Assigning process fields identify the process that started the child (new) process. Process ID allows you to link this event to the corresponding event 592 (process start of the parent process) but there is little need since this event gives you the program name (image) and the user under which the process was running (primary user fields). See 528/540 for explanation of Logon ID. 

New process information identifies the new child process that was started under the Target user name. You can use the new process ID to link back to the earlier 592 for the new child process ID but again there is little need to do this since you have the image name right here in this event. 

The following parameters are tracked for both the assigning process and the new process.
600.llm_technical_description: This event indicates the assignment of a primary token, typically done when a user gains local administrative privileges. This can occur during legitimate activities like service start-ups or scheduled tasks but may also be suspicious if not properly authorized.

601.description:
A new service was installed by the indicated user and domain. 

Service Name: the internal system name of the new service.Use "sc query" to get a cross reference of service names and their more familiar display names. 

Service Type: 

Service Start Type: 

Service Account: this is the account that the service runs under. 

User Name and Domain identify the user who installed the service. 

While this event only monitors new services, you can audit existing service related events such as starts, stops and modifications with the Object Access category. To enable auditing on a service you can use a Security Template or the subinacl (resource kit) command.
601.llm_technical_description: The event indicates an attempt by a specific user and domain to install a new service on the system. This could be a legitimate action or potentially malicious if done from an unauthorized or compromised account.

602.description:
This event actually gets logged for both scheduled task creations as well as changes to exisiting tasks. This event does not get logged when a task is deleted. 

If you enable Object Auditing for successes, you will also see file level access events corresponding the *.job file in %SystemRoot%\Tasks\ including delete events. See events 560, 564, 567, and 562. 

File name identifies the *.job file where the task definition is stored. Command documents the operating system command that will be executed when the task starts. Triggers specifies how often or what event will trigger the task to start. Time specifies the next time the task will run. Target User is the account the task will run under. By User and Domain identify the user who created or modified the task. Logon ID enables you to connect this event back with the user's initial logon. See event 528 and 540.
602.llm_technical_description: This event logs the creation of a scheduled task or changes to an existing task in Windows. It does not log deletions by default unless Object Auditing is enabled, which also captures file-level events for *.job files. The event provides details such as the command executed when the task starts and user information.

608.description:
This event documents a change to user right assignments on this computer. Rights, like most other security settings, are defined in group policy objects and applied by the computer. Therefore this event will normally show the Assigned By user as the system itself. To determine who actually made the rights assignment change you must search the domain controllers' security logs for changes to gpContainer objects (logged by Directory Service auditing). Logon ID allows you to link this event to the prior event 528 or 540 logon event of the user who performed this action. 

Assigned To identifies the user or group who was assigned the right. Prefixed by domain name. 

This event documents the system name for each user right as opposed to the more familiar description. Click here for a cross reference. 

Note: This event and 609do not log changes to logon rights such as "Access this computer from the network" or "Logon as a service". See events 621 and 622.
608.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
608.llm_technical_description: The event logs a change in user right assignments on this computer, typically made by the system. This could indicate legitimate policy updates or potential malicious activities if rights are altered without proper authorization.

609.description:
A user right was revoked from the Removed From user or group. See event 608 for a full explanation. 

Note: This event and 609 do not log changes to logon rights such as "Access this computer from the network" or "Logon as a service". See events 621 and 622.
609.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
609.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a user right was removed from the system, possibly as part of a legitimate policy change or an attempt to bypass restrictions. This could be indicative of unauthorized access attempts or misconfigured permissions.

610.description:
This event varies depending on the OS. 

Win2000 

This event gets logged twice (duplicate) by the domain controller. The DC also logs an event 620along with this event. The DC logs this event for both new trusted and trusting domains. There is no way to make a distinction. 

If directory service access auditing is turned on, the DC also logs an event 565 (object opened) where the object service is DS and the object type is trustedDomain. Trusted/trusting domain is not identified. 

See also event IDs611 and 620. 

Win2003 

Unlike Windows 2000, Windows Server 2003 only logs this event once for each new trust. Although the description says "new *trusted* domain" this event gets logged for both trusted and trusting relationships. Note trust type, trust direction, etc. in descripiton. 

Also accompanying this is an event ID 565 - if directory service auditing is turned on. 565 identifies the event as a "creat child", trustedDomain event and supplies the distinquished name of the new domain (e.g. CN=SouthAmerica, CN=System,DC=elm, DC=local) 

Trust Directions 
1 - Trusted (the domain where this event was logged accepts the identity of users of the new domain) 
2 - Trusting ( (the new domain accepts the identity of users of the domain where this event was logged) 
3 - 2-way (mutual trust) 

Trust Type and Attributes refer to whether the trust relationship is an NT 4.0 legacy trust, Kerberos realm trust or a forest or domain trust with another active directory domain and whether the trust is transitive or not. 

SID filtering involves whether SID history from the external domain is used in the local domain. 
See also event IDs 611 and 620.
610.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
610.llm_technical_description: This event indicates a policy change related to domain trust relationships in Windows environments. For both new trusted domains (where users can join externally) and trusting domains (where a trusted domain cannot join), the domain controller logs this event without distinguishing between them. Additionally, if directory service auditing is enabled, an associated event 565 is logged, which may indicate unauthorized access to trusted or trusting relationships by logging only the source domain's distinguished name.

611.description:
This event varies depending on the OS. 

Win2000 

This event gets logged twice (duplicate) by the domain controller. Unlike event 610, an event 620 does not accompany this event. 

The DC logs this event for both trusted and trusting domains. There is no way to make a distinction. 

If directory service access auditing is turned on, the DC also logs an event 565 (object opened) and 564 (object deleted) where the object service is LSA and the object type is TrustedDomainObject. Object name identifies the 610, 611 and 620 

Win2003 

Unlike Windows 2000, Windows Server 2003 only logs this event once for each new domain. Although the description says "new *trusted* domain" this event gets logged for both trusted and trusting relationships. 

If directory service access auditing is turned on, the DC also logs an event 565 (object opened) and 564 (object deleted) where the object service is LSA and the object type is TrustedDomainObject. Object name identifies the domain. 
See also event IDs 610 and 620.
611.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
611.llm_technical_description: This event (611) is related to the removal of a Trusted Domain Policy in Windows systems. It is logged by the domain controller and indicates changes to the trusted or trusting domains. The event varies between different Windows versions, with Win2000 logging it twice for both domains, while Win2003 logs it once but for both types. Additionally, if directory service auditing is enabled, events 564 (object deleted) and 565 (object opened) are also logged when dealing with TrustedDomainObject LSAs.

612.description: This indicates the system's audit policy was modified. Pluses indicate auditingis enabled, minuses indicate itis disabled. Unfortunately the Change By fields don't alwaysidentify who actually changed the policy because audit policymight not bedirectly configured by administrators. Instead itmight beedited in a group policy object which then gets applied to the computer.In that casethis event shows the local computer as the one who changed the policy since the computer is the security principal under which gpupdate runs.
612.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
612.llm_technical_description: The event indicates a change in the system's audit policy, which could involve enabling or disabling auditing mechanisms. Auditing policies control user permissions and data access, making such changes potentially suspicious if not justified. The event shows that the local computer is involved in the policy modification, possibly due to group policy edits. This could indicate unauthorized access or attempt to bypass security controls.

613.description: This event has not been observed.
613.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
613.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that an IPSec policy agent has started, which is related to secure tunneling and VPN configurations. This could be a normal setup or potentially unauthorized action depending on the context.

614.description: This event has not been observed.
614.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
614.llm_technical_description: The IPSec policy agent was disabled as part of a network security measure. This could indicate an intentional action to restrict or block secure communication, potentially signaling the start of a denial of service (DoS) attack or other malicious activities aimed at disrupting network traffic.

6144.summary: Security policy in the group policy objects has been applied successfully
6144.description: This is a useful event.  This event does not just get logged each time Group Policy refreshes.  It only gets logged (based on testing Win2012R2) when something in Security Settings the RSOP has changed (i.e. someone edited a Security Setting in one of the GPOs applicable to this computer, or Local Security Policy)thus necessitating Windows to adjust local configuration to meet Group Policy.  So basically this event tells you a security configuration change has occurred due to Group Policy (including Local Security Settings).  It doesn't tell you which policy(ies) but at least you know something has changed.
6144.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
6144.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>6144</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13573</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-10-07T22:59:32.280498500Z" /> <EventRecordID>1055041</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="524" ThreadID="712" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="ErrorCode">0</Data> <Data Name="GPOList">{8AB9311A-E5FB-4A5A-8FB7-027D1B877D6D} DC Main Policy</Data> </EventData> </Event>
6144.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that a Security Policy in Group Policy Objects (GPOs) has been successfully applied. This could involve changes to Local Security Policy or GPO settings, which might affect system access controls. It is useful for detecting unintended changes within these policies but does not provide specific information about which policy was modified.

6145.summary: One or more errors occured while processing security policy in the group policy objects
6145.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
6145.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>6145</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13573</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8010000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-10-07T22:43:54.183603800Z" /> <EventRecordID>1052680</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="524" ThreadID="3476" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DC01.contoso.local</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="ErrorCode">1332</Data> <Data Name="GPOList">{6AC1786C-016F-11D2-945F-00C04fB984F9} Default Domain Controllers Policy {31B2F340-016D-11D2-945F-00C04FB984F9} Default Domain Policy</Data> </EventData> </Event>
6145.llm_technical_description: The event indicates an error during the processing of security policy within Group Policy Objects (GPOs). This could be due to malicious activity, such as adding a backdoor or introducing malicious software via policy configuration. It also may indicate a legitimate misconfiguration that is causing issues.

615.description: This event varies depending on the OS.
615.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
615.llm_technical_description: This event indicates a change in the IPSEC PolicyAgent Service configuration. IPSEC is used for secure network communications by encrypting and authenticating data packets. A 'Policy Change' event suggests that the security policy governing the use of IPSEC has been updated. This could include changes to encryption algorithms, hashing functions, or other parameters that affect how IPSEC tunnels are managed. The implications depend on the nature of the change; malicious actors may attempt to exploit such updates if they have modified them in a way that bypasses known security controls.

616.summary: IPSec policy agent encountered a potentially serious failure.
616.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
616.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that an IPSec policy agent has encountered a potentially serious failure. This suggests that there may be an issue with network security policies, such as misconfigured rules or unauthorized access attempts. The failure could indicate potential vulnerabilities exploited by attackers, who might attempt to exploit this flaw to gain unauthorized network access.

617.description:
W2k logs this event each time the DC applies group policy. W3 corrects this problem and only logs the event when it detects an actual change to the policy. Kerberos policy is defined in GPOs linked to the root of the domain under Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Account Policy\Kerberos Policy. 

Unfortunately the Change By fields don't identify who actually changed the policy because audit policy isn't directly configured by administrators. Instead it is edited in a group policy object which then gets applied to the computer. Therefore this event always shows the local computer as the one who changed the policy since the computer is the security principal under which gpupdate runs.The time is when the policywas applied rather than the time the group policy object was changed.
617.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
617.llm_technical_description: This event logs a change to the Kerberos policy managed through Group Policy Objects (GPOs). While W2k initially logs every application of group policies, W3 corrects this by logging only when there's an actual policy change. The Change By field incorrectly attributes the change to the local computer due to how GPupdate operates under that computer's security principal.

618.description:
This event gets logged when EFS data recovery agent information is changed. User name will usually correspond to the local computer's name because EFS is controlled through group policy. To find out who changed EFS policy you must determine who changed the relevant group policy object. 

The encrypted data recovery agent policy is defined in group policy objects under Computer Configuratoin\Windows Settings\Securirty Settings\Public Key Policies\Encrypted File System.
618.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
618.llm_technical_description: This event indicates a change in the Encrypted Data Recovery Policy (EDRP), managed through Group Policy Objects (GPOs) under Windows Security Settings. The username typically corresponds to the local computer's name due to EFS's centralized management. Determining who made this change requires identifying modifications to specific GPOs, potentially indicating unauthorized access or configuration issues that could compromise data security.

619.description: This event has not been observed.
619.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
619.llm_technical_description: The Quality of Service Policy Change event indicates that network management settings have been altered. This could potentially impact traffic prioritization and network operations. Without specific context on the nature of the change or observed behavior, further investigation is required.

620.description:
This event varies depending on the OS. 

Win2000 

It appears this event only gets logged upon trust additions, not removals. A better set of events to use are 610 and 611. The DC logs this event for both new trusted and trusting domains. There is no way to make a distinction. 

Win2003 

Logged when an existing trust's properties are modified. For instance, turning on transitivity. Applies to trusted and trusting trust relationships. 
See also event IDs 610 and 611.
620.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
620.llm_technical_description: This event (ID: 620) indicates that trusted domain information has been modified. This can occur in two scenarios: when a new trust is added or an existing trust's properties are altered, such as enabling transitivity. The event is logged for both trusted and trusting domains but does not distinguish between them, making it difficult to determine the exact nature of the change without additional context.

621.description:
This event documents the grant of logon rights such as "Access this computer from the network" or "Logon as a service". 

Rights, like most other security settings, are defined in group policy objects and applied by the computer. Therefore this event will normally show the Assigned By user as the system itself. To determine who actually made the rights assignment change you must search the domain controllers' security logs for changes to gpContainer objects (logged by Directory Service auditing). Logon ID allows you to link this event to the prior event 528 or 540 logon event of the user who performed this action. 

Assigned To identifies the user or group who was assigned the right. Prefixed by domain name. 

This event documents the system name for each logon right as opposed to the more familiar description. Click here for a cross reference. 

Note: This event and 622 log changes to strictly logon rights such as "Access this computer from the network" or "Logon as a service" - not to other rights such as "Change the system time" or "Take ownership of files and other objects". See events 608 and 609.
621.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that the system has granted logon rights allowing access from the network or logon as a service, potentially granting an attacker unauthorized access if misconfigured.

622.description:
A logon right was revoked from the Removed From user or group. See event 621 for a full explanation. 

Note: This event and 621 log changes to strictly logon rights such as "Access this computer from the network" or "Logon as a service" - not to other rights such as "Change the system time" or "Take ownership of files and other objects". See events 608 and 609.
622.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a user or group has had their system security access rights revoked. This could be due to a legitimate policy change but should be monitored for potential unauthorized activity.

623.summary: Per User Audit Policy was refreshed
623.description:
623 does not exist. 806 however does.Windows Server 2003 is supposed to include per user selective auditing but no documentation exists from MS. You will occasionally see this event logged. See also event 807. 

See Roger Grimes article at www.windowsitpro.com for an excellent introduction to per user selective auditing.
623.llm_technical_description: The event ID 623 indicates a refresh of the per user audit policy, which is typically used for accountability purposes. The fact that this event exists without documentation from Microsoft and references an article suggests it might be related to selective auditing in Windows Server 2003. Attackers could exploit legitimate policy changes to hide malicious activities.

624.description: "Caller user" created "new account". This event will be accompanied by at least 2 subsequent event ID 642s and one 627.
624.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
624.llm_technical_description: The event ID 624 indicates the creation of a new user account. This is followed by two instances of Event ID 642 (User Account Maintenance) and one instance of Event ID 627, which typically relates to account-related configurations such as permissions or logging changes.

625.description:
Despite MS documentation, this event does not get logged by W2k. However W2k does log event 642 and identifies the type of change. See example below: W3 also logs 642 along with this event but the format of642 is different compared to W2k. See 642 for W3. 

Event ID: 642
Description: 
User Account Changed: 
Account Enabled. 
Target Account Name:user 
Target Domain:ELMW2 
Target Account ID:ELMW2\user 
Caller User Name:Administrator 
Caller Domain:ELMW2 
Caller Logon ID:(0x0,0x12D622) 
Privileges:-Note Windows 2000 does not log event ID 626 explicitly. Results are logged as a part of event ID642 in the description of the message. Windows Server 2003 DOES logs this event. This event will be accompanied by an event 642.
625.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a user account type was changed in Windows 2000, despite documentation suggesting this change isn't logged. However, similar events with ID 642 are logged by other systems like Windows 3 and Windows Server 2003 when the account enable state is modified.

626.description:
Despite MS documentation, this event does not get logged by W2k but W3 does log this event correctly. However W2k does log event642 and identifies the type of change. See example below: W3 also logs 642 along with this event but the format of 642 is different compared to W2k. See 642 for W3. 

Event ID:642 
Description: 
User Account Changed: 
Account Enabled. 
Target Account Name:user 
Target Domain:ELMW2 
Target Account ID:ELMW2\user 
Caller User Name:Administrator 
Caller Domain:ELMW2 
Caller Logon ID:(0x0,0x12D622) 

Privileges:-Note Windows 2000 does not log event ID 626 explicitly. Results are logged as a part of event ID642 in the description of the message. Windows Server 2003 DOES logs this event. This event will be accompanied by an event 642.
626.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
626.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a user account was enabled by someone other than the current administrator. Windows Server 2003 logs this event, while Windows 2000 does not, suggesting potential unauthorized access or misconfiguration.

627.description:
On Windows 2000, this event gets logged for both succesful and failed attempts for both password changes (user changing his own password) or password resets when one user (caller user) attempts to change the password of another user (target user). 

On Windows Server 2003 this event is only logged when a user changes his own password. For password resets by administrators see event 628. This event will also be accompanied by event 642 showing that the Password Last Set date field was updated.
627.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
627.llm_technical_description: This event logs when a user attempts to change their own password (successful or failed) or resets another user's password on Windows 2000. On Windows Server 2003, this occurs only when the user changes their own password. It is often accompanied by event 642, which updates the Password Last Set date.

6272.summary: Network Policy Server granted access to a user
6272.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
6272.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that the Network Policy Server granted access to an unknown user. The event belongs to the Logon/Logoff category within the Windows Event Log and is categorized under Network Policy Server activity.

6273.summary: Network Policy Server denied access to a user
6273.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
6273.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that a user was denied access by the Network Policy Server during the logon process. This could be due to an attempt to exploit security policies or circumvent them, suggesting potential malicious activity. If this occurs frequently, it may indicate compromised credentials or unauthorized access attempts.

6274.summary: Network Policy Server discarded the request for a user
6274.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
6274.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that the Network Policy Server has discarded a user's login request. This could imply an attempt to gain unauthorized access or bypass security measures.

6275.summary: Network Policy Server discarded the accounting request for a user
6275.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
6275.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that the Network Policy Server attempted to handle an accounting request from a user but was unable to complete it, discarding the request. This could be due to legitimate reasons such as policy enforcement or account lockout mechanisms.

6276.summary: Network Policy Server quarantined a user
6276.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
6276.llm_technical_description: The network policy server is quarantining a user account. This action typically occurs when a user's account is moved, deleted, or restricted due to policies defined in Active Directory. The event could indicate legitimate user management actions such as moving accounts between workstations, migrating users across domains, or enforcing access control policies. However, the context and configuration of the policy server are critical factors. If the action was taken without proper authorization (e.g., moving an account without consent), it may be a sign of potential malicious activity.

6277.summary: Network Policy Server granted access to a user but put it on probation because the host did not meet the defined health policy
6277.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
6277.llm_technical_description: The Network Policy Server granted access to a user but placed it on probation because the host did not meet the defined health policy. This suggests potential unauthorized access or misconfiguration, indicating possible compromise if further suspicious activity occurs.

6278.summary: Network Policy Server granted full access to a user because the host met the defined health policy
6278.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
6278.llm_technical_description: The event indicates a user account was granted full access by the Network Policy Server because the host met the defined health policy. This could imply unauthorized or misconfigured access, potentially indicating an attacker or misconfiguration.

6279.summary: Network Policy Server locked the user account due to repeated failed authentication attempts
6279.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
6279.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a user account was locked by a Network Policy Server due to repeated failed authentication attempts. This could be due to legitimate issues such as misconfigured policies or misconfigurations leading to access denial. The implications depend on the context, but it raises concerns about potential unauthorized access attempts if it's an active attack.

628.description:
On Windows 2000, this event does not get logged by w2k despite MS documentation. 

This event DOES get logged on Windows Server 2003. 

This event indicates the "caller" user reset the password of the "target" user. Password resets do not required knowledge of the current password. See event 627 for password changes by the user himself. This event will also be accompanied by event 642 showing that the Password Last Set date field was updated.
628.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
628.llm_technical_description: The event 628 indicates a user resetting their password on Windows Server 2003. This is a normal legitimate activity and does not imply any malicious intent unless accompanied by other suspicious events such as failed login attempts (1605) or credential dumping.

6280.summary: Network Policy Server unlocked the user account
6280.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
6280.llm_technical_description: The Network Policy Server has unlocked an account, but without additional details, it's challenging to assess if this was legitimate or malicious. The absence of a description makes it difficult to interpret the context.

6281.summary: Code Integrity determined that the page hashes of an image file are not valid...
6281.description: Code Integrity determined that the page hashes of an image file are not valid. The file could be improperly signed without page hashes or corrupt due to unauthorized modification. The invalid hashes could indicate a potential disk device error.
6281.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
6281.llm_technical_description: The event indicates a Code Integrity failure for an image file, where the page hashes are invalid. This could imply that the file was tampered with or corrupted during modification. The potential risks include disk device errors and compromised system integrity. The event also aligns with Sigma's Failed Code Integrity Checks rule, which is designed to detect issues like tampered binaries or corrupted drivers.

629.description:
Windows logs this event for both user accounts and computer accounts. Computer account names are recognizable by the $ at the end of the name. This event will be accompanied by an event 642 (if a user account) or 646 (if a computer account).

Despite MS documentation, this event does not get logged by W2k but W3 does log this event correctly. However W2k does log event ID642 and identifies the type of change. See example below: W3 also logs 642 along with this event but the format of 642 is different compared to W2k. See 642 for W3. Note Windows 2000 does not log event ID 629 explicitly. Results are logged as a part ofevent ID 642in the description of the message. Windows Server 2003 DOES logs this event.
629.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a user or computer account has been disabled without proper authentication. This could be an attempt to gain unauthorized access, as disabling an account can leave systems vulnerable to exploitation.

630.description: Logged when one user (caller user) deletes another user account (target account).
630.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
630.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that one user deleted another user account. This could be legitimate for changing usernames or deleting unused accounts but may also suggest malicious activity such as impersonation or erasing evidence.

631.description:
Global security group created.Type: 

AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

Scope: 

AD has 3 scopes of groups: Local, Global, Universal. See knowledge base article 326265.
631.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
631.llm_technical_description: The creation of a Security-Enabled Global Group in Active Directory indicates an attempt to gain unauthorized access or control over network resources by leveraging administrative privileges. This could potentially allow attackers to manage user accounts or devices without explicit permission.

632.summary: Security Enabled Global Group Member Added
632.description:
Member added to security global group."Caller user"added "member name"to the "target" group. Member may be a user, computer or another group. 

Type: 

AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

Scope: 

AD has 3 scopes of groups: Local, Global, Universal. See knowledge base article 326265.
632.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
632.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that a member was added to a Security-Enabled Global Group. Security-Enabled Global Groups allow members access to files and directories, potentially granting significant privileges if unauthorized or misconfigured users are added. The addition of a member could lead to unintended access control issues, making this an area for monitoring.

633.summary: Security Enabled Global Group Member Removed
633.description:
Member removed from security global group."Caller user" removed "member name" from the "target" group. Member may be a user, computer or another group. 

Type: 

AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

Scope: 

AD has 3 scopes of groups: Local, Global, Universal. See knowledge base article 326265.
633.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
633.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a member has been removed from a security-enabled global group. This could be related to legitimate access control or potentially malicious activity depending on the context.

634.description:
Security global group deletedType: 

AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

Scope: 

AD has 3 scopes of groups: Local, Global, Universal. See knowledge base article 326265.Free Security Log Resources by Randy

634.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
634.llm_technical_description: The deletion of a Security Enabled Global Group (SEGG) typically occurs during Active Directory maintenance or restructuring. This event is generally benign unless accompanied by evidence of malicious intent, such as unauthorized access or compromised user privileges.

635.description:
Local security group created.Type: 

AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

Scope: 

AD has 3 scopes of groups: Local, Global, Universal. See knowledge base article 326265.
635.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
635.llm_technical_description: The creation of a local Security Enabled Local Group (S ELG) was detected. This event indicates that an attempt has been made to configure a group with security enabled in the local forest. The creation of such groups is generally allowed, but if the group is used improperly (e.g., as a distribution list without proper configuration), it could indicate malicious or misconfigured behavior.

636.summary: Security Enabled Local Group Member Added
636.description:
Member added to security local group. "Caller user"added "member name"to the "target" group. Member may be a user, computer or another group. 

Type: 

AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

Scope: 

AD has 3 scopes of groups: Local, Global, Universal. See knowledge base article 326265.
636.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
636.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a user or group was added as a member of a Security local group in Active Directory. This could be part of normal administrative tasks but might also suggest unauthorized access or misconfigured permissions if done with malicious intent.

637.summary: Security Enabled Local Group Member Removed
637.description:
Member removed from security local group. "Caller user" removed "member name" from the "target" group. Member may be a user, computer or another group. 

Type: 

AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

Scope: 

AD has 3 scopes of groups: Local, Global, Universal. See knowledge base article 326265.
637.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
637.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a user or group has been removed from a security-enabled local group in Active Directory. This can potentially impact the permissions and access rights associated with resources controlled by this group. The removal could affect critical resources if the group is managing sensitive assets, configurations, or permissions.

638.description:
Security local group deletedType: 

AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

Scope: 

AD has 3 scopes of groups: Local, Global, Universal. See knowledge base article 326265.
638.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
638.llm_technical_description: The deletion of a Security Enabled Local Group in Active Directory (AD) indicates potential malicious intent, as such groups typically contain administrative rights necessary for system management. Deleting them could grant elevated privileges to an attacker, potentially allowing unauthorized access or command execution.

639.description:
Security local group changed.Type: 

AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

Scope: 

AD has 3 scopes of groups: Local, Global, Universal. See knowledge base article 326265. 

This event does include group member additions and deletions for which there are other event IDs.
639.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
639.llm_technical_description: The event indicates a change in a Security Enabled Local Group (S ELG) within the Active Directory (AD) environment. This typically involves adjusting permissions or rights associated with users or groups, which could be an attempt to elevate privileges or grant unauthorized access if not properly controlled.

640.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
640.llm_technical_description: This event indicates a potential security concern related to a change in an account database configuration within Windows. The 'General Account Database Change' suggests modifications to user accounts or credentials, which could be indicative of unauthorized access attempts or misconfigurations commonly exploited by attackers for credential stuffing or exfiltration activities.

6400.summary: BranchCache: Received an incorrectly formatted response while discovering availability of content.
6400.description: BranchCache: Received an incorrectly formatted response while discovering availability of content.
6400.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
6400.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that BranchCache received an incorrectly formatted response while discovering the availability of content. This could imply misconfigured user accounts or legitimate issues, such as a firewall blocking legitimate traffic.

6401.summary: BranchCache: Received invalid data from a peer. Data discarded.
6401.description: BranchCache: Received invalid data from a peer. Data discarded.
6401.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
6401.llm_technical_description: The event indicates a BranchCache issue where invalid data was received from a peer, resulting in data discard. This can occur due to legitimate operations or malicious tampering, particularly if attempting to exploit branch vulnerabilities.

6402.summary: BranchCache: The message to the hosted cache offering it data is incorrectly formatted.
6402.description: BranchCache: The message to the hosted cache offering it data is incorrectly formatted.
6402.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
6402.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that the message being sent to the hosted cache is incorrectly formatted. This could be due to issues with branch tables in hypervisor software or performance optimization data, potentially affecting data integrity.

6403.summary: BranchCache: The hosted cache sent an incorrectly formatted response to the client's message to offer it data.
6403.description: BranchCache: The hosted cache sent an incorrectly formatted response to the client's message to offer it data.
6403.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
6403.llm_technical_description: The system event indicates that BranchCache sent an incorrectly formatted response to a client's message, potentially exposing sensitive data or allowing attackers manipulation of the cache. This could lead to information exposure, authentication bypass, or silent failures.

6404.summary: BranchCache: Hosted cache could not be authenticated using the provisioned SSL certificate.
6404.description: BranchCache: Hosted cache could not be authenticated using the provisioned SSL certificate.
6404.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
6404.llm_technical_description: This event indicates an attempt to authenticate a BranchCache-managed cache with an SSL certificate, which failed. This could imply a misconfigured cached SSL certificate, potentially allowing unauthorized access to HTTPS traffic or intercepting secure communications.

6405.summary: BranchCache: %2 instance(s) of event id %1 occurred.
6405.description: BranchCache: %2 instance(s) of event id %1 occurred.
6405.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
6405.llm_technical_description: The event ID 6405 corresponds to a BranchCache misprediction in Windows. This indicates a potential system performance issue or unusual activity within the system's CPU processing. Since there are no known false positives for this event type, it may not be directly indicative of malicious activity unless accompanied by other anomalies.

6406.summary: %1 registered to Windows Firewall to control filtering for the following:
6406.description: %1 registered to Windows Firewall to control filtering for the following: %2.
6406.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
6406.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that the user has registered a rule in Windows Firewall using the command line interface (cmd.exe). This could potentially allow unauthorized access or bypass normal network security measures if misused.

6407.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
6407.llm_technical_description: The Windows EventLog entry with ID 6407 is an unknown system event with a Summary of 1%, Category System, Subcategory Other System Events. The description does not provide specific details.

6408.summary: Registered product %1 failed and Windows Firewall is now controlling the filtering for %2.
6408.description: Registered product %1 failed and Windows Firewall is now controlling the filtering for %2.
6408.operating_systems: Windows 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
6408.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that product %1 has failed registration, with Windows Firewall now controlling filtering for %2. This could imply misconfigured firewall settings preventing legitimate updates or indicate potential tampering. It may also suggest a compromised system configuration where updates are not applied as intended.

6409.summary: BranchCache: A service connection point object could not be parsed
6409.description: This event is new to Server 2012. It does not appear in earlier versions.
6409.operating_systems: Windows 2012 R2, Windows 8.1, Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
6409.llm_technical_description: The event ID 6409 indicates an issue with the BranchCache service in Server 2012. Since this is a new service introduced in Server 2012, it may not have been present in earlier versions, suggesting potential recent configuration changes or underlying issues that could impact system stability.

641.description:
Security global group changed.Type: 

AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

Scope: 

AD has 3 scopes of groups: Local, Global, Universal. See knowledge base article 231273. 

This event does include group member additions and deletions for which there are other event IDs.
641.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
641.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that the scope of a Security (enabled) Group has been changed in Active Directory. This can involve adding or removing group members, altering permissions, or changing the group's purpose from being a distribution list to an active management group or vice versa.

6410.summary: Code integrity determined that a file does not meet the security requirements to load into a process. This could be due to the use of shared sections or other issues
6410.operating_systems: Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
6410.llm_technical_description: The event indicates a system integrity issue where a file cannot be loaded into a process due to security requirements. This could involve malicious code execution in shared libraries, incorrect manifest files, or unauthorized access.

6416.summary: A new external device was recognized by the system.
6416.description: Windows logs at least 1 of these events (observed 6 in the case of a USB flash drive) when you connect a new external device to the system.  To determine the type of system look to the class GUID, or for more descriptive information, the Vendor and Compatible IDs.  Note that this event is logged whenever you connect said device - even repeatedly; unlike other audit events that only log the very first time a given device is connected.
6416.operating_systems: Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
6416.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>6416</EventID> <Version>1</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13316</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-11-13T18:20:16.818569900Z" /> <EventRecordID>436</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="4" ThreadID="308" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DESKTOP-NFC0HVN</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-18</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">DESKTOP-NFC0HVN$</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">WORKGROUP</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x3e7</Data> <Data Name="DeviceId">SCSI\\\\Disk&Ven\\_Seagate&Prod\\_Expansion\\\\000000</Data> <Data Name="DeviceDescription">Seagate Expansion SCSI Disk Device</Data> <Data Name="ClassId">{4D36E967-E325-11CE-BFC1-08002BE10318}</Data> <Data Name="ClassName">DiskDrive</Data> <Data Name="VendorIds">SCSI\\\\DiskSeagate\\_Expansion\\_\\_\\_\\_\\_\\_\\_0636 SCSI\\\\DiskSeagate\\_Expansion\\_\\_\\_\\_\\_\\_\\_ SCSI\\\\DiskSeagate\\_ SCSI\\\\Seagate\\_Expansion\\_\\_\\_\\_\\_\\_\\_0 Seagate\\_Expansion\\_\\_\\_\\_\\_\\_\\_0 GenDisk</Data> <Data Name="CompatibleIds">SCSI\\\\Disk SCSI\\\\RAW</Data> <Data Name="LocationInformation">Bus Number 0, Target Id 0, LUN 0</Data> </EventData> </Event>
6416.llm_technical_description: The system logs a new external device connection as part of normal plug-and-play activity, typically multiple times per session.

6417.summary: The FIPS mode crypto selftests succeeded
6417.operating_systems: Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
6417.llm_technical_description: The FIPS mode crypto selftests succeeded. This indicates that the system's cryptographic modules are functioning correctly according to NIST standards. While this is a normal operation for systems in FIPS mode, potential malicious activities could include unauthorized attempts to bypass these checks, such as exiting FIPS mode without proper authentication.

6418.summary: The FIPS mode crypto selftests failed
6418.operating_systems: Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
6418.llm_technical_description: The FIPS mode crypto selftests failed, indicating a potential issue with cryptographic modules. This failure can be indicative of an attack attempt, as attackers often target cryptographic mechanisms to gain unauthorized access.

6419.summary: A request was made to disable a device
6419.description: This event is generated if a user attempts to disable a device on the system. This event does not mean that a device was successfully disabled. Event ID 6420 will be generated if this attempt is successful.
6419.operating_systems: Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
6419.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>6419</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13316</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-11-14T22:23:26.789591400Z" /> <EventRecordID>483</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="2192" ThreadID="1392" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DESKTOP-NFC0HVN</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-21-2695983153-1310895815-1903476278-1001</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">ladmin</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">DESKTOP-NFC0HVN</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x3fcc7</Data> <Data Name="DeviceId">USB\\\\VID\\_138A&PID\\_0017\\\\FFBC12C950A0</Data> <Data Name="DeviceDescription">Synaptics FP Sensors (WBF) (PID=0017)</Data> <Data Name="ClassId">{53D29EF7-377C-4D14-864B-EB3A85769359}</Data> <Data Name="ClassName">Biometric</Data> <Data Name="HardwareIds">USB\\\\VID\\_138A&PID\\_0017&REV\\_0078 USB\\\\VID\\_138A&PID\\_0017</Data> <Data Name="CompatibleIds">USB\\\\Class\\_FF&SubClass\\_00&Prot\\_00 USB\\\\Class\\_FF&SubClass\\_00 USB\\\\Class\\_FF</Data> <Data Name="LocationInformation">Port\\_\\#0002.Hub\\_\\#0004</Data> </EventData> </Event>
6419.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that a user attempted to disable a device but the attempt was unsuccessful. This could suggest unauthorized access or an attempt to gain control without permission.

642.description:
"Target" user account was changed by "Caller" user. 

On Windows 2000 and XP, for some types of changes, the event will include a description of what was changed on the 2nd line of the description.
642.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
642.llm_technical_description: The event 'User Account Changed' indicates that a user account (Caller) has altered another user account (Target). This could be benign, such as updating passwords or system settings. However, it may also indicate malicious activity like Credential Dumping, where attackers change accounts to exfiltrate sensitive information without leaving evidence in standard logs until later stages.

6420.description: This event is generated when a user successfully disables a device.
6420.operating_systems: Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022

6420.llm_technical_description: The device was disabled by a user as part of normal user interaction. This could indicate legitimate user activity or potential malicious behavior depending on context.

6421.summary: A request was made to enable a device
6421.description: This event is generated if a user attempts to enable a device on the system. This event does not mean that a device was successfully enabled. Event ID 6422 will be generated if this attempt is successful.
6421.operating_systems: Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022

6421.llm_technical_description: A user attempted to enable a device via Plug and Play functionality. This event does not confirm success, so Event ID 6422 should be checked afterward.
