6422.llm_technical_description: The device enablement event (ID 6422) occurred when a user successfully enabled a device via plug-and-play functionality. This is a standard user action and does not indicate malicious activity.

6423.summary: The installation of this device is forbidden by system policy
6423.description: Logged as a result of \Computer Configuration\Administrative Templates\System\Device Installation\Device Installation Restrictions. That category contains four device installation restriction settings that allow you to prevent devices from being installed that match certain specified criteria. You can prevent installation of devices that match device ID's, device class GUID's or are removable devices. You can also prevent devices from being installed that do not match any other policies.
6423.operating_systems: Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
6423.event_xml: <Event xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"> - <System> <Provider Name="Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing" Guid="{54849625-5478-4994-A5BA-3E3B0328C30D}" /> <EventID>6423</EventID> <Version>0</Version> <Level>0</Level> <Task>13316</Task> <Opcode>0</Opcode> <Keywords>0x8020000000000000</Keywords> <TimeCreated SystemTime="2015-11-14T22:49:34.647975900Z" /> <EventRecordID>488</EventRecordID> <Correlation /> <Execution ProcessID="828" ThreadID="1924" /> <Channel>Security</Channel> <Computer>DESKTOP-NFC0HVN</Computer> <Security /> </System> - <EventData> <Data Name="SubjectUserSid">S-1-5-18</Data> <Data Name="SubjectUserName">DESKTOP-NFC0HVN$</Data> <Data Name="SubjectDomainName">WORKGROUP</Data> <Data Name="SubjectLogonId">0x3e7</Data> <Data Name="DeviceId">USB\\\\VID\\_04F3&PID\\_012D\\\\7&1E3A8971&0&2</Data> <Data Name="DeviceDescription">Touchscreen</Data> <Data Name="ClassId">{00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000}</Data> <Data Name="ClassName" /> <Data Name="HardwareIds">USB\\\\VID\\_04F3&PID\\_012D&REV\\_0013 USB\\\\VID\\_04F3&PID\\_012D</Data> <Data Name="CompatibleIds">USB\\\\Class\\_03&SubClass\\_00&Prot\\_00 USB\\\\Class\\_03&SubClass\\_00 USB\\\\Class\\_03</Data> <Data Name="LocationInformation">Port\\_\\#0002.Hub\\_\\#0004</Data> </EventData> </Event>
6423.llm_technical_description: This event occurs when a device installation attempt is blocked due to system policy settings in Plug and Play category under Administrative Templates. The system checks if the device matches specific criteria (Device ID, Class GUID) or other policies for removable devices before allowing installation. If the conditions are met, this event is logged, indicating an unauthorized or potentially malicious device installation attempt.

6424.summary: The installation of this device was allowed, after having previously been forbidden by policy
6424.description: Microsoft says "This event occurs rarely, and in some situations may be difficult to reproduce."
6424.operating_systems: Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
6424.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that system installation permissions were adjusted after a previous configuration which previously forbade installation. This could suggest misconfiguration or unauthorized changes in system policies, potentially allowing installations where they were previously denied.

643.description:
This event varies depending on the OS 

Win2000 

W2k logs frequent occurrences of this event even if you haven't changed your password policy. Each time Win2K applies Group Policy, it doesn't check to see whether the new and old policies are actually different. You can ignore event ID 643. 

Win2003 

Unlike w2k, w3 properly logs this event only when the password or lockout policy or domain mode changes. Additionally the actual settings changed are identified with their new values under Change Attributes. 

The following Changed Attributes correspond to settings group policy under Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Account Policies\Password Policy: 
Password Properties = "Password must meet complexity requirements" and "Store password using reversible encryption for all users in the domain" 
- 0 = both complexity and reversible encryption disabled 
1 = complexity enabled and reversible encryption disabled 
- 16 = complexity disabled and reversible encryption enabled 
- 17 = both complexity and reversible encryption enabled 
Min. Password Age = Minimum password age 
Max. Password Age = Maximum password age 
Min. Password Length = Minimum password length 
Password History Length = Enforce password history 

The following Changed Attributes correspond to settings group policy under Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Account Policies\Account Lockout Policy: 
Lockout Threshold = Account lockout threshold 
Lockout Observation Window = Reset account lockout counter after 
Lockout Duration = Account lockout duration 

The following Changed Attributes correspond to settings group policy under Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Local Policies\Security Options: 
Force Logoff = Network security: Force logoff when logon hours expire
643.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
643.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that a Group Policy has been changed in the system, which can include settings related to password complexity requirements, encryption methods, account lockout policies, and network security configurations. In Windows 2000, this event occurs frequently regardless of whether changes are necessary, while in Windows 2003, it only logs when actual policy changes occur.

644.description:
"Target" user account was locked out because of consecutive failed logon attempts exceeded lockout policy of domain - or in the case of local accounts the - local SAM's lockout policy. 

In addition to this event Windows also logs an event642(User Account Changed)
644.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
644.llm_technical_description: The user account locked out due to consecutive failed logon attempts, which could indicate potential malicious activity such as brute force attacks or unauthorized access attempts. The event is part of normal user account management but requires further investigation if occurring frequently in sensitive contexts.

645.description: "Caller" user created a new computer account. Note that internally Windows appends a $ to all computer account names and this is reflected in other events where computer account names are listed.
645.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
645.llm_technical_description: The creation of a new computer account by the 'Caller' user may indicate unauthorized access attempts or an attempt to gain control over other systems. Since Windows appends '$' to computer account names, this event should be logged meticulously to ensure accurate identification.

646.description: "Target"computer account was changed by "Caller" user. For some types of changes the event will include a description of what was changed on the 2nd line of the description.
646.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
646.llm_technical_description: The event indicates an unauthorized account change where a target computer account was modified by another user (Caller). This could imply potential unauthorized access or administrative privileges transfer.

647.description:
"Caller" user deleted "target" computer account. 

Note, this event also gets logged when a trust relationship is deleted. "Target" account name will correspond to the trusted/ing domain appended with a $.
647.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
647.llm_technical_description: The 'Computer Account Deleted' event indicates that the user account identified as 'Caller' has been deleted, potentially as part of a trust relationship deletion in a domain-joined environment. This could be a legitimate action or an unauthorized activity indicative of security concerns.

648.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
648.llm_technical_description: A Security Disabled Local Group was created. This indicates that an attempt was made to create a local group with restricted access rights or permissions, which could be a sign of misconfiguration or potential security measures applied to manage user or computer access within the system.

649.description:
Distribution local group changed. Type: AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

Scope: AD has 3 scopes of groups: Local, Global, Universal. See knowledge base article 326265. 

This event does include group member additions and deletions for which there are other event IDs.
649.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
649.llm_technical_description: The event involves a change in a Security Disabled Local Group within an Active Directory environment. This type of event typically occurs when group members (user accounts) are added or removed from such groups. Since these groups cannot be used to assign permissions, any attempt to do so would fail. The presence of this event could indicate potential misconfiguration attempts, which might be part of malicious activities aiming to bypass security measures.

650.summary: Security Disabled Local Group Member Added
650.description:
Member added to distribution local group. "Caller user" removed "member name" from the "target" group. Member may be a user, computer or another group. 

Type: 

AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

Scope: 

AD has 3 scopes of groups: Local, Global, Universal. See knowledge base article 326265.
650.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
650.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a member has been added to a distribution local group with security disabled. This could imply potential misconfiguration or malicious intent if not properly vetted.

651.summary: Security Disabled Local Group Member Removed
651.description:
Member removed from distribution local group. "Caller user" removed "member name" from the "target" group. Member may be a user, computer or another group. 

Type: 

AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

Scope: 

AD has 3 scopes of groups: Local, Global, Universal. See knowledge base article 326265.
651.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
651.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a member was removed from a distribution local group with security disabled. Distribution groups are read-only and used primarily for email distribution lists. Removing a member could imply unauthorized changes, potentially indicating an attempt to alter access control without proper authorization.

652.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
652.llm_technical_description: The event 'Security Disabled Local Group Deleted' indicates that a local group associated with an account has been deleted, potentially after being marked as disabled. This could be part of a legitimate system maintenance or an unauthorized action by an attacker. The category is Account Management, which suggests the event relates to user accounts or permissions. The description mentions a Distribution local group was deleted, implying it may have contained sensitive information or configurations.

653.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
653.llm_technical_description: A global distribution group was created. This is a standard setup process in many organizations for sending emails or messages, typically managed via Active Directory.

654.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
654.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that the global group distribution has been changed, which typically occurs when an administrator adjusts permissions or access levels for users within a global group. While this is generally a legitimate operation, it could also be indicative of unauthorized changes if not properly tracked.

655.summary: Security Disabled Global Group Member Added
655.description:
Member added to distribution global group. "Caller user" removed "member name" from the "target" group. Member may be a user, computer or another group. 

Type: 

AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

Scope: 

AD has 3 scopes of groups: Local, Global, Universal. See knowledge base article 326265

This event is logged only on Domain Controllers.
655.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
655.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a member has been added to an SD (Security Disabled) group in Active Directory. This could potentially introduce malicious access if the member is not properly configured or if the attacker gains unauthorized access to the group.

656.summary: Security Disabled Global Group Member Removed
656.description:
Member removed from distribution global group. "Caller user" removed "member name" from the "target" group. Member may be a user, computer or another group. 

Type: 

AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

Scope: 

AD has 3 scopes of groups: Local, Global, Universal. See knowledge base article 326265.

This event is logged only on Domain Controllers.
656.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
656.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a member has been removed from a distribution group in Active Directory. This could be due to unauthorized removal, potentially leading to issues if the distribution list was intended for email communication which requires security features like GPOs to be enabled.

657.description:
Distribution global group deleted.Type: 

AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

Scope: 

AD has 3 scopes of groups: Local, Global, Universal. See knowledge base article 326265.
657.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
657.llm_technical_description: The event involves the deletion of a Security Disabled Global Group in Active Directory, which cannot be used for permissions or rights as it's intended solely for Exchange distribution lists. This action could indicate legitimate administrative management, potentially after a misconfiguration or manual cleanup.

658.description:
Security universal group created.Type: 

AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

Scope: 

AD has 3 scopes of groups: Local, Global, Universal. See knowledge base article 326265.

This event is logged only on Domain Controllers
658.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
658.llm_technical_description: The creation of a Security Enabled Universal Group on Domain Controllers indicates a potential administrative activity, possibly carried out by an attacker to gain unauthorized access or manipulate network permissions. While normal operations often require such group configurations, deviations from standard procedures could signal malicious intent.

659.description:
Security universal group changed.Type: 

AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

Scope: 

AD has 3 scopes of groups: Local, Global, Universal. See knowledge base article 326265. 

This event does include group member additions and deletions for which there are other event IDs.
659.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
659.llm_technical_description: The event involves changing the security status of an AD group from Security (enabled) to Distribution (disabled). This implies a potential attempt by an attacker or administrator to alter group configurations to restrict member rights, possibly as part of a malicious activity such as unauthorized distribution access.

660.summary: Security Enabled Universal Group Member Added
660.description:
Member added to security universal group. "Caller user" removed "member name" from the "target" group. Member may be a user, computer or another group. 

Type: 

AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

Scope: 

AD has 3 scopes of groups: Local, Global, Universal. See knowledge base article 326265.

This event is logged only on Domain Controllers
660.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP

661.summary: Security Enabled Universal Group Member Removed
661.description:
Member removed from security universal group. "Caller user" removed "member name" from the "target" group. Member may be a user, computer or another group. 

Type: 

AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

Scope: 

AD has 3 scopes of groups: Local, Global, Universal. See knowledge base article 326265. 

This event is logged only on Domain Controllers.
661.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
661.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a Security Universal Group (SUG) member was removed from a domain controller log. SUGs typically have high administrative privileges and can be used for permissions or distribution lists. Removing a member may affect user access rights, potentially exposing sensitive resources if not properly secured.

662.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
662.llm_technical_description: The deletion of a Security Enabled Universal Group indicates that permissions for a collection of users have been adjusted, potentially impacting their access rights. This could expose sensitive data or resources if the group contained elevated privileges.

663.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
663.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a universal group was created through distribution. Universal groups in Windows are typically used for permissions control, such as assigning access to files or applications. While this activity alone does not imply malicious intent, it could potentially be exploited if improperly managed by an attacker. For example, an attacker might distribute malicious content using legitimate group creation methods to gain unauthorized access or spread harmful software.

664.description:
Distribution universal group changed.Type: 

AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

Scope: 

AD has 3 scopes of groups: Local, Global, Universal. See knowledge base article 326265. 

This event does include group member additions and deletions for which there are other event IDs.

This event is logged only on Domain Controllers.
664.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
664.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a group in Active Directory has been changed from Security enabled to Security disabled (Distribution). This is typically done to prevent using the group as a container for permissions or rights and instead use it only for distribution lists. Domain Controllers are logging this change, which can be normal if the group was modified intentionally or maliciously.

665.summary: Security Disabled Universal Group Member Added
665.description:
Member added to distribution universal group. "Caller user" removed "member name" from the "target" group. Member may be a user, computer or another group. 

Type: 

AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

Scope: 

AD has 3 scopes of groups: Local, Global, Universal. See knowledge base article 326265.
665.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
665.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a member was added to a Distribution (Security Disabled) group in Active Directory. This type of group is typically used for distribution lists and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. The fact that the 'Caller user' removed a member name from the 'target' group suggests that this could potentially indicate unauthorized access or an attempt to bypass security controls by adding a user with admin rights to such groups, which are generally meant for Exchange distribution purposes.

666.summary: Security Disabled Universal Group Member Removed
666.description:
Member removed from distribution universal group. "Caller user" removed "member name" from the "target" group. Member may be a user, computer or another group. 

Type: 

AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

Scope: 

AD has 3 scopes of groups: Local, Global, Universal. See knowledge base article 326265.
666.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
666.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a user or group member has been removed from a Distribution Universal Group, which is typically used for creating Exchange Server distribution lists. This operation affects the group's permissions and can be indicative of unauthorized changes or accidental removal.

667.description:
Distribution universal group deleted

Type: 

AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

Scope: 

AD has 3 scopes of groups: Local, Global, Universal. See knowledge base article 326265. 
This event is logged only on Domain Controllers.
667.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
667.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a Security Disabled Universal Group (UDG) was deleted at a Domain Controller. UDGs are typically used only internally and cannot be assigned permissions or rights, nor can they serve as distribution lists in Exchange. Deleting such a group may not indicate malicious activity but could suggest misconfiguration or legitimate actions.

668.description:
This event gets logged when scope or type of the "target" group is changed by the "caller" user. 

Type: 

AD has 2 types of groups: Security and Distribution. Distribution (security disabled) groups are for distribution lists in Exchange and cannot be assigned permissions or rights. Security (security enabled) groups can be used for permissions, rights and as distribution lists. 

Scope: 

AD has 3 scopes of groups: Local, Global, Universal. See knowledge base article 326265.

This event is logged only on Domain Controllers.
668.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
668.llm_technical_description: The event indicates a change in the type of a group (Security vs. Distribution) or its scope (Local, Global, Universal). This could potentially allow an attacker to gain unintended permissions or access, especially if the change is unauthorized or part of an attack vector. The implications depend on whether the group was intended for distribution or security purposes.

669.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
669.llm_technical_description: The Windows Event Log entry with ID 669 under Account Management category indicates that a user has attempted to add session history data. The event summary 'Add SID History' suggests this activity may relate to user session management or configuration.

670.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
670.llm_technical_description: The event ID: 670 refers to an attempt to add Side Information Directory (SID) history, which is not yet confirmed. SIDs are often associated with user accounts and can be used by attackers for unauthorized access if the credentials are compromised or misused. The lack of confirmation makes this event a potential indicator of malicious activity if it were to occur in an unexpected manner.

671.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
671.llm_technical_description: The 'User Account Unlocked' event (ID: 671) is logged twice and typically occurs when an account is unlocked using Locksmith or similar tools. This event may indicate unauthorized access attempts, especially if it's part of a series of failed login attempts.

672.description:
This event varies depending on the OS. 

Win2000 

This event gets logged on domain controllers only. 

At the beginning of the day when a user sits down at his or her workstation and enters his domain username and password, the workstation contacts a local DC and requests a TGT. If the username and password are correct and the user account passes status and restriction checks, the DC grants the TGT and logs event ID 672 (authentication ticket granted). The User field for this event (and all other events in the Audit account logon event category) doesn't help you determine who the user was; the field always reads SYSTEM. Rather look at the User Name and Supplied Realm Name fields, which identify the user who logged on and the user account's DNS suffix. The User ID field provides the same information in NT style. 

Client Address identifies the IP address of the workstation from which the user logged on. 

W2k logs other instances of event ID 672 when a computer in the domain needs to authenticate to the DC typically when a workstation boots up or a server restarts. In these instances, you'll find a computer name in the User Name and User ID fields. Computer generated kerberos events are always identifiable by the $ after the computer account's name. 

Win2003 

This event is logged on domain controllers only and both success and failure instances of this event are logged. 

At the beginning of the day when a user sits down at his or her workstation and enters his domain username and password, the workstation contacts a local DC and requests a TGT. If the username and password are correct and the user account passes status and restriction checks, the DC grants the TGT and logs event ID 672 (authentication ticket granted). The User field for this event (and all other events in the Audit account logon event category) doesn't help you determine who the user was; the field always reads SYSTEM. Rather look at the User Name and Supplied Realm Name fields, which identify the user who logged on and the user account's DNS suffix. The User ID field provides the same information in NT style. 

Client Address identifies the IP address of the workstation from which the user logged on. 

W2k logs other instances of event ID 672 when a computer in the domain needs to authenticate to the DC typically when a workstation boots up or a server restarts. In these instances, you'll find a computer name in the User Name and User ID fields. Computer generated kerberos events are always identifiable by the $ after the computer account's name. 

In W2k failed authentication ticket requests generate event ID 676 but in W3 this event is used for both success and failed requests. The reason for the authentication failure is specified in Result Code. 

Microsoft's Comments: 

Does not contain any additional information if audit details from logon events 528 and 540 are already being collected. This event records that a Kerberos TGT was granted, actual access will not occur until a service ticket is granted, which is audited by Event 673. If the PATYPE is PKINIT, the logon was a smart card logon.
672.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
672.llm_technical_description: This event (Authentication TicketGranted) is logged on domain controllers during successful user logins. It indicates that a user has successfully authenticated using their credentials and the system has granted access, which could be part of a legitimate process such as accessing services or resources within the network.

673.description:
This event varies depending on the OS. 

Win2000 

Whereas event ID 672 lets you track initial logons through the granting of TGTs, this lets you monitor the granting of service tickets. Service tickets are obtained whenever a user or computer accesses a server on the network. For example, when a user maps a drive to a file server, the resulting service ticket request generates event ID 673 on the DC. 

User Name and User Domain identify the user. 
Service Name corresponds the computer name of the server the user accessed. 
Client Address specifies the IP address where the user resides. 

Win2003 

W3 uses this event ID for both successful and failed service ticket requests. 

Whereas event ID 672 lets you track initial logons through the granting of TGTs, this lets you monitor the granting of service tickets. Service tickets are obtained whenever a user or computer accesses a server on the network. For example, when a user maps a drive to a file server, the resulting service ticket request generates event ID 673 on the DC. 

User Name and User Domain identify the user. 
Service Name corresponds the computer name of the server the user accessed. 
Client Address specifies the IP address where the user resides. 

The reason for a failed service ticket request is specified in Failure Code.
673.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
673.llm_technical_description: This event, ID 673, is related to service ticket grants in Windows systems (Win2000/Win2003). It occurs when users access servers or network services, such as mapping drives. The fields include user details and server information.
673.llm_security_impact: If no detection rules are set, this event may not provide direct security insights. However, it could indicate unauthorized access if misconfigurations occur.

674.description:
This event varies depending on the OS. 

Win2000 

Kerberos limits how long a ticket is valid. If a ticket expires when the user is still logged on, Win2K automatically contacts the DC to renew the ticket which triggers this event. See event 673 for an explanation of the fields. 

Win2003 

Kerberos limits how long a ticket is valid. If a ticket expires when the user is still logged on, Win2K automatically contacts the DC to renew the ticket which triggers this event. See event 673 for an explanation of the fields.
674.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
674.llm_technical_description: This event (ID: 674) indicates that a Kerberos ticket has been renewed automatically by the Domain Controller when it expires during user login. This is a normal Windows behavior and should not be considered malicious unless there are additional signs of compromise or unauthorized activity.

675.description:
When a user attempts to log on at a workstation and uses a valid domain account name but enters a bad password, the DC records event ID 675 (pre-authentication failed) with Failure Code 24. By reviewing each of your DC Security logs for this event and failure code, you can track every domain logon attempt that failed as a result of a bad password. In addition to providing the username and domain name, the event provides the IP address of the system from which the logon attempt originated. 

Win2K also logs event ID 675 when a user attempts to use a different username (i.e., a username other than the one he or she used for the current workstation logon) to connect to a server. For example, a user might try to use the Connect using a different user name feature to use someone else's account to map a drive to a server. 

This event can be logged for a few other reasons which are specified in the failure code. All Kerberos event failure codes correspond to the error codes defined by the Kerberos standard (RFC 1510). Click here for an explanation of failure codes. 

Recommended response for failed instances of this event: 

Check the User ID field. Most events generated by computer accounts are safe to ignore. Determine the reason for the authentication failure by checking Failure Code. TGT failures are usually due to a bad password or time synchronization between workstation and domain controller. If Failure Code indicates a bad password, how many failures exist for the same account? Look at the client IP address. Is an innocent user error or malicious attack indicated. If practical contact user regarding their recent logon attempts.
675.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
675.llm_technical_description: This event (ID 675) indicates a pre-authentication failure in a Kerberos logon attempt. It can occur due to user error with incorrect passwords or legitimate failed attempts, as well as potential malicious activities such as unauthorized account access. The event provides details like username, domain name, and client IP, aiding in detecting suspicious patterns.

676.description:
This event varies depending on the OS.

Win2000

W2k logs this event when the user's initial logon fails for other reasons than those reported by 675. See events 675 and 672 for explanation of the fields.

Win2003

W3 does not log this event. Instead W3 logs a failed instance of event 672.
676.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
676.llm_technical_description: The 'Authentication Ticket Request Failed' event (ID: 676) occurs when a user's initial logon attempt fails due to reasons not covered by the related event 675. On Windows 2000, this is logged as W2k, while Windows 2003 uses event 672 instead.

677.description:
This event varies depending on the OS.

Win2000

Sometimes an attempt to acquire a service ticket fails even though the DC successfully authenticated the user and granted a TGT. In this case, Win2K logs event ID 677 (service ticket request failed) with a variety of failure codes depending on the situation. See event ID 675 for a list of failure codes.

Common example: user tries to connect from Win2K+ workstation to NT server. Generates event 677 with Failure Code 7. The workstation first asks the DC to grant a Kerberos service ticket, but that fails because the NT server doesn't support Kerberos. Thus, the DC logged event ID 677 with Failure Code 7. This type of error is transparent to the user because the workstation immediately falls back to using NTLM.

Win2003

This event is not logged by Windows Server 2003 despite MS Documentation. It is replaced by 673 type Failure Audit.
677.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
677.llm_technical_description: Service Ticket Request Failed Event ID 677 indicates a failure in Kerberos authentication attempts by users attempting to connect to an NTLM-protected server. This event is typically logged when a Windows Active Directory (WAD) configuration issue prevents the successful issuance of Service Tickets, leading to a TGT failure and subsequent NTLM fallback. The occurrence may suggest misconfigured AD roles or authentication issues that could be indicative of legitimate problems or potential attack vectors.

678.description: This event is not confirmed to exist outside MS documentation.
678.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
678.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that an account has been mapped for logon by a user or application during system access attempts. The fact that the description is not confirmed outside MS documentation suggests this may be an internal or potentially unauthorized action, which could indicate compromised permissions or unauthorized access attempts.

679.summary: The name: %2 could not be mapped for logon by: %1
679.description: This event is not confirmed. Without seeing examples we can't document the meaning of %2 and %1. If you have an example please post it in this event's forum; you'll find a link on this page.
679.llm_technical_description: This event indicates an issue with account authentication attempts. The summary suggests that a principal (account) could not be mapped correctly during a logon attempt by another user or principal. This might indicate either a legitimate misconfiguration in Active Directory, such as incorrect directory traversal settings, or potential unauthorized access attempts.

680.description:
This event varies depending on the OS. 

Win2000 

When DC successfully authenticates a user via NTLM (instead of Kerberos), the DC logs this event. This specifies which user account who logged on (Account Name) as well as the client computer's name from which the user initiated the logon in the Workstation field. 

This event is only logged on member servers and workstations for logon attempts with local SAM accounts. 
The Account Used for Logon By field identifies the authentication package that processed the authentication request. Read more about Account Logon events. 

Win2003 

When DC successfully authenticates a user via NTLM (instead of Kerberos), the DC logs this event. This specifies which user account who logged on (Account Name) as well as the client computer's name from which the user initiated the logon in the Workstation field. 

This event is only logged on member servers and workstations for logon attempts with local SAM accounts. 
Account Used for Logon By identifies the authentication package that processed the authentication request. 

In Windows Server 2003 Microsoft eliminated event ID 681 and instead uses event ID 680 for both successful and failed NTLM authentication attempts. So on Windows Server 2003 don't look for event ID 681 and be sure to take into account the success/failure status of occurrences of event ID 680.
680.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
680.llm_technical_description: This event (Event ID 680) captures successful NTLM authentication attempts by a user account on Windows Server versions 2003 and later. It logs the Account Name used for the login and the client computer's name where the logon originated from the Workstation field. This event is typically generated when users authenticate successfully via NTLM, which is commonly used across Windows domains.

681.summary: The logon to account: %2 by: %1 from workstation: %3 failed.
681.description:
This event varies depending on the OS. 

Win2000 

If an NTLM authentication request fails for any reason, W2k logs event ID 681. 

Error code provides the reason for the failure.
681.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
681.llm_technical_description: This event indicates a failed attempt to logon to an account using username %2 from workstation %3. In Windows 2000, such events are triggered when NTLM authentication fails. The error code provides details about the failure reason. This could indicate unauthorized access attempts or other security issues.

682.description:
Windows logs this event when a user reconnects to a disconnected terminal server session as opposed to a fresh logon which is reflected by event 528. 

User Name and Domain identify the user of the remote desktop connection that was reconnected to. 

Logon ID corresponds to the logon id specified in an earlier event 528. See 528 for more details. 

Client Name specifies the computer name of the client computer while Client Address specifies its IP address.
682.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
682.llm_technical_description: This event indicates a user reconnecting to a terminal server session from a previous Logon (event 528). While typical, unusual activity such as multiple reconnects or under unexpected circumstances could signal malicious intent.

683.description:
Windows logs this event when a user disconnects from a terminal server (aka remote desktop) session as opposed to an full logoff which triggers event 538. 

User Name and Domain identify the user of the remote desktop connection that was reconnected to. 

Logon ID corresponds to the logon id specified in an earlier event 528. See 528 for more details. 

Client Name specifies the computer name of the client computer while Client Address specifies its IP address.
683.operating_systems: Windows Server 2000, Windows Server 2003, Windows XP
683.llm_technical_description: The session disconnect from winstation event (ID 683) indicates that a user disconnected their terminal server session without completing a full logoff process, which would be indicated by event ID 538. The Logon ID associated with this event corresponds to an earlier successful login attempt (event ID 528), suggesting potential unauthorized access or an attempt to bypass security measures.

684.summary: Set ACLs of members in administrators groups
684.description:
According to MS documentation: "Every 60 minutes on a domain controller a background thread searches all members of administrative groups (such as domain, enterprise, and schema administrators) and applies a fixed security descriptor on them. This event is logged." 

I have confirmed this event to exist but it is unclear under exactly what circumstances it is logged.
684.llm_technical_description: The event involves setting Access Control Lists (ACLs) on members of administrative groups within a domain. This is a routine task performed by Domain Administrators every 60 minutes across all domain controllers, as per MS documentation. The event logs these changes, indicating normal system activity.

685.description: When an account name ischanged, the SID remains the same. However the Target ID in this event indicates the new name. This is because when the operating systemdisplays this event it evidently queries the database where the SIDis stored and translates the SID to the domain\username.
685.llm_technical_description: This event indicates a change in an account name, which is typically managed by users or administrators. In Windows, changing an account name updates the display name without altering the SID (System Identification Number), which uniquely identifies a user within a domain. The Target ID reflects the new username used for login.

686.summary: Password of the following user accessed
686.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a password for an account was accessed. While the description is not confirmed, given it falls under Account Management, potential implications include unauthorized access attempts or legitimate login activities. Without specific context about the credentials accessed (e.g., username, password), it's challenging to determine if this constitutes malicious activity. The lack of known false positives in Sigma rules suggests this event may be genuine but without further details, it's hard to assess its nature.

687.description:
These events are not confirmed. 

These events evidently relate to application groups which are created by application developers using Authorization Manager. These groups include basic application groups and LDAP query groups as special cases. Application groups are specific to Authorization Manager roll based administration. Authorization Manager provides a flexible framework for integrating role-based access control.
687.llm_technical_description: The event indicates the creation of a Basic Application Group in Authorization Manager, which can be used for roll-based administration and role-based access control. While these events are typically legitimate actions by application developers, malicious actors could exploit them for unauthorized access if misconfigured.

688.description:
These events are not confirmed. 

These events evidently relate to application groups which are created by application developers using Authorization Manager. These groups include basic application groups and LDAP query groups as special cases. Application groups are specific to Authorization Manager roll based administration. Authorization Manager provides a flexible framework for integrating role-based access control.
688.llm_technical_description: The event indicates a change in an Application Group within the Windows environment. Application Groups managed through Authorization Manager allow for roll-based administration and fine-grained control over user permissions. This type of event could be indicative of legitimate system administration tasks, such as updating access controls or moving sensitive data, but it can also be monitored for potential misuse, such as unauthorized application group modifications that might bypass security measures.

689.description: These events are not confirmed.These events evidently relate to application groups which are created by application developers using Authorization Manager. These groups include basic application groups and LDAP query groups as special cases. Application groups are specific to Authorization Manager roll based administration. Authorization Manager provides a flexible framework for integrating role-based access control.
689.llm_technical_description: The event indicates a user being added to an Application Group in Authorization Manager, which is used for Role-Based Access Control (RBAC). While this is a legitimate administrative action, potential malicious behavior could include unauthorized access by adding users with high privileges. The event should be monitored for signs of misuse such as unexpected group member additions or permissions changes that might expose sensitive data.

690.description:
These events are not confirmed. 

These events evidently relate to application groups which are created by application developers using Authorization Manager. These groups include basic application groups and LDAP query groups as special cases. Application groups are specific to Authorization Manager roll based administration. Authorization Manager provides a flexible framework for integrating role-based access control.
690.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a member has been removed from an application group managed by Authorization Manager. This tool is typically used for role-based access control in Windows environments. The removal of a member could be a legitimate administrative action but may also indicate unauthorized access if not properly secured.

691.description:
These events are not confirmed. 

These events evidently relate to application groups which are created by application developers using Authorization Manager. These groups include basic application groups and LDAP query groups as special cases. Application groups are specific to Authorization Manager roll based administration. Authorization Manager provides a flexible framework for integrating role-based access control.
691.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that a basic application group has been added without proper authorization in the Authorization Manager system. Application groups are managed by users with specific permissions and are used for role-based access control. If these events are not confirmed, they could suggest unauthorized access attempts or misconfiguration, which may indicate potential malicious activity.

692.description:
These events are not confirmed. 

These events evidently relate to application groups which are created by application developers using Authorization Manager. These groups include basic application groups and LDAP query groups as special cases. Application groups are specific to Authorization Manager role based administration. Authorization Manager provides a flexible framework for integrating role-based access control.
692.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a user who does not have access rights for an application group has been removed. This could be due to unauthorized actions or misconfiguration in systems using Authorization Manager for role-based access control.

693.description:
These events are not confirmed. 

These events evidently relate to application groups which are created by application developers using Authorization Manager. These groups include basic application groups and LDAP query groups as special cases. Application groups are specific to Authorization Manager role based administration. Authorization Manager provides a flexible framework for integrating role-based access control.
693.llm_technical_description: The deletion of a Basic Application Group in Authorization Manager indicates potential unauthorized access control measures being circumvented. Developers typically manage these groups to enforce role-based access, so their removal might signal an attempt by attackers to bypass legitimate security configurations.

694.description:
These events are not confirmed. 

These events evidently relate to application groups which are created by application developers using Authorization Manager. These groups include basic application groups and LDAP query groups as special cases. Application groups are specific to Authorization Manager role based administration. Authorization Manager provides a flexible framework for integrating role-based access control.
694.llm_technical_description: The event indicates the creation of an LDAP query group by an application, possibly without proper authorization. This could be indicative of unauthorized access attempts or configuration misconfigurations.

695.description:
These events are not confirmed. 

These events evidently relate to application groups which are created by application developers using Authorization Manager. These groups include basic application groups and LDAP query groups as special cases. Application groups are specific to Authorization Manager role based administration. Authorization Manager provides a flexible framework for integrating role-based access control.
695.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that an LDAP query group has been changed. This could relate to application-specific administrative activities within the Windows Active Directory environment. The change might be necessary for legitimate business operations or potentially malicious if unauthorized.

696.description:
These events are not confirmed. 

These events evidently relate to application groups which are created by application developers using Authorization Manager. These groups include basic application groups and LDAP query groups as special cases. Application groups are specific to Authorization Manager role based administration. Authorization Manager provides a flexible framework for integrating role-based access control.
696.llm_technical_description: The deletion of an LDAP Query Group indicates a potential administrative action related to directory services. While this is a common operation in Active Directory environments, unauthorized deletions could potentially be exploited by attackers as stepping stones for further malicious activities.

697.summary: Password Policy Checking API is called
697.description: Microsoft says this is "typical behavior" and can be ignored. I concur. You may frequently see it on SQL Servers.
697.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a Password Policy Checking API call was made under the Account Management category. While Microsoft considers this activity typical for systems, including SQL Servers, it is not inherently malicious unless additional context suggests otherwise.

7045.summary: A new service was installed in the system
7045.description: A new service was installed in the system
7045.llm_technical_description: A new service was installed in the system under Security system extension. This could indicate potential malicious activity such as credential dumping tools execution or suspicious service installations associated with known vulnerabilities like Micro-Star MSI Afterburner and ProcessHacker privilege elevation.

806.summary: Per User Audit Policy was refreshed
806.description:
Windows Server 2003 is supposed to include per user selective auditing but no documentation exists from MS. You will occasionally see this event logged. See also event 807. 

See Roger Grimes article at www.windowsitpro.com for an excellent introduction to per user selective auditing.
806.llm_technical_description: Event 806 indicates the refresh of Per User Audit Policy (PUAP) in Windows Server 2003, which updates user auditing settings. This could affect user permissions and security configurations.

807.summary: Per user auditing policy set for user
807.description:
Not confirmed. See event 806 for more information on per user selective auditing. 

See Roger Grimes article at www.windowsitpro.com for an excellent introduction to per user selective auditing
807.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a policy change was made enabling per user selective auditing, allowing users to control their logging behavior by opting out of specific log categories.

808.summary: A security event source has attempted to register
808.description: A process identified by Process Id registered itself as being able to report events to the Windows security log. See event ID 809 also
808.llm_technical_description: A process has registered itself with the Windows security log, which typically occurs for system notifications such as user account management changes. This registration could indicate legitimate activities related to system monitoring or permissions updates.

809.summary: A security event source has attempted to unregister
809.description: A process degistered itself as source for reporting events to the security log. See event ID 808
809.llm_technical_description: The event indicates that a process has attempted to unregister itself as a security event source. This could be an attempt by an attacker to clean up their logging infrastructure, possibly for exfiltration of sensitive information or other malicious activities.

8191.operating_systems: Windows Server 2016, Windows 10, Windows Server 2019, Windows Server 2022
8191.llm_technical_description: The event with ID 8191 indicates a system-defined audit message of the highest value. This typically occurs during critical system activities such as user log-ons or failures that may require immediate attention.

848.summary: The following policy was active when the Windows Firewall started
848.description: This event is logged once each time Windows Firewall start which is usually at boot up. This event documents the highlevel policy settings in effect at the time of startup.
848.llm_technical_description: The Windows Firewall policy change during startup indicates the high-level firewall policies in effect at system boot. This could be a legitimate setup or configuration activity by an administrator. However, if there is a pattern of unexpected or malicious policy changes, it may warrant further investigation.

849.summary: An application was listed as an exception when the Windows Firewall started
849.description: This isn't really an event per se. It's just logged for each Windows Firewall applicationexception when the firewall starts in order todocument the exceptions that were active at the time. See also event ID 850.
849.llm_technical_description: This event logs when an application exception occurs during the Windows Firewall's startup process as a result of policy changes. It serves to document exceptions encountered at the time of firewall activation, aiding in troubleshooting and monitoring.

850.summary: A port was listed as an exception when the Windows Firewall started
850.description: This isn't really an event per se. It's just logged for each Windows Firewall exception when the firewall starts in order todocument the exceptions that were active at the time.
850.llm_technical_description: This event occurs when a firewall exception is logged during the Windows Firewall startup process. It serves as documentation for the exceptions active at that time.

851.summary: A change has been made to the Windows Firewall application exception list
851.description: Windows logs this event when an administrator changes the local policy  of the Windows Firewall or a group policy refresh results in a change to  the effective Windows Firewall policy - specifically exception rules  that allow traffic for specific applications.
851.llm_technical_description: The event indicates a change in the local policy of the Windows Firewall application exception list, which may involve modifying traffic rules for specific applications.

852.summary: A change has been made to the Windows Firewall port exception list
852.description: Windows logs this event when an administrator changes the local policy of the Windows Firewall or a group policy refresh results in a change to the effective Windows Firewall policy - specifically exception rules that allow traffic through.
852.llm_technical_description: This event indicates a change in the Windows Firewall port exception list. Such changes can be indicative of malicious activities like port scanning or attempting to establish unauthorized connections. However, they could also be legitimate updates aimed at blocking known threats.

853.summary: The Windows Firewall operational mode has changed
853.description: Windows logs this event when an administrator changes the local policy  of the Windows Firewall or a group policy refresh results in turning on or off the Windows Firewall operation mode.
853.llm_technical_description: The Windows Firewall operational mode has changed, which can occur due to administrator settings or group policy updates. This event is a normal administrative action and may not indicate malicious activity without additional context.

854.summary: The Windows Firewall logging settings have changed
854.description: Windows logs this event when an administrator changes the local policy   of the Windows Firewall or a group policy refresh results in a change to   the Windows Firewall logging settings.
854.llm_technical_description: The Windows Firewall Policy Change event (ID 854) indicates a modification by an administrator or group policy refresh. This event may inadvertently trigger appx package location checks on the deployment server as part of system updates, potentially for compliance monitoring.

855.summary: A Windows Firewall ICMP setting has changed
855.description: Windows logs this event when an administrator changes the local policy    of the Windows Firewall or a group policy refresh results in a change  to   the Windows Firewall ICMP settings.
855.llm_technical_description: The event indicates a change in the Windows Firewall ICMP settings, which can occur due to an administrator modifying firewall configurations or during group policy refreshes. This is a normal system-level event and does not inherently indicate malicious activity.

856.summary: The Windows Firewall setting to allow unicast responses to multicast/broadcast traffic has changed
856.description: Windows logs this event when an administrator changes the local policy     of the Windows Firewall or a group policy refresh results in a change   to   the Windows Firewall whether it should allow unicast responses to multicast and    broadcast traffic.
856.llm_technical_description: The Windows Firewall policy change indicates that an administrator has modified the setting allowing unicast responses to multicast and broadcast traffic, which can be indicative of potential malicious activity aimed at exerting network control or testing new policies without proper permissions.

857.summary: The Windows Firewall setting to allow remote administration, allowing port TCP 135 and DCOM/RPC, has changed
857.description: Windows logs this event when an administrator changes the local  policy  of the Windows Firewall or a group policy refresh results in setting the Windows Firewall setting to allow or disable remote administration.
857.llm_technical_description: This event indicates that the Windows Firewall policy has been modified to allow remote administration through TCP 135 and DCOM/RPC ports. This is a legitimate action performed by an administrator or as part of a group policy update, typically done for system configuration changes.

858.summary: Windows Firewall group policy settings have been applied
858.description: This event is logged whenever group policy is refreshed and a change in  the RSOP (resultant set of policy) of Windows Firewall policies is  detected.
858.llm_technical_description: The Windows Firewall group policy has been changed, which could indicate an attempt to deploy malicious software or elevate user privileges. This event is logged when a policy change occurs in the Resultant Set of Policy (RSOP) for Windows Firewall.

859.summary: The Windows Firewall group policy settings have been removed
859.description: This event is logged whenever group policy is refreshed and as a result the Windows Firewall policy settings are removed.
859.llm_technical_description: The Windows Firewall group policy settings have been removed. This event occurs during a normal policy refresh process and is typically automated by the Windows operating system as part of its maintenance tasks. Removing these settings may indicate an attempt to bypass legitimate administrative controls or access restrictions, potentially suggesting unauthorized changes or an attempt to manipulate user permissions.

860.summary: The Windows Firewall has switched the active policy profile
860.description: This event occurs, if the Windows Firewall profile changes from standard to domain and vica versa.
860.llm_technical_description: The Windows Firewall has switched between policy profiles (standard and domain), which is a normal operational activity. This can indicate legitimate administrative changes or potential insider threats if the profiles contain malicious configurations. The event does not inherently pose a security risk but requires context to assess for suspicious behavior.

861.summary: The Windows Firewall has detected an application listening for incoming traffic
861.description: This event documents applications that request to open UDP or TCP ports in listening mode and whether the request was allowed.
861.llm_technical_description: This event logs applications attempting to access specific ports in listening mode. Denial of these requests can indicate malicious activity, especially if the application is non-standard or critical.
